title: "Joke of a company"

cons: Don’t give a care in the world about their employees. They literally gave used books and thrift store items as rewards to high performers on my team and those next to us. I got a GS hat for doing the work of two people for a month. Would have preferred to have gotten nothing. Bonus is based on how you did compared to your peers not how well you actually did. Racist and sexist company. They have groups and associations for everyone and everything unless you’re white or a male or straight. Teammates do everything they can to crawl over you and get their name on your project so they can claim they helped lead and advise you on it. Managers only care about you if you’re going to help them get promoted.

Superficial culture; a lot of smiling up front and lots of trash talking behind people's backs. People love to gloat over the Goldman brand but in reality they are underpaid and work twice as much as anyone else. You want proof? Excluding management, the average tenure is less than 2 years. Chicago branch is able to sustain itself because of the large inflow of applicants wanting to be part of the prestigious GS brand. Little do they know the majority of the GS divisions are carried by the profitable few.

title: "Hands down, worst company I've ever worked for."
pros: Salary isn't awful. Starting pay pretty good at senior analyst level. Good for the resume.
cons: Where to start...worklife balance is essentially non-existent. 50-60 work weeks are pretty much the norm. Expect some weeks to be even longer. You really don't have vacation, I was expected to work remotely even though I was taking vacation or sick days. Which in turn would make me more sick and miss coming in more because I couldn't really rest. I would find myself working on projects for my managers, only to have them receive the credit and I wouldn't get any credit. You do get a decent salary, but there are really no benefits. You have to pay for parking, transportation, and any other "perks" offered. So in the end, your total take home pay really isn't a lot if you are at the analyst level, or even associate. The only benefit for working at Goldman would be at the Vice President or higher level. This is the level where the company actually will care about you. To move up to the top you pretty much need to dedicate your life to work, not have a family (which I have), and kiss up to the right people. This organization is extremely political, if this isn't your thing, don't expect to move up. The company uses a quartile system for performance. Which means even if everyone in your division is great, you can still be rated as a "low end" performer just because everyone else happens to be better than you. I found during my time there people in the company were encouraged to put others on the team down and be overly critical and nit-picky just so they could get a higher rating. This caused the environment to be extremely toxic. I found that the team as a whole did not work well together and in some cases were sabotaging each other's projects so that they would be marked down. Recruiters can deceive you. This might not be for all cases but I will share what happened with me and a factor for me leaving Goldman. A heavy selling point for me was that continuing education was paid for to an extent, but for me to get my MBA, it would pretty much be paid for. So with that as a "perk", I decided to expect a position at Goldman. Once I was eligible for the benefit, I approached my manager about pursuing this. Long story short, they said that would not be in their best interest as getting the MBA would "take time away from me doing my job" and that they have never given any one the benefit because "everyone would take advantage of it." I thought this was extremely shady on there end because recruiting sold the benefit as being widely used and easy to be approved for. All in all, I did not have a great experience and promptly left once a good opportunity opened up elsewhere.

title: "Fantastic Place To Start A Career"
pros: Working in the finance department is a good place to learn how to operate in a large company with multiple divisions. If you work hard you will receive significant responsibility. Internal mobility is difficult but possible, if you work hard and network you can move across divisions.
cons: Work tends to be process based rather than true problem solving. The company is large and therefore has its fair share of politics. There is a significant push for diversity, which I believe is important, but the effort has come at the cost of hiring less qualified candidates. Face time still exists, there is shaming for leaving earlier than others even if there is no more work to be done.

title: "High Turnover - Approach with Caution"
pros: generally smart and hard working colleagues, good benefits
cons: There has been very little attempt to properly integrate some groups in the SLC office with their counterparts in NYC. The experience likely varies from group to group, but I found there to be little to no incentive for any form of management to exist in the office. This in turn leads to extremely high turnover among dissatisfied employees who feel overworked, underpaid, and ignorant of any sort of progression or development. Much of what had attracted me to the opportunity never materialized beyond lip service in interviews.

title: "Good place to work"

title: "Great environment"

title: "Engaging culture"
pros: Challenging problems to solve constantly

title: "Terrible management"
pros: Interesting events to enhance experience of employees such as GS Talks, Round Table Discussions, and education opportunities within the firm. Networking is seen as important and firm offers ample opportunity to network with others at the firm.
cons: Not a merit based system, a popularity and favoritism based system. If you are liked by your manager and the MD over your department, you can easily get promoted. You just have to be liked more than the other people in your department. You'll see plenty of losers, lazy people, those with lesser credentials, and horrible leaders that are not well-liked get promoted. You can work harder than everyone and never move up due to this. Most often you will probably have a terrible manager that is not a subject matter expert and doesn't understand what you do because Goldman does not care whether you are a subject matter expert. Goldman cares only about putting people in management positions that the manager and MDs like. You'll see everyone in the office is 20 something. MDs are usually in their 30s or early 40s. Age discrimination for sure! You cannot really indicate concern with any problems because the firm utilizes 360 reviews, which means your peers provide your reviews. if your direct issue is with a peer or a manager, reporting bad behavior such as poor work ethic will only hurt those that are doing the right thing. Employees that do want change and need to report behavior will not for the sake of their career because of this awful system.

title: "Demanding"
pros: Strong population of employees that push you
cons: Could build a better leadership development program

title: "Great place to learn"
pros: Very competitive culture and you will learn a lot. People are eager to solve problems.
cons: Due to the competitive nature can be difficult to find work/life balance

title: "Loved it"
pros: Good leadership easy to get help good scheduling
cons: hard work takes dedication requires commitment not fun

title: "It was great for a while"
pros: Exposure to brilliant people and global businesses. Great learning opportunities.
cons: Salt Lake Office gets over worked and under paid. Very high turnover -many leave to pursue positions at neighboring institutions that pay more and have less stress.

title: "It's Goldman Sachs"
pros: Great place to work with a great expectation and emphasis on superior performance. As long as your expectations are aligned, the experience will be rewarding.
cons: Tech and automation disrupting every inch of financial services. From the front office to the back office. Macro outlook of total industry impact is still uncertain.

title: "Very positive learning environment"

title: "Great people, repetitive work"
pros: The people and opportunities for personal and professional growth are endless. A lot of resources where you can learn to code or any skill you want.
cons: Ops work is very repetitive and incredibly dull. You work at least 10 hours a day.

title: "Great place to work"
pros: There are no slackers here, they just don't last. It can be a very rewarding place to work, with so many smart people. Everyone pulls in the same direction and it's a very collective environment.
cons: The forced quartiling of staff is frankly 1980s MBA strategy and needs to end. While the firm is committed to diversity there is a lot more to be achieved in this space. The firm is incredibly hard charging and over the long run that can get challenging, particularly when children and partners enter lives.

title: "challenging place to work with great benefits to match"
pros: very personable staff and management; great benefits; engaging environment
cons: can get a little political

title: "Ruthless Culture"
pros: You will be surrounded by incredibly smart people, across all devisions.
cons: They don't value their people. The most important thing is the bottom line and that's quite clear in the culture of the company, starting at the leadership level.

title: "Steep learning curve"
pros: Smart peers. Candidates can learn from colleagues. System is mature. Analysts have less concern about infrastructure.

title: "Great place to work if you are oblivious toe what is happening around you"

cons: Very competitive environment which can wear you down

title: "Good but not great"
pros: Opportunities to learn and grow. Bright motivated people. Impactful work.
cons: Long hours. Depleted culture that fundamentally does not align with the stated values of the company. Limited work life balance.

title: "Marcus - rapidly becoming the call center job you didn’t sign up for."
pros: • The benefits are top notch, much more available to employees beyond the traditional health/vision/dental. The 401K plan is extremely generous for employees after their first anniversary, and tuition reimbursement is available at $10k a year. • Learning opportunities - you will learn more than you can possibly imagine. The networking that comes from the groups, events, and cross-division/departmental projects really help expand your skill set and resume. • Resume booster- a large percentage of my colleagues came to the firm for this very reason. Post Goldman life has also been very nice for most as they move on to other opportunities. • People - It was a privilege to work with such a talented group of people. Everyone has great ideas, strengths, and works extremely hard. Also of note, there are a lot of opportunities available to volunteer locally, people do really seem to genuinely care about what they do, and I was extremely impressed with how the firm handled any HR type issues.
cons: • Work/Life balance. I was fortunate to work in a division that offered overtime, however extra hours were always available and it was strongly encouraged to work extra. • Stress- Do more with less seems to be the philosophy here. Departments seem to be understaffed, overworked, and undertrained. Management seems to be reactive to change in staffing rather than proactively working to make the day easier for employees. Turnover is extremely high for a company of this caliber in the division I was in. • Pay - pay is subpar, and employees are discouraged from discussing this with each other. Annual raises, bonuses, and promotional increases could use some work to be in the same league as other companies. • Internal promotion can be difficult depending on the needs of your team. The firm tends to hire outside, and tends to promote management more frequently than those that work in operations. There’s not a lot of transparency about career pathing, and that heavily impacts morale.

title: "Great place to learn finance"
pros: Very smart and invested people, best people to learn from and start your career. Ability to get exposure to unimaginable number of different topics.
cons: Somewhat slow adoption of latest technologies and software

title: "Great place"

title: "Politics, Greed and Self-Interest"

cons: - Radical PC culture muzzles direct communication and effective problem-solving - Stale talent across the VP level despite the utter incompetence of many legacy employees - Backstabbing is rampant, as is turnover - Employees put their own interests above those of the clients - People are expected to suck up to management - So much bureaucratic red tape that it makes even basic tasks impossible - Tech is terribly outdated and slow

title: "Richardson TX Tech"
pros: Nice suburb office, gym. Learning experience dealing with people, low quality service from dependent teams, fighting fires caused by poor execution.
cons: Leadership, managers making people decisions. They hired lots of costly and underperforming contract workers, while allowing underpaid full time employees be responsible for cleaning up the mess and working long hours. High performing employees are not rewarded at this location. There is no incentive that can justify going the extra mile. Management is far more keen on justifying the low cost, high value nature of this location, to a point that the value of marginal out performance is compressed to zero. Quality of support you receive from the federated teams are dismal and frustrating.

Operations in particular is pretty bad. Ops is the red headed step child of the firm, and they would automate the whole division if they could.

Everybody is smart, but depending on the team, they have little interest in helping you learn and grow. title: "It's everything like you think it is, and then some!"

title: "Redundant back office task work, selfish management, constant cost cutting measures."
pros: A few managers and employees are bright and fun to work with.
cons: Constant cost cutting measures making it an increasingly less attractive place to work. Managers will set unrealistic mobility and flexibility expectations that they do not hold up to. Many managers entice new joiners by telling them there are opportunities for internal mobility or physical location mobility, which happens rarely. If you are okay with working a redundant back office role it's a good option, but things get boring quickly and value is not great for work life balance for how little the wages are.

Promises given by management are never followed through. They hire from outside the firm instead of promoting within. Ultimately a very disappointing experience.

title: "Mixed Bag - you will learn a lot but you will also get burned"
pros: You will work with incredibly smart and driven people. The benefits are good and there is focus on wellness and resilience. The Goldman name makes it really easy to get a huge comp bump and promotion when you leave.
cons: The work environment is incredibly intense and needlessly so. Management does not take a long view but rather jumps from one crisis to the next. Teams are short staffed which contributes to the constant need to put out fires rather than think about mitigating risk long term. In order to get a promotion, you need to play the politics game. Unfortunately there are some toxic individuals in senior leadership who will prevent anyone but their favorites from being promoted/get raises. Just doing a good job will not get you ahead -- you will need to lobby for promotions and raises.

title: "Great company for certain lifestyles"
pros: Depending on what your ultimate goal is for your life and family Goldman can be a great place to work. You are able to continually grow and improve as an employee at this company. They offer great maternity leave (16 weeks paid), good time off policies (depending on what department you work in too federal law requires you to take 1-2 consecutive weeks off work so you will be able to use your time off) and an ever changing environment.
cons: - No work life balance (I literally mean none, expect to work a min of 50 hours a week no matter your department) - Promoting is difficult (they use a quartiling system and only do promotions once a year in December) - If you don't like your team or job internal mobility is an option but is one of the most difficult experiences

title: "Vice President"

title: "Great for entry level employees"

cons: Pay difference for the same level is huge. The group and manager matters. Not all groups and managers are the same.

title: "Cheap Employer"
pros: They are really serious about innovation. Not a place where "keep your head down and get your work done" is emphasized.
cons: Not enough restrooms. Many employees roam the staircase, looking in floor after floor for an open bathroom. I have checked 8 floors before and still not found an open bathroom. Not a good place to work if you ever use the restroom.

title: "If in Tech, run away from this place."
pros: There are some genuinely honest and decent people working here.
cons: There might be a chance that you end up working in a team that's good, but it's far more likely that you will end up working in a team supporting decades old technologies, working with tech leaders that have no idea how to build a good tech ecosystem. This can end up wreaking havoc on your professional career as a technologist. You will learn nothing that will carry you forward in your career. At best, you'll end up with a brand name on your resume, but the bureaucracy and politics of this place will destroy your soul.

title: "Unsustainable"

cons: Poor work-life balance; unsustainable expectation to work consistently long hours while maintaining maximum productivity.

cons: -Very top heavy / bureaucratic -Plum assignments are given to those with most tenure not capability (to justify big pay checks) -Decision making power is concentrated to a small group and so limited ability create and own at mid to junior levels -jobs have become less aspirational

title: "Perfect for the upper middle class white male looking to jumpstart his career"
pros: Working at Goldman definitely made me a better employee. When I compare how I was before Goldman to after, I'm much more organized, focused, and precise. There's no room for imperfections as any mistake can have catastrophic consequences, and that mentality is hard to let go even when you leave! I also met some wonderful, brilliant people who challenged me, and I'm grateful to have gotten to work side by side with them.
cons: Now where do I begin... There is a deep deep foundation of inequality between men and women. Women are hired more often for certain roles rather than others, and not surprisingly those roles top out at VP rather than Managing Director or Partner like the roles that are more often held by men. Last year on national women's day (or a comparable made up holiday), we got an email from the executive office stating that they recognized the disparity between men and women at the firm, and in an effort to remedy that, they would be endeavoring to hire 50/50 men vs. women in the incoming analyst class...... This hollow attempt at a solution just floored me. It felt like throwing a limp soggy bandaid on a gaping wound. The problem isn't that you aren't hiring enough female analysts at the bottom of the ladder--the problem is that you aren't enabling women to stay in the workforce and move UP the ladder. Better yet, you aren't holding men to the same standards that you hold for women who seek the same promotions. For example, a good friend of mine spent ten years at the firm. She had multiple credentials behind her name, had recently gotten her MBA, and spoke up about wanting to make the switch to a separate position with more responsibility and room for upward mobility (also a role overwhelming held by men). Management told her that they were instead going to give her a different role that they'd just created--something sort of halfway between what she'd been doing already and what she wanted to do. Simultaneously, there was a guy who had been hired at the firm straight out of college, who'd been there two years and had no advance degrees but walked around with his chest puffed out, and management decided that he WOULD be a good fit for the same role that my friend was trying to get into. For what it's worth, this wasn't something that they were just hiring one person for but rather they were accumulating many candidates to train for the program all at once, so there was definitely room for the both of them at the onset. My friend kept fighting and finally she was given the okay to go into the program, but they'd managed to ruin the whole thing for her in the process. She ended up making the decision to leave the firm and is much better off now... But it was certainly an eye opening experience for me. If you're a woman, expect to work ten times as hard for the same opportunities. Additionally, and this is particularly timely given the recent cultural awareness provided by #metoo, if you're a woman, you can expect to get touched inappropriately by men that you work with. It's literally just something that you get used to. I'd be talking to my friends in other industries about this one guy who always puts his hand on my lower back or the other one that would rub my shoulders, and they'd be SHOCKED. Another dude would always find a way to get close to me at office happy hours and find some way to touch me. Meanwhile I was just used to laughing it off! Another time, a male supervisor reprimanded me for "not bothering to put on some earrings" before a client meeting. Mind you I was wearing makeup, a tailored Armani skirt suit, low Louboutin heels, and had done my hair, but that wasn't put together enough for him! He was wearing.... a suit. My work friends and I would all share stories over drinks, but we all knew that nothing was going to be done about it. Management was already aware, but the primary offenders were the rich white dudes that kept their business afloat (in their eyes), so there was no touching them (pun intended). How about another one... After my first year, I had exceedingly positive feedback in my 360 Feedback (the word "allstar" was used multiple times by multiple aforementioned important white men) and yet I got a 3% raise. A male peer had been hired a week after me in the same role, had made multiple mistakes that cost the firm money, and got a 6% raise (yes, we discussed these things). His bonus from the firm was also twice what I got. A year later the same guy was fired after he CONTINUED to make mistakes, and I was promoted to a different title but again only got a 3% raise. For anyone who is want to say that women make less because they don't negotiate, I can promise you I fought tooth and nail for a higher raise, and was given a YOU'RE WELCOME with my measly 3%. If you're pretty and you're smart, you won't have any trouble making friends, but you WILL have a hard time getting ahead. I wish I'd known ahead of time!

title: "Great Place to Work"

title: "Marcus"
pros: Nice pay and office environment
cons: People leaving in droves All decisions being made in NYC SLC is an island

title: "Toxic Culture"
pros: Great benefits, generous PTO, looks good on the resume.
cons: The culture is within Marcus is very toxic and political. Management only focuses on people who kiss up to them, you only get ahead by management liking you, rather than the results you get. The pay is below market value. The culture is that you work ridiculous hours or you are considered lazy. Everyone is there to get ahead even if it means throwing someone else under the bus. Change is horribly communicated, you are expected to fall in line and not ask questions.

title: "Changing Culture"
pros: Very smart and highly driven people work here and the company takes care of its people. Lots of high profile speakers come to visit and the firm gives you access to great resources (benefits, etc.)
cons: Culture shifting and become more political - it really is about who you know.

title: "Associate"
pros: Great working environment with intellectually stimulating colleagues.
cons: Aggressive demands and working hours.

title: "Operations"
pros: Brand name will help you get a better job once you burn out 401k, health insurance, vacation
cons: Poor management - lack of leadership, professionalism and regard for team. If you’re not best friends with your manager or speak the same language as them, good luck getting ahead. If your manager is insecure or considers you a threat to their career, you will be slandered in front of others, talked down to, not given projects, given FALSE negative feedback, not given opportunities to speak up, and prevented from any internal mobility opportunities. Terrible pay, terrible bonus structure for non-rev. If you have a real degree and actually put in effort in college, don’t take that job in Operations. You will be underpaid based on your education, and doing the type of work that does not require a degree and should have been automated or outsourced years ago (ie. DATA ENTRY, copying and pasting, checklists etc.). Embarrassing to describe what you actually do at work and really difficult to spin it in a way that will make you seem attractive to new employers. Outdated technology and systems. Systems cannot support the business or client requests and do not connect between teams (teams are not familiar with systems if they don’t use them). Any mistake has an extremely negative effect on ops and you will be held accountable even if the mistake occurred due to other team’s oversight/negligence. New and “innovative” ideas to help streamline processes are disregarded. Lots of cool events related to company values but no one seems to abide by them. Lots of closed door meetings, lack of transparency and poor communication amongst teams. EXTREMELY HIGH TURNOVER due to all of the above and burnout.

title: "Sweat Shop & Under appreciated Work"
pros: Great resume builder Good networking for your future Awesome learning lessons/continual growth both in your career and personally
cons: Step on other to get ahead mentality Hard work does not matter if you are not a favorite by your manager Staying late just to prove you love your job Terrible salary in Operations; only good salary in revenue generating jobs (IBD, IMD etc.) False promises on more you can get involved in

title: "I would not recommend"
pros: The job is fairly the easiest job
cons: Although the job is very very easy, the find ways to grade you that do not make sense and are not customer or company impacting, its just a way to say that they're doing something and to monitor some sort of progress. The pay is ok, but only if you were downgrading from a higher paying job and they'll try to match it with maybe $2,000 salary decrease. They are not clear about any decisions they make. One day you can hear something and the next it can be completely different. Managers do not care about the employees what so ever and about 99% of the employees there, complain DAILY about how much they hate the job and are all actively looking. The switch you to schedules you didn't sign up for. I've had my schedule changed 3 times since I was employed, without my request. They even took incentive pay from the employees who worked over night, they didn't let them know until it was going into effect.

title: "DONT go to this place!"

cons: Hopeless & toxic environment. People who can con others succeed. Hard working souls are shown the door. 360 degree feedback is a Joke as it is purely opaque and has unbelievable power vested in the hands of Few MD's that can play around with your career.

title: "VP, Engineer"
pros: Very good health/medial/dental/vision benefits. Nice perks like live interviews with famous people in different industries. Lots of opportunity to learn the ins and outs of the financial/investing sector. Nice co-workers.
cons: Tech salaries are about 10-20% below market. Super strict environment. SEC restrictions abound. They train you every year on the countless reasons for which you can be fired. Very much a "what have you done for me lately" culture. Unless you're an intern or a new college hire, whatever you do is never good enough. The best you can hope for is a neutral "ok, you can keep your job today." Highly political. Fear is the key motivator. High turn-over. Guaranteed layoffs every year of the lowest performing 5-10%. Mgmt not worried about turn-over because they heavily recruit new blood from universities.

title: "Worse than Wells Fargo"
pros: Higher pay, good benefits, PTO and sick time. Highly professional, intelligent and mature people at building 111
cons: With all feelings set aside, I’m going to list the facts about this department and it’s truths that I wish so badly I had seen on here before I started with them.gokdman Sachs sought me out to hire, and before I went forward with being recruited, I ADAMANTLY inquired if they would work with my schooling and had accommodations. They assured me several times they would since they were a competitive company, and had a reputation. This was not the case. Here are the facts I did not know until AFTER I was hired, and the events that took place: From day one, training is serious. It is intense and you must pay attention and pass exams; study hard. If you don’t pass, they will work with you if you show the determination, otherwise they will let you go. There are a series of exams: written, oral, and hands on, and it’s unnecesarily extensive. They don’t provide any lunch or snacks at all, esp for your first day; you’re on your own. It is a call center, though smaller. You must work a MANDATORY 40 + hours a week, and no less. That appointment you needed to go to, or that errand to run? You can go, but you will have to make it up in that week in overtime of cutting your lunch hours, otherwise you will be fired. My schooling? They refused to work with me on that specifically, and even when I went, I had to make up the time, forcing me to drop the class by mid semester; my last english class. You are monitored and expected to be at your desk performing 7 hours a day; the computers track what is called your adherence. If you are not following this strictly, esp with assigned breaks within a few minutes’ time, you will be fired. I recently received a lecture for using the restroom off break time, and how I ought to control that. The same lecture was given in training. The coffee is the most awful thing you’ll ever have there, and though few poeple drink it out of desperation, and many complain, no one does anything about it; they are also CONSTANTLY breaking! Some go unfixed for months at a time. The accommodations I needed were not given. In terms of ergonomics, it took months to receive the necessary equipment, and in terms of having a sit/stand installed... it arrived after six weeks, but delisted emails and such, it’s still not been installed. I was moved to a desk that already had one, finally. Most of those you work with dislikes their job, and it’s very taboo, but known. They start because the benefits are good, but that’s it. The environment is immensely stressful, and too much pressure is out on the employees for more, more , more even beyond breaking points. When I called the HR hot line to speak with a counselor, they told me they had no sick thing (they do, but I found out over a week later after investigating again). My first doctor under the insurance network, upon meeting me, looked st my chart and said “Goldman Sachs, eh?? We get quite a few people from there, here, for stress.” There is no such thing as work-life balance. You are expected to dedicate yourself in almost your entirety to them, and your life/family revolves around them. Much is expected from you, but little, it at all, is given back. No other incentives like prizes, pizza, snacks really, unless it’s out of pocket. The leadership is very poor in terms of praise or affirmation; you constantly shown what you are doing wrong , not right. I started with this company with high hopes and expectations, for they were fed to me. However, I’m currently looking for another job as this place is highly disappointing. Everyone works very hard, but again, little is given back. The high up management seem to be optimistic and encourage you, but then those below them could care less about you beneath; it’s whatever they can gain for themselves that matters. However, I give credit that my immediate managers are very good and learning to listen. It’s the ones above them that don’t care. The outlook continues to go downhill or plateau from here; it apparently was more lax and fun when the department started; now it’s unbearable with the unrealistic work loads and pressure. Compared to other departments, we seem to be the step-child in terms of being heard or ignored. If you truly enjoy working a lot and dedicating yourself almost wholly to a company that will invest in you otherwise, then this job is for you. They will invest in you, but only if you give them 200%, no less. They only expect the best , if not then better, and then even better, from you. They will not stoop “down” for your needs to bring you “up;” you must meet them upward first.” *update* Since I have left, more and more employees have quit, and after moving homes, switching childrens' schools and cancelling parking passes in order for the department to move to draper as promised this October, overnight an email was sent postponing everything for another month; company has not compensated employees for anything, not even parking. Employees that were hired into a specific job were moved to another against their will, despite contract agreement. The department has become more unorganized, chaotic, and overbearing.

title: "Associate - Operations"
pros: Infinite opportunities if you are driven, and hard work pays off. Salaries, bonuses, and benefits are hard to beat, but they come at a personal price. The company is pretty accommodating to special schedules (working from home, certain days off during the week, late/early start, etc). The people are incredibly smart, driven, creative, and diverse--and that's what kept me motivated. It's definitely the people I'll miss the most.
cons: Work-life balance is hard to achieve here. Face-time is built into the core of the culture, so long days are standard. Working your tail off and having something to show is what is valued at GS. Ten hours is a standard work day in Operations--not eight. If you want/need to work eight hour days, you take a 20% pay cut. Teams are incessantly understaffed. Layoffs happen every year and each team feels the constant pain of losing people who had knowledge, struggling to get through the daily workload, and constantly starting over and training new people. If you haven't had a promotion in a couple years, you are on the chopping block. Technology infrastructure is wildly outdated; in one function, you can use upwards of 40 different applications/web tools. Processes are painfully manual because of old and non-integrated technology.

title: "Great"

title: "Financial Engineer"

title: "Executive Assistant"
pros: Overall as a whole the company itself is great. The salary and perks are amazing. Couldn't ask for anything more in that area but....
cons: The peoplele in the IBD department are for the most part spoiled Prima Donna's. Everyone is SOOOO passive aggressive and expects you to read their minds. The MD I worked with was truly this case as well as one of my Associates. No one minds working and doing their job but sometimes you have to do something for yourself and they can't do anything. As an assistant I realize that you are supposed to make things happen but sometime you have to ask questions and when you do, you get looks like your an idiot. The passive aggressive, I'm better than you, I can't do anything for myself behavior is REAL!! People you work with everyday will walk right past you and not say a word but will speak when they need something from you. The owners family member was more personable and he had more reason to be rude and obnoxious than the others, not that, that is acceptable but he does. the culture they strive so much to have needs a lot of work. I did have great people in my group my bankers not so much.

title: "Decent work environment, uncompetitive pay"
pros: I'm on a "front office" tech team in NY, and given all the negative reviews I've seen for technology, I was actually pleasantly surprised to see that they are trying to make things more fair between tech vs. strats (and "revenue generating" roles). There's a lot of things that Silicon Valley companies could learn from how GS runs its business. Since career progression for junior employees is largely based on arbitrary metrics like number of years out of school, if you have a BA vs MA vs PhD vs MBA etc., in certain situations when you're transitioning from a different career path you can actually get pretty nice pay for your experience, even though overall GS pay doesn't seem that great.
cons: The pay for junior employees really doesn't compare to what big tech is paying these days. You could double the bonus and it still wouldn't be able to match FANG pay. You can tell that the new grads and interns coming into tech/strats are not really the best. Then again, this is probably by design, but it's not great if you're an employee. The perks do need some upgrading IMO, for morale reasons. The cafeteria and vending machines are not exactly cheap, and being able to afford the more expensive snack/food items unintentionally signals your status/income level. Slightly upgraded drinks at the water cooler like soda/sparkling water, maybe some snacks, and slightly subsidized cafeteria food would help.

title: "Vice President Investment Banking"
pros: Top level management is very adept at executing strategic initiatives.
cons: Culture has eroded over the years as promotions and ability to earn based on merit have deteriorated

title: "BI Specialist"
pros: It is a great place to work
cons: The hours are somewhat insane

title: "Vice President"
pros: Surrounded by smart, hard working people. Opportunity to work on great projects.
cons: Be prepared to work 24/7

title: "Financially rewarding"

title: "Ops"

title: "Great Company"
pros: Big Company. Pays well, still not as competitive with FANG for senior engineers. Adjusted comp this year to compete with big tech firms at analyst/associate level(junior engineers) - not for senior engineers yet. You can learn a lot from technology side and from company/team politics. You will be challenged many times in your career. You can build a career/not a 2 year job - there - if you play your cards correctly and be patient.
cons: Long hours. Start early, leave late. Proprietary technology in many teams, but more adoption of newer technology in past few years. Pay distribution was not fair at least this year. Top performing Technology Analysts and Associates were paid more than top performing VPs in the same team/many teams. It is good news to see an adjustment to pay for analysts and associates to match big tech, but demotivating to existing top performing VPs with way more years of experience to know analyst total comp was higher. Titles don't mean much now. Titles control base pay, but bonuses are at discretion of Managing Directors and this is what make the difference in pay at end of year. Either adjust VP total comp to be higher than associates/analysts, or more VPs will leave. Vps who stay will also lose motivation after they know they have way more responsibilities and less pay than team members they are tutoring/getting up to speed.

title: "Collaborative, supportive, stimulating environment"

title: "GS"
pros: Small teams become your second family - whether you love or hate them. Because of small teams, you have a say on how to improve workflows and outputs. Work life balance was getting better over time (usually 50-60 hours a week). Flexibility in your job to work from home if needed. Managers usually very accommodating to personal situations. Able to interact with many different departments. If you work hard and get in with the right people at the start you have a good chance to grow.
cons: Operations department was very repetitive Lack of clarity in the interview to what your potential job actually is. Bureaucracy, no so much Meritocracy, make sure you get in with your people who review you early.

title: "The Best People in the Industry"
pros: Goldman consistently attracts the best people in finance. It has a tremendous culture of teamwork and communication. The leadership is far-sighted and steers the firm well in tumultuous markets. The platform opens incredible doors all around the world.
cons: The firm has become increasingly commercial over the years, which is obviously the point of the entire enterprise, but in a way that can be off-putting. The overarching mission of the company has become less inspiring. The hours can be brutal. And compensation is lower than industry average because their brand is at the top of the industry.

title: "Analyst working in SLC"
pros: 1. The company has a good culture. Ppl are respectful, nice, and willing to help. 2. A great company to go for the first job out of school 3. Salt Lake City is very cheap to live in a decent life. (you can get a fancy 1b1b apartment for less than $1200/ month) 4. You have GS under your resume.
cons: 1. Honestly, SLC office is a giant in-house outsource center for GS. The most of teams are doing things that ppl in NY don't even bother to do. 2. Hard to move laterally to hub cities' GS offices (some ppl can, It's like one out of ten chance), so you want to use SLC experience to leverage into NY HQ, think twice. 3. The work is boring AF, and your learning curve will plateau after three months. 4. Turnover is high. It is depressing when you constantly see people you know leaving the firm. 5. It's Utah, not NYC, there is not that much finance opportunity in SLC.

title: "Modern Slave Ship"
pros: The Goldman name on your resume! Nice coffee and tea services. Free dinner if you work 12 hours in one day.
cons: It’s a slave ship. A meat grinder atmosphere that will destroy you. Many people come for the name and future job potential. Many leave after a few years after they realize it’s hell on earth. 60 hrs a week is the minimum and don’t expect market wages as senior management believe they don’t need to pay market since the privilege of working for Goldman is a form of compensation. Also, they stack rank people on a yearly basis and the lowest ranked person from your team will be fired. If you are a team of 5 geniuses but you happen to be the least genius one, you will be fired!

title: "Tech - 2018 is looking good"

I here high performer analysts this year received around 40k bonus and 30% salary increase, which is unprecedented. Not sure how they compensated people at higher levels. Upper management is trying to match other tech companies' compensation to compete for top people now.
cons: In some teams expect to work multiple weekends and also stay late. On an avg day people leave around 7 pm. Some people log back in when they get home.

title: "Intern"

cons: Long hours and stressful, little room to climb up corporate ladder even with highly skilled and experienced in the particular field.

title: "Great Culture"
pros: This was my first job out of college and I was blown away by the mentorship and access to senior members of the firm. I was not expecting this coming in as an analyst but now that I have experienced the culture at other firms, it makes me appreciate the time and effort that senior people both within and outside of my team put in.
cons: The hours were tough, but I was expecting that going in. It can be a high stress environment at times so you just have to be prepared for that and figure out how to get through those moments.

title: "Research Assistant"
pros: Fast paced, learn a lot with quality co-workers

title: "It's not great any more"

title: "Unrealistic Expectations"

title: "GS"

title: "Great place, not for everyone"

cons: Despite what people will tell you, the company is very political from middle management upwards and increasingly so as you move up. This can sometimes get in the way of well-intended employees looking to focus on the work.

title: "Top investment bank"
pros: Smart people, good benefits and lots of internal opportunity
cons: Competitive culture, poor work/life balance

title: "Analyst"
pros: Incredible Culture & People are great
cons: You have to put in the hours

title: "Great Place"
pros: -Lots of great professionals to learn from
cons: -Get ready to work some long hours

title: "Work hard and get rewarded, learned a lot"
pros: Worked for full time here for 6 years. Great place to learn and start your career. Learned an incredible amount and I would say if you are able to prove yourself even if you are young, you will get the additional responsibility you deserve, at least in my group. Amazing mentorship as well.
cons: Certain aspects can be micro-managing but I can understand why given the fear of compliance issues.

title: "Good"

cons: A poor work / life balance as one might expect, compensation is not always competitive in the industry.

title: "Good employer"
pros: Good compensation and positive outlook
cons: Long hours and stressful environment

title: "Look for a real technology job if you are in tech"
pros: Good people to work with, interesting projects, flexible work from home policy highly dependent on team, 401k 100% matching up to a certain amt. Good resume builder.
cons: No loyalty. Every year they let go 5% of the company, stagnant salaries for the amount of work that you were expected to do, new hires with no experience are receiving 35K more in compensation than people that have been there for a few years. Upper management is incompetent and provides no leadership.

title: "Great place to start your career"
pros: great culture and support system (supportive and understanding for newcomers). Internal mobility is encouraged and supported. I transferred to another team on day 1 and felt very supported
cons: Since it’s is a big and structural firm, it can take awhile to move a project somewhere. I think they are trying to become a tech driven financial firm without having all the perks the tech companies offer

title: "Strats"
pros: good environment in the new york city
cons: less money and i just made it

title: "Amazing"
pros: Get to work with a lot of smart people who are always willing to help you grow in your technical skills as well as help you progress throughout your professional career. Just an over all positive uplifting place to work and grow with challenging work and benefits to match.
cons: Something that is somewhat of a con is that there can be a lot of red tape involved when getting things done, some times this is for good reason as we are a high profile bank we have to be very strategic in the risk we take and can not always be on the bleeding edge of technology.

title: "Vice President"
pros: - Fast paced environment - You are continuously challenged by very intelligent people. - Good pay and benefits
cons: - Technologies used are a bit behind the curve. - All tech solutions have a layer of customization that sometimes makes it completely different than original product.

title: "Good Pay, Terrible Politics"
pros: Well compensated, amazing 401k, met lots of smart colleagues.
cons: Was struck physically multiple times by line managers in two different divisions. "Long term greedy" was abandoned by 2010.

title: "long hours but focus mostly on getting things done"
pros: great place to start a career, mostly long hours, but people are generally nice and focus is mostly on getting things done. This usually results in great friendships and a lot of on the job learning.
cons: politics, definitely as you grow in the org, as well as long hours likely not compensated as much as in the peers.

title: "Be careful working here"
pros: Fast paced - put in a lot of hours for the salary and benefits.
cons: They never tell you everything, you will never be good enough, and most not in the top quartile work out of fear of losing their job. Of course they don't tell you which quartile you are in. You are watched the entire time you are in the building. No privacy.

title: "Lots to learn"
pros: - Great people. Super smart - Can teach any individual a lot about the capital market - For someone out of college this job will be proven to be very rewarding after the initial 2-3 years
cons: - Increasing politics; too many committees to get things done

title: "Great Place to work for!"
pros: High pay and bonuses (based on your performance of course), great work environment (people working there is really willing to help you and you are expected to do the same with your colleagues) and culture, plenty of benefits offered,
cons: Huge amount of working hours (especially at the beginning of your career) and low balance between work and personal life (but I think it’s pretty much a standard in all big investment banks).

title: "Work culture can be better"
pros: You get to be part of a big team and complex environment. Good learning experience.
cons: No worklife balance Dont give good increments You are overloaded with tons of responsibilities

title: "ficc sales"
pros: great comp, pverall great company
cons: not nearly as fun as it used to be

title: "Awesome"
pros: Great Company to work for
cons: none to say that is negative

title: "The good, the bad, the ugly....."
pros: Good compensation as long as you give blood. I would only recommend for the compensation.
cons: You may encounter some of the most viscious and nasty people ever in a career. POLITICS!! Meaning you may not get promotions or career advancement unless you play the game.

title: "The people are the reason to join and stay"

title: "Talented people"
pros: 1. Highly talented and motivated folks 2. Flexible working environment 3. Lots of automation projects for tech folks to work on

Younger one can thrive here. 3. GS calls itself a tech firm when it is not one. Tech is in old state but trying hard to move away. 4. Too many committee to approve any $$ spend. It can take months to approve even the smallest project. 5. Managers changes job often (in the name of mobility) creating lots of obstacles for project planning and execution.

title: "GREAT"

title: "Excellent Career Opportunity"
pros: Great team culture. Personal growth. Financial knowledge and experience.

title: "Great place to learn"

title: "delined over the years"

title: "Not great for tech."

title: "Investment Banking Analyst"
pros: -People. Incredibly smart and hard-working people. Bankers in the SF group were generally pretty humble (for finance) -Good deal flow. Being in the SF IBD office, you get to work on some of the world's most high-profile transactions -Culture. The GS culture is about working smart, working hard, being positive and professional. I never saw anyone really get yelled at.
cons: -Hours. I heard it's gotten better now, but if you sign-up to be an i-banking analyst, you will be working extremely long hours (unpredictable hours, work during weekends and holidays, hard to plan dinners and trips with friends). E.g. I was happy if I got home at midnight and could do my laundry.

title: "Great Place to Work!"
pros: Great company to work. Team oriented culture, motivated and driven employees focused on creating the best products.
cons: Intense environment and hours can be long and unpredictable.

title: "Toxic Culture"
pros: good professional training, trial by fire
cons: terrible toxic culture, no meritocracy or best idea wins mentality. managers are in place because they are either good at the role or have been there a while, NOT because they are any good at managing others. comp is far below market. those who do best are people who come from lower tier schools and feel like this is their big shot and are willing to put their head down, take a beating, and be grateful for getting nothing.

title: "Great place to learn and grow your career"
pros: No shortage of amazing projects
cons: Too many managerial changes looses sight of continuity of deliverables

title: "Good Learning Opportunity"
pros: Great environment to grow and learn. Work is getting done.
cons: Management generally don't care about employees Poor pay if you count in all of the stress and hours.

title: "SE"
pros: Tough fun exciting new people
cons: Too much work, this isn't important

title: "VP"
pros: Great people and interesting work.

title: "Great Company"
pros: Good pay, great people. New York Office is really nice
cons: Long hours and the benefits are dropping

title: "Good place to work if you want to learn regardless of the pay/v long hrs"
pros: Smart and hard working people you work with in general compared to what you will find elsewhere Good starting salary if you are being hired as a lateral hire but after that its mostly downhill
cons: Salaries can really go down if you do not perform at a top level. Meeting expectations of your job responsibilities means that you are at the very bottom and need to improve a lot as going beyond your basic role is expected. If you work in the controllers group then forget about taking off for any month end dates and quarter end dates which usually takes away July 4th and New Years.

title: "Client Service Professional"
pros: Flexibility. Collaborative Company Culture.
cons: Limited mobility unless in NYC

title: "Good not great"
pros: Very smart people and very rewarding
cons: Too stressful at times. It is not for everyone

title: "Large company, small minded with specific division."
pros: Good Pay. Security. Great Benefits
cons: There's many branches within Goldman. So I can not speak to them all as the company is massive. However for the division I work in I see a few issues. One being that management talks behind the backs of the employees. Also that if someone is not doing well in the division, it's openly known on the floor. I've had one co-worker who had really no business knowing another co-workers standing talking to me about "His numbers" and how poorly he does, and basically what a looser he is. If this was one isolated incidents it would be one thing, but it just isn't. I've had this come up in meetings with my manager where he discussed the standing of someone and though didn't give an name, gave descriptors that made if fairly clear who he was talking about. I've also noticed that thought they do attempt to coach and help these people, they also treat them like they are total morons, talking just a bit more slowly, or explaining things just a bit more than necessary. This sometimes coming from manager who have only had this and one other job in the two or three years they've actually been old enough to work.... Manager I'm thinking of is 22. It's only his second job. No education past High School talking to an older man with a bachelors and 40 years work experience under his belt. Speaking of age, I have also noticed within our division, no one over a certain age gets promoted. There is a huge age gap in regards to who's moving up and who's not. This I find highly disturbing in that it appears to be clear age discrimination. Though the job is secure, they will not fire anyone for the most part. In all likelihood to avoid unemployment penalties. However they will keep people around bumping down their pay and putting them through Hell trying to push them out. On the surface it's a friendly upbeat environment. Under the surface though it's very very dysfunctional edging on abusive. One last thing to note..... the company is VERY conscious of it's image. They are big on "Reputational Risk." In working here you are told you are forbidden to act in any way politically, like any protests, volunteering with certain groups, etc. So be sure you are willing to trade your civil and constitutional rights fr a pay check. It's to the point that one person who wanted to volunteer with the opera of all things was told she had to get permission from a review board before she could even look at it. Beyond mind boggling.

title: "Great place to work but a bit behind the times on technology"
pros: - Great group of people to work with, which is helpful given the extensive hours - Lot of internal mobility options if you tire of the same role and would like to try something different; often easier interview process relative to external hires making it easy to join in a federation role and transition to a client facing role
cons: - This has been said in numerous reviews but the hours can be incredibly challenging At times. - Even in client facing roles “pet projects” and unecesary bureaucracy can add to the burden and become frustrating - Technology is outdated with a lot of computationally heavy work being done in Excel.

title: "Decent Experience"
pros: Compensation is decent for new york area
cons: Culture can be toxic as the primary focus here is alpha centered

title: "Great place to work"
pros: The smartest people on Wall St hands down Opportunities to be promoted are very good in SLC Work life balance is awesome in SLC Great place to have a family and a successful career at a top tier firm
cons: Very political Not a true meritocracy Lower-paced in SLC, not as upbeat as NY SLC employees are viewed as "less" than NY (at least everyone feels that way) SLC salaries are much lower than any other bank in SLC

title: "Stay away if you love programming"
pros: a)People assume you are very rich because you work at GS. b)You meet some very capable individuals
cons: a) Despite the constant sound of GS being "one team", the differences even in terms of facilities such as the kind of desk, floor and coffee machines between Technology and Operations are significant with Technology being treated like a doormat. b) Despite the recent attempts at calling themselves a "Technology Company competing with Google for talent", the fact is neither the pay nor the average quality of engineers is even 20% of what Google is. c) While there is gym and cafeteria, it is cheaper to walk outside the building and find a better food/facility at half the price you pay within the building. d) Toxic politics with constant bickering amongst middle management who see no chance of moving to MD level and are always frustrated e) While the company boasts about teamwork, you are alone when there is a crisis due to some inadvertent mistake. You will be punished severely with multiple people questioning you why you went wrong 0.01% while nobody appreciates when you were right 99.99% f) Company doesn't believe in spending even a single dime on you besides your compensation signed in the offer letter. You will be asked to attend many Friday evening drinks all of which are self-funded and you pay around 20 bucks even if you just had a 3 dollar beer. g) You will not learn any new technical skills h) Nobody will allow you to work on a new open source technology unless the bureaucracy has approved it. That means hundreds of people spend loads of time doing the same repetitive work in Excel. i) Too much time wasted on useless meetings with incapable people. j) Work from home is not encouraged. k) Work space is extremely congested for Technology team with everyone sitting next to each other with a gap of less than 1 feet on a large open bench.

title: "Over view"
pros: Smart colleagues, and the brand.
cons: Lack of true appreciation for employees, constant cost cutting and benefit reducing, expansive healthcare, expensive cafeteria, lack of clarity in promotions to MD, lack of respect for below MD titles, not a flat organization I. Practice. Limited number of vacation carryovers and won’t pay for carryover days if/when you leave. Promotion to MD is every other year, more than half of employees are VPs.

title: "Investment Management"
pros: Very highly regarded firm, looks good on resume
cons: Highly political Pay more a function of who likes you than performance

title: "Rigid, stuffy, and over-managed"
pros: It's a system that works, for the bankers and the IB professionals. Many good perks for people in the NY office. Competitive pay.
cons: Unless you are an actual banker, you have no support from the company. The red tape will choke you to death.

title: "Great first job"
pros: Despite some of the bad reviews, the firm is actually very good place to start. You build valuable contacts and learn important processes. But its not the 90's anymore.
cons: Very conservative place, by its nature I suppose. Its hard to suggest new things or change processes. The organization is hulking now, so there's a lot of bureaucratic sluggishness.

title: "Great people to work with"
pros: People are so sharp. Great diversity. Pay growth can be strong with high performance. Great pay for SLC.
cons: Never under 50 hours per week, that's pretty universal.

title: "Not bad- good perks, long hours, good exit opportunities"

title: "Associate"

cons: Heavy bureaucracy , long hours, work/life balance is an issue

title: "Recruiter"
pros: Career growth. Professional environment providing a great foundation to success. Training & Mentoring.
cons: Perception of having to be on the desk or you're not productive.

title: "Employee Relations"
pros: Smart and talented team members

title: "Quantitative Analyst"

title: "Analyst"

title: "Private Wealth Advisor"

title: "Good Place to Work"
pros: Great pay and benefits.
cons: Upward mobility limited to EA's

title: "Goldman Sachs"
pros: Pros include Opportunities, culture, people.
cons: Cons include Compensation, senior management

title: "Good place to start your careers"
pros: Smart people around and incomparable infrastructure ( SecDb )
cons: Long working hours and hierarchy in the office

title: "BEST COMPANY!"
pros: I have worked at most of the major Financial firms on the 'street' and Goldman Sachs is by FAR the best place to work. They are cutting edge in their collaborative work environment. Diversity is mandatory and everyone's voice matters. They don't just talk the talk they walk the walk. It feels like I work for Google and not a financial company. You are allowed and expected to constantly learn new things and challenge yourself. I couldn't be more grateful to such an awesome company. It only took me a very unpleasant past experience at a company to appreciate how wonderful other companies and managers can truly be...
cons: Only wish I would have worked here long ago...

title: "Intense"
pros: Excellent, hard-working, ambitious people around. Offers trainings, talks and other development opportunities. Program can be flexible. The bonus is good.
cons: Long hours, work takes highest priority. Sometimes given more projects than one can actually complete in the time window. Need to fulfill various roles depending on the temporary requirements of the company.

title: "Wonderful summer IBD analyst experience"
pros: mentorship, steep learning curve, people, and variety of questions
cons: long hours, but manageable, weekend work

title: "Work culture"
pros: Strong work culture in the office
cons: Long working hours during the day

title: "Toughest Job You'll Ever Love"
pros: The people are enthusiastic, intelligent, collaborative, and fun. Things are always changing and there is always an opportunity to take on more responsibility.
cons: Very long hours and often stressful.

title: "Tech could be better"
pros: Surrounded by very bright people. Great place to work for driven individuals who require only the minimum managerial oversight. The culture can wildly vary depending on which team you join. Firm in general has a desire of building their own solutions over vendor products which means you’ll always have some new interesting initiative to build (even if it’s just rebuilding what an open-source would already provide).
cons: Preference to build rather than buy technology solutions means a profuseness of buggy libraries and services with little or no documentation and support. Often integrating with such systems hinges on the success of who you know that can point you in the right direction (“talk to so-so who may be able to refer you to someone who may know somebody that has a foggy memory of how you use that convoluted API”). Team cultures vary. I’ve worked on close-knit groups where everyone worked hard for the common goal, while other teams I’m just a headcount regardless of my contributions.

title: "Tech Analyst"
pros: Prestigious company and it looks good on a resume. Surrounded by smart people.
cons: Tech employees are treated as support, rather than being part of the team. The company is very political and they fire a percentage of employees from each department on one day each year.

title: "Career Path Ambiguity"
pros: Fast paced environment and very smart and talented people
cons: People management inst what it used to be. Alot of attrition.

title: "Not a good company for IT professionals"
pros: Diversity and ability to work with multiple regions in different areas. Competitive pay.
cons: Bad management and leadership overall. Not a fair review or advancement opportunities.

title: "Goldman"
pros: Wonderfully intense. Intellectual. Ethical. Driven.
cons: No down side. If you have the right mindset, it's a great place to work.

title: "Analyst - GSAM"

title: "Goldman Sachs - Part Time Tax Clerk"

title: "Great firm to start your career"

title: "Misogynist, racist, anti-Semitic boss.  Run away NOW."
pros: None. None. None. None. None.
cons: I was unfortunate enough to be stuck with a misogynist, racist, and anti-Semitic manager. Example: When setting the support rota for April, he waited until I went to lunch, sat down with everyone else on my team, and pulled out a calendar and deliberately scheduled me to be on call during Passover. (He himself never took call.) Another example: I was held at fault for "arriving late" every time there was a delay on the Metro-North commuter rail or the subway. Yet another example: There was a subway strike while I was at GS. All employees who had to take the subway were allowed to telecommute for the duration of the strike. My manager was not affected by the strike. He wrote me up for telecommuting because it was "unnecessary" -- for HIM. I did my best to deal with the situation, but it was untenable. I approached upper management, who told me to deal with it. I ultimately dealt with it by quitting for my own mental health and finding a job in Midtown Manhattan where they understood that delays on Metro-North were Metro-North's fault, not mine. And their idea of work/life balance is "if you have time for a life, you obviously don't have enough work to do, so here's some more!" People don't leave companies, they leave managers. I left mine.

title: "associate"
pros: great challenging and place to grow
cons: hours are long but pay off if you land the right team

title: "Former full-time Operations Analyst in the SLC office"
pros: Pros: - Overall, great group of smart, motivated, diverse, kind, and talented people - Daily interaction with global markets and teams - Well thought out 365 peer review system that collects performance reviews from managers and peers below, at the same, and above your level - Great potential for growth in the company
cons: Cons: - Poor work/life balance - Starting pay considered low for how many hours you work - High stress and demanding job - Operations work can grow monotonous - Strong corporate culture

title: "Slipping and falling"
pros: Exit opportunity is there so take it.
cons: Company has been slipping for years. Consider the fact that your compensation does not mean anything when you work 12+ hour days. Your base salary is no greater than working at a 9 to 5 job at a company with equal career outlook. This place will always choose their investors first before their employees and only care about select divison of employe. They will cut cost by cutting head counts making impossible amount of work dreadfully more miserable. Tech development is not organic at all. Its just made nt bunch of real tech compan rejects who are looking for a buffer period to put Goldman Sachs on their resume and move on with unfinished or poorly developed product. Stress you get from this place is not even worth the negative health risk you become exposed to. However they do have on site physicians and psychiatrist who can help so that you can go back to the toxic work environment without having to leave the building. I never envisioned my 20s to spent missing so many birthdays and dinners. Also in regards to their marketing "campaign of great place to work" doesnt seem to be all that great at all when you have to deal with sting eyes of your managers for using your "volenteer" day or going to one of GStalk unless you are in tech. Operation and middle office space seem to take on lot more work in order to create bigger bonuses for the front office positions. Literally disgusting how we should feel thankful for less than a $10k bonus for analyst when your counterparts are drowning in bonuses multiples times greater. They take advantage of the fact that there will be next person in line to take your seat in a heart beat. This place is no different than getting a job at a factory that produce apple product.

title: "Fantastic place to start your career--if your interested aren't fixed"
pros: Amazing culture. I wanted to find a place where the people strive to motivate each other, and I found that every day at Goldman Sachs. The people there will develop you professionally and you will get meaningful responsibilities very fast. I was able to be open about how I truly felt during the internship, and everyone gave me an intelligible and beneficial response, even if it was discussing moving divisions or to another company. In addition, GS has moved to a more merit-based promotion structure, so it'll be easier for those who excel among the best to push ahead. Nobody will micromanage you.
cons: Placements seem extremely random. I emphasized my interests in my interviews, and I was placed in an unrelated role. It's the same for being hired on full-time.

title: "Good Place to Start Career"
pros: Strong people, extensive resources for learning and development
cons: Insufficient differentiation in compensation for junior level employees

title: "Used to be great, not anymore from what I hear"
pros: Many leadership and career opportunities. GS had a team-oriented culture, which I found very productive and supportive. It enabled me to grow in my field as well as a leader. Benefits were very good (ex: unlimited sick leave, long vacations, great health plans)
cons: VERY political at more senior levels. Based on what I heard from ex colleagues who are still in GS, the culture and company has changed quite a bit in last 2 years. Many VERY good people left because the company shifted policy of hiring top talent with extensive experience to hiring mostly people fresh out of university. Work-life balance was pretty poor (especially in the NYC office). 12 hour days was a norm.

The most vocal brown noses are usually going to fare well. , as they ride the coattails of biggest, most influential deals.

title: "Obsessed with Risk"
pros: Great culture, no back stabbing, everyone just wants to find the right answer. Very little politics. No deadweight, everyone is a high performer. A lot of maturity and emotional intelligence.
cons: Technology. This company is so obsessed with protecting against a bad employee doing something stupid it's smothering. Tons of legitimate web sites are blocked, the browser has so many other restrictions it barely works, you can't send an email attachment without being interrogated multiple times, all emails and IMs constantly monitored... Also, in SLC there aren't enough bathrooms. It sounds trivial but it's not. They cram too many people in a building and you have to hunt on sometimes 5 different floors for a stall. They said they new building would mitigate this but it didn't.

title: "Pick your division wisely"
pros: There are smart and driven people who inspire the same in others. It's an okay place to start out if you have little to no tech experience, but it'd be best to leave as soon as you can get another offer.
cons: My division hires people at titles beneath their experience level which is problematic if you leave the firm for any reason. Also, gender discrimination is a very real and serious issue in my division. There are very few women in leadership and if you are a woman and you’ll get very little support and sponsorship that's needed for get ahead. You’ll be excluded from events that can help build relationships vital to your career. Women who speak up are retaliated against and gossiped about. HR is slow to react to complaints. My division hails itself as being forward thinking and competitive in FinTech, but the only attributes they’ve adopted from Silicon Valley are sexism, cronyism, and dysfunction. Not a good place if you're looking to work with modern and commonly used technology for your day to day tasks. It's difficult to do your job because the internet is so restricted.

title: "Great place to work"
pros: At the core, GS is an excellent place to work. The employees are very smart and management is fully engaged. They live by the mantra that their success depends on their clients success, The information flow, from the highest level of the organization, is fabulous. The pay is very competitive.
cons: The promise/opportunity of individual success is what drives most people at GS. The proverbial gold at the end of the rainbow is to become a Partner level managing director. And in order to get there, you have to make a lot of sacrifices, both personal and professional. Employees often stab each other in the back to get ahead. There is also an annual "culling" to keep people on their toes. Many good employees lose their career this way as they get blindsided. I was laid off not because I wasn't doing a god job or working hard, but because regulatory changes were squeezing profits out of my role.

title: "IBD Analyst"
pros: Learn a lot and quickly, great brand, decent pay, culture of excellence
cons: Bonuses were terrible this year, culture of intensity and unsustainable, not much mentorship / very political

title: "Long hours and very boring work"
pros: People are nice and workplace is challenging you do real work as an intern and feel like part of the team

title: "Great Place"

title: "Solid job. Good company"

cons: The compensation is good for high performers but not for medium performers. Fewer leadership opportunities exist in salt lake office.

title: "Excellent place to start a career"
pros: You're surrounded by really high achieving people in a professional environment. You'll work hard with the opportunity to learn with some incredibly smart people. The GS name provides an unbeatable resume boost, and the firm as a whole is very well managed from the very top (from the perspective of benefits, events, etc.).
cons: All around great experience but not without some gripes (entirely preventable with better/more focused management at the group level). My group had some serious cultural issues that were largely ignored by the partners, who made no effort to invest behind the junior people. There could be a lot more emphasis on developing managerial skills among the mid-tier (associates/VPs). Some of the VPs who were retained/promoted were toxic to culture.

title: "Service Specialist"

cons: More often than not, it seems as if those who "get close" to management are the only ones who move up in the company.

cons: comes with a sacrifice of personal life. Culture and diversity is great in Goldman, breaks and personal time, not so much!

title: "Associate"

cons: Career update, new challenge, better life, good workplace and popular work environment leading to a better job experience

title: "Vampire Squid to their own people"
pros: Brand name for you to be attracted to recruiters few years down the road (Maybe). Talk at GS is awesome if you ever get to go.
cons: Even the recruiters are starting to realized that there are not that many smart ones left in this company and all false illusion. I honestly have no idea what people are talking about when they mention lots of smart people. 1. Finance is a dying industry so everyone is looking else where at all times. 2. Oversized tech talent in the firms are all real tech company rejects. Never gets anything done and nothing really to be proud of. 3. Goldman is no longer the best in the industry and lost its innovative touch for years. They are trying copy what others do and they are doing poor job at it. 4. My daily internal interaction involves dealing with at least one egotistic pretentious narcissist per day. 5. All of Ops roles are dependent on playing politics and pushes for no quantitative measurement on performance and advancement in career. 6. Operation has lowest compensation across all division and fake small bonuses you get does not depend on the business line you support. Basically could be pulling 12- 14 hour days regularly but it hold no weights comparing bonuses to people doing 9-5 function. Most managers will justify it as career opportunity but really - its just for them to suck every little life out of people.

title: "Goldman - place for rainmakers only"
