title: "You will put in time, but it's worth it"
pros: Speaking from the perspective of an IB analyst, the quality and quantity of experience and knowledge you will gain is tremendous. You will have the opportunity to work on complex and landmark transactions that have significant and long-lasting impact for the clients. Exit opportunities are excellent.
cons: Not an enviable work life balance. As an analyst or associate, working 80+ hours a week is fairly common and you will be expected to be on call and available almost all the time, including during the weekends.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Steep learning curve and exit opportunities.
cons: The hours are well beyond those of my peers at other firms in similar positions.

title: "Associate"
pros: Work with some of the smartest, most respected, driven individuals. Firm has a massive worldwide impact. Excellent infrastructure.
cons: Lifestyle is tough - constantly on call

title: "Long hours, good benefits, ok pay"
pros: Good pay. Good insurance. The office location is downtown so there are plenty of places nearby for lunch. Flexible schedule (i.e. Able to come early/leave early, etc.)
cons: You're expected to work long hours. It is difficult to get recognition. If GS is not your life it is hard to move up.

title: "Great company to start your career"
pros: Very competitive, everyone is super smart
cons: nothing much - a great place to start your career

title: "Need more creativity"
pros: Smart coworkers and people want to complete projects with highest quality
cons: Need more room to apply creativity

title: "Good Place to Work"
pros: Great people, good culture - very collaborative approach to working. People help each other towards a common goal
cons: Can be very hide hound with limited opportunities for advancement. Compensation is typically below market too - because they are GS they can afford to pay less

title: "Past job"
pros: Decent atmosphere within the company. Could be lifted a bit more
cons: I have no cons about the company.r

title: "Investment Banking Analyst"
pros: Great experience, access to senior bankers and clients early on, lots of responsibility
cons: Hard to move up in the company, too much inefficient bureaucracy, always staying late because someone else couldn't get their act together until the last minute

pros: I don't have anything negative to say in regards to my current place of employment . Great place to work.
cons: I don't have anything negative to say in regards to my current place of employment . GS has a very good culture

title: "Critical System Support"
pros: An incredibly talented group of people who remain a step ahead of the pack.
cons: The home life tends to lose to the work life. You're easily taken up in the "get it done" attitude.

title: "Lack of intellectual curiosity"
pros: Brand name is strong . Good to have on resume.
cons: Abundant arrogance. In general "goldmanites" think that there is nothing better out there , so quite often (especially in technology) they end up with quite narrow intellectual horizon

title: "A senior VP at GS Tech (Not a Senior Engineer)"
pros: Fast paced, intellect level of peers naturally challenges you
cons: Cut throat and hence does not naturally encourage collaboration

title: "Information Technology"
pros: Salaries, benefits, nice office.
cons: long working hours. Poor management

title: "Great Place to work (in general)"
pros: Good benefits. Challenging work.
cons: In the end it's a bank, so not like a pure tech company in the valley.

title: "Manager"
pros: It was a awesome company to work for great people great money and great benefit
cons: U could always be understood here they we're great folks to work for loved them to pieces

title: "Horrible Work Life Balance with no proportional pay"
pros: Culture of team work and collaboration Learning and career growth opportunities Recognized name in industry
cons: Non existent work life balance. You are expected to work like a slave. Be prepared to say goodbye to family life, exercise routines and hobbies. Pay is not proportional to no of hours you put in. I worked for many years before joining Goldman Sachs. There are many companies who will pay you same or more amount of money for working significantly less no of hours a week on better tech/fin tech projects. Work pressure and deadlines are not really driven by business/clients. Most of the times unnecessary pressure is created by management. Mid and senior managers in some teams are not respectful and have little patience to listen to developers to understand why things take time to complete. I have seen managers insulting team members by shouting and creating a scene. Firm lays off certain bottom percentage of people every year. I have seen some really smart, hard working colleagues getting fired in those cycles. So good work does not guarantee you job security. High rate of attrition = even more lack of work life balance for existing employees. Lot of technology is really old and proprietary which gives you no experience in skills that you can use outside GS.

title: "Smart People"
pros: You get to work with some of the smartest people in the industry
cons: Relatively long work hour days

title: "Technology"
pros: Smartest people you will ever meet
cons: NO over time and you put way too many hours

title: "Analyst Program, GS"
pros: Excellent brand working with amazing people. The firm truly hires the best of the best, and the calibre of the team reflects that.
cons: Long hours, inflexible lifestyle. Pretty much everyone works a 12 hour day (at minimum) regardless of which area of the firm you're in.

title: "It was pretty good"
pros: Amazing salary, surrounded by bright people.
cons: Long hours, very cutthroat culture, but this isn't exactly a secret.

title: "Software Engineer/Vice President"
pros: Exciting business. Opportunities to transfer to many places around the globe. Occasional exciting technology
cons: Too much stress. Almost everyone eats lunch at their desk. Not many Tech opportunities in my region (non-NYC)

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Excellent benefits and top notch in the industry. Working with the brightest minds from New York and London. Attending talks that bring in geniuses from across the world. A fantastic CEO who values diversity at the work place. I've met way too many inspiring individuals during my tenure at Goldman Sachs! I have to admit that it was a great first job out of school - I've learnt and grown so much from this place. I have LOTS to be thankful for.
cons: Managers in Operations Salt Lake City are mostly jokes. They are brought in from either Bangalore (where they lack EQ, people skills, common sense) or London ( cliquish, zero technical skills, London rejects). You can't find true leadership at this office. Your career will have no growth and you'll be asking yourself every day "Am I really working for the best investment bank in the world?" Operations was built out in Salt Lake City only as a cheap, escape route for the firm. GS wanted to save money and decided to pick the most boring city in the entire United States of America. Poor decision! The lucky 2% manage to move to New York and the rest of us are stuck with low caliber managers and Mormon colleagues that are sickeningly sweet but unfortunately boring. This office is a major disaster and Salt Lake City is looked down upon by rest of the firm (well Bangalore still wins for being the worst). I don't even understand how some of these people make Vice Presidents at Goldman Sachs. My advice to incoming folks: Run far from this office. There are way too many people who are unhappy and very limited opportunities for internal mobility. Also, ask yourself if you want to be a glorified factory worker processing brainless information every. single. day? That is Operations for you. It's only prestigious to work at Goldman Sachs if 1) You are working anywhere BUT Salt Lake City and Bangalore 2) You are working anywhere BUT Salt Lake City and Bangalore 3) You are working anywhere BUT Salt Lake City and Bangalore I think you got the message.

title: "I worked with a great team."
pros: Great work environment. The VPs really care about making sure that the team is properly trained and happy in their roles.
cons: During my time at Goldman Sachs I did not have any bad experiences. It was a great experience. I left to pursue another degree.

title: "Good Exposure and Smart Colleagues"
pros: Really smart people you get to work with and great exposure to various parts of the business as well as exposure globally. There are a lot of cool things happening within the company (affinity networks, events, talks) as well. People are generally open and helpful!
cons: A fair share of politics, depending on where you are, which can often pre-determine where you'll go within your specific organization; Transparency could always be better

title: "Better than Most"
pros: Smart people, accountability-driven, good learning environment if you take advantage of internal training programs and mentoring opporutnities.
cons: Lots of management transitions and organizational movement. Not necessarily a "con", but it seems that people are always vying to move on to the next best thing.

title: "Operation Analyst"
pros: Goldman's culture is really top notch, that I haven't seen anywhere else is like that. The training program is great if you join as a new analyst.
cons: I think everyone talks about the long hours if you works at Goldman. That's one major cons of working at Goldman, but then you get used to it.

title: "Technology Analyst"
pros: If you get a good team you're set. Make sure you get a good idea of EXACTLY which division you'll be in and your team's work culture. Goldman is a totally different company depending on where you get placed. The right team will land you great hours and promotion/bonuses. Most teams will not be this kind of team so be incredibly meticulous when considering an offer. An Okay place to work that will be Okay for your career and will pay just Okay.
cons: Most teams are not good teams. Some teams will work much longer hours than your normal 9-6, usually with managers who don't make an attempt to connect with their employees and wind up with unreasonable expectations. Tech is not respected nor compensated very well. Goldman has built a good brand but joining goldman tech will never make you rich. Period. Almost all the tech management comes from Strats and tech bonuses aren't even remotely close to the other divisions'. Most tech teams will not make you a good engineer. Goldman Tech is all about learning the business. If you ever try to find a job after GS nothing you learn at GS will be useful. Slang is not useful except in other banks that pay similarly poorly. You'll spend a huge amount of time in meetings discussing small details and requirements. GS tech is almost exactly how you'd imagine a bank's tech division: slow and mostly outdated. An Okay place to work that will be Okay for your career and will pay just Okay.

title: "Associate"
pros: Work Culture, End to End responsibilities
cons: Nothing substantial that I can think of

title: "Senior Analyst"
pros: -great learning experience -great networking -great exposure to investments
cons: -poor compensation and advancement within division

title: "Great for resume"

title: "VP"

title: "IBD Analyst"

title: "A so-so company now"

title: "Great place to learn"

title: "Analyst"

title: "Great Place"

In the securities division (sales and trading), management tends to be to important to spend time with junior employees, so the task is generally delegated to other junior level employees. This works for some and fails for many others that end up quitting.

title: "VP"

cons: Hyper competitive environment in which, despite the 'put the client first' and 'put the firm second' endless refrains are BS. Extremely political. No time outside of work as 24/7/365 is expected.

title: "Horrible Culture"

cons: - Focus on quick but subpar deliverables - Self marketing and networking more important than real knowledge, experience and quality - Lack of methodology and team leadership - Too many cheap, just out of school inexperienced hires. They usually leave the firm in 1 year after realizing this company sucks - No external training - Bonus used to be good until 5 years ago, now is a joke (10-15%)

cons: Hours can be long and this can sometimes mean having to walk a tight rope between personal and work life.

title: "Trying to keep up..."
pros: GS has the most talented people I have ever worked with. The key to the company is the talent it attracts. For the most part, GS has a flat management structure meaning you really do have a voice. The culture of professional growth is strong and generally the environment is collaborative.
cons: There is very little transparency at GS. I have no idea what other people in my role earn nor do I know what my boss makes. I often do not know why decisions are being made that directly effect me or my team but am asked to tow the line. In my opinion, there is an assumption that there isn't life after GS. If they tap you on the shoulder for a new role you essentially have to take it or there is a very good chance your career stalls at GS. Lastly, I work 60+ hour weeks and am told I have a good work/life balance. I know many people in other divisions that would love to only work 60 hour weeks. That is not good "work/life balance" in my humble opinion

title: "Mormon Goldman Sachs--You're in or out!"
pros: Your 5-person team experience does not necessarily reflect what GS is as a firm. if you don't like your team leave it as soon as possible before your managers turn on you and recommend you to be fired before it's too late.
cons: Managers don't help you train you. You're left to your own devices to learn your function. If you don't do a good job it's your fault! Good luck not being mormon. If you're not you're silently ostracized. so much for a firm that focuses on diversity. GS stresses people to come up with innovative ideas but they use that as an elimination device to purge employees that do not fit with the culture or quietly acquiesce to the will of their senior managers.

title: "Good place"

title: "Global Investment Research (GIR) ART Program in Salt Lake City"
pros: Working in Salt Lake City provides you with convenient access to skiing and other outdoor activities that would not be available if you were located in New York or San Francisco.
cons: The Analyst Research Training (ART) management in Salt Lake City will tell you nothing other than that you are the "exact same as someone who is hired in New York" or another core Global Investment Research (GIR) office to get you to sign the offer. After starting it will quickly become apparent that the goal of this program is to hire people into the program that are either from non-target schools or who were for one reason or another not a strong enough candidate to be considered for a position in New York and make them all compete for a few positions in New York after you have "proven" that you are capable of performing at a New York level. Your two years of experience will count as only one year of experience in New York (that means it will take you 4 years to become an Associate versus IBD where it take 2 years). You will be held to a higher standard than those that are hired into the New York analyst program as you need to "prove yourself" in order to be considered for a New York position. Management will state that the goal of the program is to pay analysts approximately 55% of what they pay them in New York since the cost of living is lower, however virtually all program participants will agree that part of the 45% discount is cost of living related and the other part is just the fact that you are considered a lower valued "front office" employee (on a cost of living adjusted basis you are just not getting paid what they do in New York). Even the argument of the discount being cost of living related is contradictory given that analysts that are hired in Houston (where the cost of living is even lower than SLC), get paid the same salary as an analyst in New York. As virtually all program participants are unhappy and regretful of the situation, you will constantly hear the Analyst Research Training (ART) program management in Salt Lake City and other levels of management say things like "you just need to trust the system", "for you to perform at a New York level, I need you to do XYZ for me", and "we are going to have someone from New York speak with program members about making the transition from Salt Lake to New York". Since it is generally accepted that the exit opportunities to the buy-side or corporate are more or less nonexistent from Salt Lake City (which from personal experience, this is more or less true), the goal of virtually all participants is to "make it" to New York. However, transferring to New York is discouraged after so many analyst have transferred to New York and immediately started recruiting for the buy-side. Since you are remote and your boss and team members don't have to see you face-to-face on a daily basis you will be treated as a second class citizen and anything you do or say will be automatically assumed incorrect or lacking merit because you were not good enough to be in New York. Doing anything to please the senior analyst and be a "team player" is expected, however this is only expected from the junior team members as management is perfectly fine with senior analysts treating junior team members like the second class citizens that they are. Senior analysts know that you have no other options, and that they can expect and demand anything from you regardless of how unreasonable it may be and the Analyst Research Training (ART) program management in Salt Lake City, will do nothing other than agree with them no matter how absurd and ridiculous it may be. There is no right and wrong, there is what a more senior person says and what a more junior person says and the senior person will always win. Probably the most challenging aspect of the program is that you are working on a daily basis with other program participants who are extremely jaded and distrusting of the firm. The vast majority of program participants will openly say to each other that they regret signing the offer because they feel they were deceived by the firm and management, and virtually everyone is doing anything and everything they can to leave the program, but most are not successful.

pros: You're surrounded by some of the brightest minds, where your manager gives you a great deal of responsibility. It is very regular at Goldman Sachs to have an analyst present to a very senior manager. Despite the shade that is sometimes

title: "Unsustainable work-life balance"
pros: Smart people Good exposure - get to work with a lot of different groups in the bank Potential for client interaction with relatively senior people Fast paced and challenging if you are on the right teams Great mentorship from experienced people if you are lucky Can learn a lot Relatively good culture compared to other bulge bracket investment banks, based on my conversations with friends After you leave most other jobs will seem relaxed
cons: Long hours (some of it unavoidable, a lot of it exacerbated by bad senior people) Many senior people are terrible at managing e.g. bad tempers, demanding, feel like they have no respect for your time A LOT of time spent on things like formatting/reformatting that will really make you feel like you're a ppt monkey Lifestyle is bad for your physical and mental health - in the end I don't think the pay is worth it

title: "Emerging markets economist at Goldman Sach"

cons: short deadlines, long hours, extensive travel

title: "Rewarding but stressful"
pros: You get to work with a lot of bright people, therefore you will be pushed to show your potential to the fullest.
cons: It is expected of you to keep progressing every year, if not, you will be "chopped"..so it is quite stressful.

title: "Good company but too many greedy highly overpaid partners."
pros: Good benefits. Some very smart folks.
cons: Long hours. The pay is good but if if take into consideration the amount of hours you put in (Typical 60-70) its not necessarily all that good. The partners love to take millions in dollars instead of distributing it the folks that truly make this company tick.

title: "Vice President, Operations Manager"
pros: They are who the advertise. They demand a lot but give you a lot of opportunity to advance your career.
cons: It takes a while for the compensation to catch up to the work you are performing.

title: "Financial Analyst"
pros: Experience and many other things
cons: Hours are very very long

title: "Long term career"
pros: People are great to work with Benefits are excellent, especially healthcare and assistance with financial planning. Challenging environment with room to grow
cons: Extended hours can be tough especially if you commute and have kids Up or out ethos can be needlessly stressful. As elsewhere, manager performance is inconsistent

title: "Excellent workplace"
pros: Smart colleagues, collegiate environment, women in top management positions
cons: no work/life balance, relentless workload

title: "Agility and collaborative environment is a work in progress"
pros: Top notch medical benefits. The teams are hard working and professional. Good place for people starting out their career.
cons: The organization is still working on understanding know how to work in a collaborative agile environment. The current management team doesn't believe in the Agile framework and make it difficult to transition to an Agile and collaborative environment. ScrumMasters have difficult constraints engaging unsupportive management, limited career options and have unfair and unclear expectations. The groups also don't have a strong ScrumMaster team structure which have resulted in ScrumMasters reporting to Dev Managers and Product owners which is not the best situation for ScrumMasters.

title: "Awesome place to work"
pros: Good mentorship, good deal flow, great learning experience
cons: Senior people are extremely detached

title: "Goldman in SLC is great"
pros: Better work/life balance in the SLC office; less stressful enviroment while still producing top notch product for the company. Goldman attracts top talent, so your co-workers work as hard as you do.
cons: Can require longer hours - expected minimum is 50 hr/week. This is not just a 9-5, but you do get compensated.

title: "Financial Analyst"
pros: Looks good on a resume.
cons: They do not care about developing their young people. The analyst program is meant to churn you out after 2 years. There is little room for growth and it is not a meritocracy. They have not figured out that they're losing talent to companies that care more about their employees.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Great people. Challenging work. strong relationships made
cons: no consistent strategy, inefficient spend, cost cutting out of line with strategy

title: "Good"

cons: During my years in GS there were ups and downs in total compensation because of the change in the investment banking market.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Great learning experience in leadership

I felt at a slight disadvantage when I first started and had to prove my intelligence coming from a large state school.

title: "Good"

title: "OK"

title: "Good short term experience/limited long term continuous growth options"

title: "Working at Goldman"
pros: A lot of opportunities for learning and developing skills needed to perform in job function.
cons: There is not much room for work-life balance.

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Great people Fast paced Pay is okat
cons: Long hours Under appreciated as a junior person

title: "Exposure to latest Technologies, but not so-great management"
pros: You could delve into some of the latest technologies and present that to your team. The team that I worked for especially encouraged best practices over known/old technologies. Work-life balance is pretty good. You get to work with smart people. You also have a lot of flexibility to move between different teams.
cons: Projects takes really long to finish, as there is no project management. Goldman has a flat structure, meaning there is no one manager. If you are in a place other than New York, that there is lesser visibility of your work, which gets accentuated by lack of management. Senior management(MD and above) is most of the times detached with projects and work accomplished within teams. Goldman also hires a lot based on your communication skills, and A-performers, which reduces overall balance of personality types in a team, where everybody wants to compete with each other and there is no team work. Emphasis on communication skills, over technical skills makes it rather difficult to get a lot of technical projects completed in an efficient manner.

title: "GS is a phenomenal place to become an expert in your field. The company demands excellence."
pros: At Goldman Sachs, everyone you work with is smart, capable and always willing to teach and help you with your work.
cons: The work is often hard and requires long hours. The commitment to excellence is challenging but worth the stress in the long run.

title: "Great culture, good people"
pros: Great culture, great people, company cares about career development
cons: Hard work, attempt to care about work/life balance not always great

title: "FA"
pros: pay, interesting, status, the quality of life, location.
cons: work hours, competition, no change, stress, same everyday

title: "Overall Positive"
pros: Great co-workers, engaging work, meritocracy that recognizes talent and effort. Opportunities to develop and grow; community outreach.
cons: Work life balance is a struggle. Management says to not work crazy hours, but at the same time has expectations to keep 20 balls in the air at the same time, that no one of the team can do without long hours.

title: "VP Investment Banking"
pros: + Unmatched upward / lateral mobility + Firm is very open to (and focused on) nurturing mentorship relationships + Great exposure to senior-level clients + Compensation is tough to beat if you are a high performer + Excellent maternity leave support and policies
cons: + Limited feedback transparency (major grade inflation makes reviews difficult to interpret) + Real competition among peers + Hierarchical structure can make it difficult to feel like a true meritocracy

title: "Exactly as you have heard"

cons: The hours can be long as there is always work to be done. It can take a toll if you do not set limits for yourself, or maintain a healthy work-life balance

cons: Limited work/life balance. No real time outside of work. It's a small miracle I still have any friends.

title: "Senior case manager"
pros: Great place to work. Keep it up.
cons: A little too much hours.

title: "Front Office Developer"
pros: 1) Work in high intensity trading floor, unforgettable experience 2) Met some great co-workers.
cons: 1) Putting out fires constantly 2) no recognition from middle and upper management 3) Pitted against one another by management 4) compensation not in line with effort 5) Long hours (12 hours a day) 6) archaic coding system (slang/secdb) 7) churn and burn

title: "Opportunity, Competition, & Long Hours"
pros: Pros include good opportunity at internal mobility, good transparency in workflows and projects, and always surrounded by people with many great traits.
cons: The environment is cut-throat with a strong CYA tone, very long hours (commute for many too).

title: "VP"
pros: Quality peers, work ethic of employees, culture of excellence. You learn a lot very quickly from intelligent and capable individuals.
cons: Long hours that do not allow for much work life balance. I don't think GS even tries to hide this anymore.

title: "It's aiight"
pros: On-site gym, Dinosaur BBQ and Momofuku on tap, big name, high salary. Clean facilities, smart ambitious people, etc.
cons: Executive slaveship with nice perks. No Christmas tree. Arrogant individuals sprinkled in the mix. Sucky work life balance. Have to cross west side highway to get to it.

title: "Operations Analyst SLC"
pros: - Decent Comp - Brand Name - Intelligent coworkers - Good benefits - Recent positive improvements to the internal mobility platform
cons: Operations work for the most part is mind numbing and repetitive. People are used as patches for the processes that haven't yet been automated. This leads to daily work that doesn't build any transferable skills. What knowledge you do manage to build is usually rooted in the technical aspect of the firms system, and will eventually become obsolete once they roll out a system update. Depending on your managers compensation and promotions can be very closely tied to office politics. It is almost impossible to stand out as a high performer through your daily work alone. Which means that a lot of analyst spend time doing useless project work on top of the daily work load just to get recognition from senior managers. I think GS can be a great place to work if you are in a different division but would recommend people avoid ops at all costs.

title: "AycoGS"
pros: Love working for Goldman, but the place is highly stressful for most of their employees. While working there, you will be treated well by your bosses and by the company. Everyone is there to help you succeed if that is your goal. Great Benefits.
cons: Stressful, high-intensity Jobs.Poor Work and Life Balance and long working hours

title: "Busy"

cons: - Arrogance and rudeness abound. Seen a lot as people get more senior. - People putting in lots of work don't get the same recognition as those that just play up to management. - Trying to change teams or leave is like a bad break up. Management does not handle it well. - Comp is below standard but justified because "the culture you get is like no where else" (quote from an MD on why the pay isn't better)

title: "Best-in-class people and processes"
pros: My job is engaging and ever-changing. I am constantly learning. The people I work with are incredibly skilled at what they do, and they are also well rounded, quality people who are a joy to worth with. Pay is good, although you'll need to start performing at the next level before getting paid at the next level. I've noticed a real push for work/life balance from the top of the firm, and I feel I have the flexibility to prioritize my family responsibilities when needed and also lean into my work when things get especially busy at the office.
cons: The regulatory burden has really increased over the past few years, as have the processes and systems in place to comply. To succeed at the firm you need to be able to deal with a large amount of red tape and also be an entrepreneurial and commercial critical thinker.

title: "Analyst Experience"

pros: Great people, great office and I personally loved the job there. If you are looking to have good excit opps, this is a great position to be in.

title: "Good place to start your career"
pros: Ability to learn, and better your skills. Very team oriented. Comp is ok.
cons: work life balance. Compensation process is very opaque.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Great place to start your career. Talent development is a top priority for the firm and most managers. Acute understanding by the firm that its strongest assets are its people.
cons: Very difficult to be successful and have work life balance. The top performers always sacrifice their personal life and that feels like the expectation.

cons: No snacks, in general fewer of the classic tech job perks. Potentially hard to get passionate about the work areas due to their financial nature.

title: "Great Job"
pros: Amazing people that I love to work with, they always seem to have a great mindset. I want these people to understand that this sort of work is very tedious but rewarding beyond belief.
cons: Long hours and the people can not help sometimes which does suck. Being the CEO i love to walk around and ensure everyone is completing their work on time and efficiently.

title: "Good place to work."

title: "Review"

title: "Analyst"

title: "Fun internship, declined full time offer"
pros: The name on your resume opens doors Fun intern activities! Salt Lake City isn't as expensive as the New York/NJ Office area
cons: Pay is incredibly low as compared to the front-end of the company (Investment Banking, etc...) Stern hierarchy where you CANNOT talk to certain people or else it is frowned upon because... well, who do you think YOU are? Their HR (aka HCM) is very unorganized No one actually talks about what they think of the firm. If you ask, usually you get, "Oh it's fantastic!" then you hear the person quit a few months later...

title: "Great Learning and solid comp"
pros: Resource-rich, people willing to assist in learning, will pay you just enough to keep you
cons: Hard to excel as a Junior employee without more senior folks

title: "Operations"
pros: Company with great prestige
cons: No one at Goldman is valued. Everyone is disposable, because everyone wants to work there. Except for certain leadership, no one is important enough to even have their own space. Because they feel like they can replace you so easily, they have demands that ridiculous. Expect to work more than 50 hours a week. While they have sone great benefits, it is not worth sacrificing your personal life for a place that doesn't value you. Expect increasing demands that can will easily take over your life. If you're not willing to do that, then they will guilt you into doing it because you're working at GS. If you have depression or anxiety or another of mental illness, expect wellness to treat your illness as an excuse to want some sort of arrangement. They will treat you like a liar, even after meeting with the therapist that is employed by GS. Last thing, if wellness does make an arrangement with you, don't expect it to last. It's like they think that those things will go away after a couple of months.

title: "Great company, but no work-life balance"

cons: - Everyone seems to be overworked and depending on the team/ manager upward and lateral mobility maybe skewed

title: "Not the best place for a technical person"
pros: Good Insurance of a big company.
cons: Long work hours but low performance because the work environment is designed for brokers, NOT developers. People tend to negatively compete because of the ranking system that leads to firing people every year.

title: "director"
pros: good pay and good support for technology needed. nice people and good benifit
cons: bad culture, bad location in downtown NYC, hard to commute

title: "Intern"
pros: The pay was a pro, as well as the netwroring opportunity.
cons: The firm is very individualized, with nobody really willing to assist with work.

title: "Great summer"
pros: -Learned things everyday -Had impactful and interesting work -Spent time with quality people
cons: -I'd be pretty tired when I got home and usually went to sleep soon after.

title: "This place is not the best place"
pros: You definitely are able to always earn a certain amount of money that is much more than that which is necessary for daily subsistence and minimal happiness.
cons: The most important of the cons, of which there are many, to me is that the work you are doing contributes very strongly to the detriment of the people around you including your compatriots

title: "Ops is menial back office work, no real transferable skills."
pros: - Looks great on your resume. Some managers try to really emulate the company's ethos in their interaction with their staff. - For a young person, fresh out of school, GS is an excellent introduction to Corporate America. Approach it with an open mind or like a social examination as your experience will be a great determiner whether working for corporations could be a thing for you.
cons: If you're unable to muster or feign the interest and importance managers feel is due to this work, note how what was once average/good feedback quickly turns unprofessional, insulting your intelligence and mental aptitude. However many times they try to tell you the work is challenging and not for everyone, know that it is not. It sort of felt like it was a way for them to legitimize and feel better about the menial, mind-numbing work it truly is. Although GS prides itself on diversity, it often seemed forced (checking off boxes). In general, I think it's good to be wary of any organization that pushes diversity initiatives and programs that hard. Surprisingly, it didn't make the workforce or managers more tolerant of others. Finally, the fact that one ethnic subset of the analyst class were assigned mandatory diversity mentors/champions is indicative of something. The culture really breeds sycophancy and since fragile egos run amok, you can only imagine how crucial your ability to engage in office politics will be for promotion and staying in the good graces of managers. Believing you'll be judged based on the merits of your work is a common mistake new joiners make. For some of my teammates, the highlight of their day (week perhaps?) was having the MD greet them and acknowledge their presence. I hope I've simultaneously dispelled any claims regarding GS being flat. It is as flat as feudalism in 9th century Europe.

title: "Entry-Level"

title: "HCM Analyst"
pros: Great learning environment and you are challenged constantly.

title: "Goldman Sachs, New Jersey office"
pros: I work in a team with excellent team spirit and culture; people help each other and cooperate, and are encouraged to learn and grow. "You own your career" is helpful as well as important to remember throughout your career. Many learning resources are available at work as well as home devices (Pluralsight, Egghead, Safari Books, ...) It's a big bank, but the NJ office (30 Hudson St) has a general "casual dress" policy, suit and tie are ok but few people wear it. Some wicked smart people work there, lots to learn from them. I was able to work from home whenever needed (family, sickness, ...), and be productive from home.
cons: Big company comes with many restricting policies by the Feds, which limits personal trading and requires more paperwork to get seemingly stuff done. More paperwork means less focus on what you think is job-relevant. The company blocks (has to block) many web sites because they might allow you to post text that it cannot retain & track, unfortunately that includes many sites that can be very useful for developers (google groups, blogs, ...).

title: "Senior Engineer"
pros: Dealing with intellectual professionals to solve complicated problems. Never a dull moment, lots of challenges to find solutions for. Innovative spirit encouraged. Good infrastructure, office facilities and services. Decent opportunity to change job roles every 18 months or so, pending favorable performance reviews.
cons: Cost cutting has deeply impacted all parts of the firm. More experienced (yes, more costly) professionals are being let go or leaving (to find better opportunities). Most teams are stretched, taking on more responsibilities than should be done by the few people, can cause points of tension and stress in a crisis situation. Younger workers are brought in, but these professional lack the experience or the ability to multitask and get things done sooner. The work demands are heavy, can bring about higher burn rate. A professional here will do the job of 2-3 people at another comparable firm. The joke that one works at GS from 9 to 5, has been interpreted as working "9 AM to 5 AM (the next day)".

title: "Great place to work"

title: "You're paid well but be ready for long hours. Also, experience highly varies from team to team."
pros: This is highly dependent on the team you land on. GS is a big place and I don't think any single pro/con list is going to fairly represent _anything_. On the team I worked on though: We were paid well, the work was engaging, and we had great clients who gave us requirements and used our products. For the US-side, absolutely fantastic people. Smart, good work-ethics, great stuff. Challenging work, good access to managers, and we had a great MD too.
cons: This is highly dependent on the team you land on. GS is a big place and I don't think any single pro/con list is going to fairly represent _anything_. On the team I worked on, the support structure was a mess. We were paid well but were called on weekends when our support rotation came up (and in the beginning years, there weren't support rotations, it was just all hands on deck when crises happened). Code upkeep and (non-existent) documentation: A complete mess. God help whatever people inherits our code. Also, there were emergency calls in the middle of the night (rare, but it happened) and our off-shore team didn't work well with our US-side team. For the record: Our US-team was only about five people though. A small team. Finally: Our technical process was a mess. People simply wrote code and committed. No process whatsoever for deployments. Inconsistent dev/qa/prod environments. No build/packaging pipeline. No easy way to revert code base. Loose-class deployments by manually breaking apart jars. You get the idea.

title: "Goldman does not care about its employees. They say they do, but they really don't."
pros: Relocation bonus, referral bonus are pretty sweet. Great network. Looks good on a resume.
cons: Pay starts shockingly low. 360 feedback system is a joke. The firm is focused only on efficiency and the bottom line; they will cut you at the drop of a hat if you're not grinding the wheels. Layoffs were pretty awful. People just disappeared-- managers didn't say anything before, your coworkers just weren't there anymore, people you cared about and got close to-- gone. Again, the firm does not care. They do not care about you, there is no loyalty to you. The hours are long and thankless in ops. 10 hours minimum every day. Never had less than a ten hour day. Work life balance is virtually nonexistent. You exist to make money for the firm; they do not care about you. Management spends a lot of time trying to talk up how great it is to work in ops, but everyone's trying to get out. Ops is where careers go to die; it is the red headed stepchild of the firm. You know how everyone associates Goldman with Wolf of Wall Street types? Well in Ops, you're the one on the other end of the phone when said wolf picks up the phone to scream about a failing trade. It's purely extractive and exploitative. Do not listen to anyone who's trying to tell you that you'll have a long and satisfying career in ops. You'll be strategizing the entire time about getting away to another division, and getting to a prestige office. In ops, you'll never get the choice of anything. New office building? Nope. New facilities? Nope. Healthier food? No. Central location? No, we're going to put you in the far office. Everything in ops feels punitive.

title: "Worst work/culture environment in existence!"
pros: The company name looks good on your resume. Met some good people there and I can't imagine why they continue on in such an environment. The must be masochistic.
cons: Too many to list-honestly! The CS/CRS division is nothing more than a sweat shop managed by inept senior management whose primary concern is to save money at the expense of providing a good service for the company. If you get an offer to work in CS/CRS as a "contingent" worker, run as quickly as you can in the other direction! The worst culture/work environment I have ever experienced.

title: "operations analyst"
pros: A good company to work for if you are fresh out of college.
cons: long hours and the work can be boring.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Great preparation for all future jobs/career
cons: Too intense atmosphere, with limited to no consideration for people's personal lives

title: "GS Software Engineering"
pros: Very smart and competent people here
cons: Minimal personal conversations with coworkers/managers during the day

title: "Software Engineer"
pros: -High Compensation -Abilities to get training experience
cons: -Long hours -Projects can become very political

title: "Stay Away if you are an experience individual"
pros: Great culture for new analysts, work from home flexibility, Onsite gym and medical care
cons: Nowadays the company focuses more on new analysts and ignores experienced people. No lateral and upward mobility, no raises and toxic environment with politics

title: "Goldman Sachs Asset Management"
pros: Smart people who want to do a good job.
cons: The hours were too long, and the pay isn't what it used to be.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Compensation, Deal Flow, Culture, Training Program
cons: Work/life balance, Exposure, Opportunity to move up

title: "Team manager and line work"
pros: The people are smart, driven and flexible. People will rally around an issue and all will help to find the best solution. If raised your managers will work with you if you have any issues outside of work.
cons: Unrealistic expectations cause burnout. Many people can become overwhelmed by the amount of tasks you are given to do. In as competitive of an environment that Goldman Sachs is just being great at what you are asked to do puts you on the same level as everyone else. You really need to push hard to be noticed and the rewards downy always seem to match the effort.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Challenge environment and could learn tons of new things in fast paced environment
cons: intense working environment & work life balance

title: "Finance and Planning"
pros: Intellectually challenging, fast paced, dynamic, distinguished colleagues, collaborative environment, competitive. Brings out the best in oneself. Continuous personal and professional growth
cons: Not many cons to share. The hours can be long sometimes, but that goes without saying for every job if you want to deliver a top class product.

title: "Great firm"
pros: Very bright people and highly educated
cons: Lots of office politics and hurdles.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Smart, driven, professionable people. Interesting work. Opportunities to move around - division and location b
cons: Lots of politics and favoritism. Not the place for anyone 40+ years. Long hours. Lip service paid to work/life balance.

title: "Acquisition Analyst"
pros: Learned a good amount, provided good exit opportunities so I could leave ASAP
cons: Managers are stifling, 90% of coworkers are pretty vapid, with no life outside of their work

title: "trading"
pros: good pay smart people successful business good benefits and perks for museums hotels 401 k health care and great network
cons: long hours people need to put in face time to get ahead or a promotion expect to come in early and work late

title: "Operations analyst"
pros: Great name for resume
cons: Horrible culture, they hire anyone.

title: "Associate"
pros: Very collaborative and inclusive environment. People take the time to train and teach you new concepts. Very culture driven, which forces you to elevate your skill set and knowledge to the next level
cons: Work life balance is not ideal, but again its Goldman Sachs. The firm has been cost cutting over the past few years, translating to less than stellar compensation.

title: "Overall: a great firm"
pros: Great culture As close as it gets to meritocracy Pay can ramp up quickly More its size, very efficient with little bs
cons: Equities culture toxic, people constant making inferior decisions for political gains IT is political and not as closely aligned to meritocracy, and not often aligned to revenue. Specifically, more risk than reward for IT people

title: "Associate"
pros: Great training. Really smart people. Fast paced.
cons: People manager was horrible! Hard to move up the ladder.

title: "Smart people"
pros: Very smart people Intellectually very stimulating

title: "VP"
pros: There are very smart people around. Team work are valued.
cons: Like many big corporate, politics can be significant.

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Competitive benefits, business trip opportunities
cons: the atmosphere has been changing a lot, they hire more consultants

title: "Investment Management Division"
pros: Amazing people and good culture compared to rest of wall street.
cons: Large company. Finance is not what it used to be.

title: "Hello"
pros: Good culture great people easy
cons: Stressful demanding long short mean

title: "Executive Assitant"
pros: Good place to work nice culture activities
cons: Investment banking nothing to say about

title: "Financial Analyst"
pros: High Bonusses on good years, and good 401k.
cons: Extremely long hours, and above average stress for this position.

title: "Great Internship in Operations Division"
pros: Lots of Responsibility Little Finance background needed (the teach you on site)
cons: Lots of work hours pressure to get next big promotion

title: "great"
pros: great to work with inspirational professionals
cons: hate the llong hours can be drainging

title: "Awesome"
pros: Growth and challenges. If you want to forge your skills in the fire this is the place for you.
cons: None. Work hard and thingsee work out well.

title: "Managing director"
pros: Well run organization with very high standards.
cons: Like many big organizations, GS is forced to be politically correct, often to the detriment of clients.

title: "Clerk"
pros: It has a great program.
cons: There is a problem about the management.

title: "VP"
pros: Each day is a challenge, work with smart people
cons: Not a great work-life balance.

title: "Senior Developer"
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Developers are literally second class citizens

title: "Summer operations analyst"
pros: The people were nice & it seemed like my managers were genuinely concerned about my experience.
cons: not very challenging/engaging work. If going into operations, know that everyone sells you on how great the company is. Personally, I felt that was the only thing I gained was getting a "brand name" on my resume. All actual serious investment jobs I subsequently interviewed for were quick to dismiss my experience as relevant.

pros: very challenging enviornment and ample opportunities to grow
cons: No personal life . Work work and more work

title: "Associate"
pros: Top notch compensation & benefits Everyone is smart and driven
cons: limited work life balance limited mobility within the firm

title: "Working at GS"
pros: Great culture. Brilliant people. Interesting work. Good pay and benefits. They take care of their employees and value human capital above all else.
cons: Hours can be long, but that naturally comes with working at a place like Goldman Sachs. You are well compensated for your time though.

title: "Summer Intern"
pros: Pros Surrounded by extremely high-quality talent, which is a great environment for personal development. Talent development processes are robust and rigorously tracked. Career progress is well understood. Internal mobility program affords great exposure across products and geographies.
cons: Cons Long hours and difficult work/life balance are definite features of a career in GS's "front office."

title: "GS is a great place to work"
pros: Great work environment with really talented people. Lots of interesting projects and issues arise daily at a fast pace that keeps the work interesting.
cons: The hours can be very long and the pay structure can be political and vary greatly from position to position. the environment can be high stress for individuals who are not accustomed to working in such environments.

title: "Operations VP"
pros: I love the fact that GS drives people to stretch in ways they never knew was possible. I never thought i would continue working for a large employer after college, as I wanted to pursue my own thing; however I've learned more here than I ever could have imagined 10 years ago.
cons: Things have changed in the industry. Forces on the industry have made management minimize expertise and commoditize the value the experience and knowledge folks in the division have. There is an increase of squeezing this division to cut costs, despite increasing regulation and the need to facilitate new business to keep up with decreasing ROI and shrinking margins.

title: "Good learning experience but opaque process"
pros: opportunity to learn and network
cons: opaque process and incompetent HR

title: "Internal Audit"
pros: There are many honest, good, intelligent professionals working at Goldman Sachs and you will have an opportunity to work with many of them.
cons: A highly political organization where your professional success is determined primarily based on which senior manager you work for than the quality of work. Management expects every auditor to work 11 - 13 hours per day and each auditor to work on 2 - 3 audits at the same time. A culture that encourages gossip and pointing out the mistakes of your peers rather than a supportive, team environment. New college grads, sourced through the summer intern program, are used to replace leavers due to a consistently high turnover rate in the double digits annually. A very observant summer intern recently commented to me during a one-on-one that "it appears most people don't want to be here". She was spot on.

title: "Excellent Place to Work"
pros: Worked with talented, driven individuals. Competitive Salary Prestige of working at one of the top financial firms on the Street Goldman Sachs benefits package, especially with regards to museums around town.
cons: As an Administrator, I was encouraged to not put in overtime, even though my job might require me to work more hours to complete a particular specialized task.

title: "Probably not the place to be if you're a techie. Network is top notch"
pros: Excellent place to network. Open floor seating, although offices for higher uppers still exist. Super flexible work from home policies (at least for the tech division). ~18 days vacation plus US holidays to start off. For tech, highly underpaid, at least for people just starting off in their careers. Fun training program for new tech hires out of college.
cons: SLOW. Of course, highly dependent on the team. Technology can be antiquated (lots of legacy systems). Can be a real pain to get your hands on new tools. Many times you need permission to download new tools. Super bureaucratic. Promotions seem to be based more on "connections."

title: "GS"
pros: Great compensation Good benefit package Resume builder
cons: Long, stressful hours Very political if you want to advance

title: "Challenging environment"
pros: The challenges of the environment, the network that you build and maintain throughout your career, the work ethic you develop through the rigorous program
cons: The egos can get tiresome and old, the personalities can be forced at times and disingenuous. Hours can be long and unforgiving

title: "Software Engineer"
pros: Competitive environment, very intelligent co-workers and culture of excellence. The in-house software platform was very interesting to work with.
cons: Working for the vampire squid. Industry that is only concerned with money. Hours can be challenging to manage.

title: "IBD"
pros: Amazing people to work with. Best peers on the street. Exceptional training programs and internal resources.
cons: Long hours, but interesting work.

title: "Vice Pesident"
pros: Very much team orientated and structured work place.
cons: Too much politics in the company.

title: "Great benefits, but beware of what job you take"
pros: Great benefits, great location, competitive pay and mostly great and very talented people.
cons: The company is very siloed. If you get hired into one division and want to transfer to another division, you will have a hard time doing so. This is especially true for administrative positions. Do NOT be fooled into thinking that taking an administrative job at this firm would be a great way to get your foot in the door. Administrative assistants are largely overlooked. Internal training, mentoring, etc are all focused on associates, analysts, and VPs. The job is a complete and utter deadend. A lot of people are completely dismissive of administrative assistants and won't even bother reading your resume to see what you did prior to that job. If you are qualified for other positions and have career ambitions and are hungry for advancement, do NOT get talked into taking an administrative role. It will be a huge setback for you and a shocking number of people will be completely dismissive of you. You might as well be background furniture.

title: "Operations Vice President"
pros: Large company, fast moving and challenging environment. Working with many extremely talented and intelligent individuals from very diverse backgrounds.
cons: Stressful and very political environment. A lot of getting ahead is dependent on relationships and not abilities.

title: "Amazing family orientated company with great ethos"
pros: Some of the nicest most caring people you will ever meet. Goldman gets a bad rap in the press but I lost count of the number of times I witnessed employees put people over profit. This is a company that really cares about giving back. We recently packaged up a some sub-primes from the Malaysian markets, sold them to a commercial bank in Indiana, and then used the money from the sale to make more loans to people who needed houses. Sometimes I feel so proud when I arrive home because I have helped people realize their dreams of home ownership. Securitization is the pennicillin of the 21st century.
cons: We have to work with some real meanies in other investment banks; people that only care about making money and buying fancy clothes. The good thing is they make me realize that we are the good guys

title: "Vice President"
pros: Challenging environment, Smart People, Compensation
cons: Long hours, Impersonal people development

title: "Not as much opportunity for advancement"
pros: Great pay, competitive environment, learn a lot
cons: Management can be tough, must be part of the "bro culture", not much opportunity to get promoted out of junior analyst role.

title: "Associate"
pros: Pay is ok, overall if you don't mind lots of hours.
cons: Work life balance is not very good.

title: "Spring Internship"
pros: It's a very comfortable and helpful environment to work. Everyone there was ready to help, though it was just an internship. They try as much to ensure you get as much as you can in such short time
cons: It was very rigorous, you have to be hardworking to cope. But of course you'd expect that from a top global investment bank.

title: "Associate"
pros: No promotion avenues. Senior Management are only worried about bottom line, no career counseling and subordinates usually are not well managed and non disciplined and no concern about other people careers.
cons: Extremely good training ground for all disciplines and good networking place to enhance your career.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Mobility opportunities, global focus, strong senior management
cons: always runs extremely lean, compensation challenging

title: "Investment Analyst"
pros: Amazing place to work. I loved it!
cons: I cannot think of any.

title: "Good experience for recent grads, even though the role might not be a good fit"
pros: The experience and training you get as a new hire here is unparalleled. Strong commitment to continual skills development. Great access to industry-leading professionals. Also the GS name on the resume never hurts.
cons: There's very little flexibility once you've joined the firm. Hard to switch or move around if you feel that your role and/or location isn't a good fit for you. Might not be an experience exclusive to GS but many other banks will make an effort to switch analysts between roles if it doesn't appear to be a good fit.

title: "Ok to start"
pros: the gym and the benefits are pros
cons: old school mentality and awful work life balance

title: "Secular pressure and everyone (smart) knows it"
pros: Opportunity to work with extremely smart and motivated people. Lots of resources and easy to make connections across the industry.
cons: There's still an old school mentality within the company that needs to reverse course if they want to retain top talent. The secular pressure on the business has lowered compensation pretty much across the board and instead of adjusting hours down and work/life balance up the company has moved the opposite direction. Paid less, work less. People generally take themselves way to seriously.

title: "Great experience"
pros: Wonderful co-workers, great opportunities, pleasant environment.
cons: There were really no cons.

title: "Good learning experience but not a place to build a career (S&T)"
pros: Work with smart people in a fast paced environment. You learn how to work hard, work smart, and deal with demanding clients. The analyst class training experience and summer internship provides a great network for future endeavors.
cons: Many managers are not focused on talent development and retention. The industry is getting smaller and the firm will continue to cut back. New regulatory strictures will continue to chisel away margins and profits.

title: "Vice President"
pros: You will have as colleagues very smart, ultra-driven people; the sharpest in the industry. Challenging but rewarding assignments. Lots of pride in company and work. Opportunity to learn and grow.
cons: The occasional unfiltered unmodulated and unjustified mean guy (who is so comically cliche-like who seems almost like coming from casting central); but I guess it comes with the territory. Otherwise people are sharp smart hard working and truly team players. The industry also seems to be undergoing deep fundamental transitions.

title: "Summer Analyst - Operations"
pros: You work for the most prestigious investment bank in the world. You are encouraged to network and given the opportunity to learn about all areas of the firm. If you perform well, there is a good chance you'll receive an offer to come back after graduation.
cons: The work and workload differs highly from team to team within operations, so there's a chance you will not be doing meaningful work. Salt Lake city isn't a good fit for everyone.

title: "Business Manager / Imports consultant @ Trintaglo CC"
pros: Atmosphere / Culture ambient and relaxed. Strong focus on developing YOU! Assisting with development in retail, wholesaling and Imports distribution spaces
cons: Small entity No view to expand.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Great salary, benefits, and career opportunities.
cons: Work life balance is difficult there.

title: "GS"
pros: Compensation, colleagues, facilities, meetings, travel
cons: Competition, hours, flexibility, career progression, regional compensation

title: "Former employee"
pros: Great place to learn and get a start in the industry. Very smart colleagues. Great reputation that helps with future employment opportunities.
cons: Tough and competitive environment. Very long hours. Some internal obligations and bureaucracy felt unnecessary.

title: "Senior Engineer"
pros: highly talented set of people focus on best, high quality product, very cautious abt reg
cons: too much politics at the higher levels, no meritocracy at the top trending do more and more and more with less and less and less resources, drain on morale and has started to impact quality

title: "Underwhelped"
pros: Nice people, brand name, new office being built
cons: Salt Lake City, less qualified people than I expected

title: "Gs out of college"
pros: Good place to start, performance gets appreciated. Depending on your team you will love your work or do something that should be automated.
cons: It can be very dull work, wait 18 months to transfer to another team or jump ship.

title: "advisor"
pros: Goldman is an extremely well known co.
cons: hard to live up to

title: "Pros and Cons working for GS"
pros: In general it is a good company to work for; you're compensated fairly, great mobility programs (you can move to different teams after certain period of time at current position), great benefit packages (health and dental insurance, 401k matches, floating holidays and sick leaves, on-site gym (you don't need to bring anything as the gym provides all you need), excellent online training, and, of course, discretional bonus.
cons: A lot of required trainings from time to time, and there are resitrictions on investment due to the nature of the jobs in financial sectors. The work can be intense there, depending on what you do. If you want to excel, you'd need to be more creative. It's not enough to just finish your projects.

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: - Great culture, people are nice and smart and helpful. - Exposure to some significant things and supporting something huge. - Opportunities to relocate or move within the firm. - A well-oiled machine in every sense.
cons: - Manual processing isn't for someone with a college degree. Most people working there are overqualified. Those who improve their processes are a step ahead, but they have to work longer hours to do that or have existing technical knowledge. - 50 hours a week is sort of the minimum. - The salary.

title: "Vp"
pros: Very talented people around . Lot of learning opportunities
cons: Too much burrecracy and process . Need to remove the layers

title: "Tech Analyst"
pros: Pretty relaxing environment and good summer program
cons: Nothing much to work in a business environment

title: "Associate"
pros: A place where you should be able to find knowledge and intellectual challenges
cons: There is no loyalty among peers and management is just selfishly worry about getting their bonus and nothing else. You will be on your own and expected to only have time for work. Not a family oriented company.

title: "Good"
pros: Interesting work. I can get good domain knowledge and lots of technologies to explore. Lots of passionate and inspiring people to work with.
cons: Too much work, there is no exact work hours. Work life balance is totally up to us and we need to manage it.

title: "VP"
pros: People, brand recognition, some flexibility, opportunity to learn
cons: High stress, stagnant compensation, poor management

title: "First impressions"
pros: Surrounded by capable people Strong teamwork oriented environment Leaders in the hierarchy are friendly and easy to approach
cons: Very long, if not abysmal working hours

title: "Its all Politics"
pros: In Operations SLC, not much. You might have a better experience in a different Division.
cons: Good luck advancing unless you are the brown nosing type as advancements are super political. Promotions are based upon who you know, not based upon hard work and meritocracy. Do not move to GS as an analyst or associate in Operations as you be a puppet punching numbers 60 hrs/wk while the senior people (VP and above) make money. Even if you do go over at the VP level, you will be a slave to the man and have to rub shoulders, be buddy buddy, and spend more time with internal networking than actual working in order to advance. Unless this is your personality type, DO NOT move to GS.

title: "Vice President"
pros: surrounded by smart and motivated people, many who have gone on to do bigger and better things.
cons: relative ratings system creates internal competition amongst peers.

title: "GS review"
pros: Brand. Good number of smart and energetic people.
cons: Bureaucracy due to big size, difficult to grow. If you have sweat one ounce to deliver something then sweat 3 times to sell it otherwise your delivery will be pretty much forgotten.

title: "Excellent place to work"
pros: Very motivated people; great employee care at the company. Terrific for people with children- with a day care on site.
cons: Financial sector has been in a secularly difficult environment and Goldman is in that group. There is lots of pressure on revenues- so career upside can be frustrating.

title: "Associate"
pros: Very good experience for resume. Great exposure to industry. Compliance, background checks, and interviews assure that they only hire the best.
cons: There was no training system in my department, so it was like being thrown into the fire with an extreme learning curve (combined with culture shock if you have moved from another state or country). Extremely competitive, so even if you are awesome at what you do, it could go unnoticed. Long hours and poor work/life balance. Very hard to have a family and ever see them.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Good exposure to the financial industry. They hire good people and the culture is very vibrant and social. Learn a lot of great skills early in your career, a great stepping stone for a future job if desired.
cons: The environment is extremely stressful. They are always expecting you to do more to a point where you can never satisfy. Even if you accomplish something incredible it will quickly be forgotten about in a few months. Too much competition where the environment has turned toxic and manipulative. Getting ahead is more about playing the political game than what you actually do and how you are performing. Because they hire such high quality people, a lot of good solid employees get unnoticed. This company does not care about their employees, they are all numbers on a paper and they show no signs of loyalty. Keeping their people happy is very low on their priority list and it is very evident after you've been there a few years. When company is not doing as well as they expect comp budget is the first to go. You can go very far and make a lot of money here but it is extremely difficult and you have to sacrifice your health and your life. Goldman is not just a job, it becomes your life.

title: "Culture"
pros: People work hard and in general will help if you have the right questions.
cons: No guidance, no time with your managers, no directions. Placed an intern in a position with no team.

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Smart People Fast past Professionalism Hard-working staff Market Place and Reputation
cons: No serious cons if you like the pros

title: "Not Bad"
pros: Fast paced environment Global company Great learning opportunities Team Environment
cons: Long hours Repetitive work Non-diverse workforce Rigid, outdated promotion structure

title: "Great place to work overall"
pros: - Very smart people: generally, the best of the best - Opportunity is virtually unlimited: exceptional talent gets exceptionally rewarded - The rewards at the partner level are still very big
cons: - Its easy to fall short here even if you are very smart, overachiever, etc. - On "average", you have to work harder here than at other banks - Very political ... probably the same as any other bank

title: "Vice President"
pros: Energetic working environment and things move fast.
cons: often don't have time to dive deep into the problem.

title: "Technology Analyst"
pros: The brand name is great; the facilities are world class; you get to work with some pretty smart people.
cons: You are far underpaid, because the management thinks the brand name alone will keep you around.

title: "Vice President Sales"
pros: - Competitive Environment - Meritocracy - Relatively flat structure
cons: - Cut throat environment - They will cut non performers in a heart beat

title: "Long-time employee"
pros: Opportunities to work with very bright and dedicated people.
cons: Many uncertainties considering current market and loss of revenue.

title: "a compnay in decline"
pros: everyone very collaborative given the mantra that Goldman instills in the employees.
cons: Folks are hung up on "the prestige" of Goldman on your CV. Don't expect to have work life balance at all. 12 hours every day is the norm and forget about "free time" on the weekends". The reward for all this is that come bonus time we will pay the analysts a few shekels. They laid off nearly 10% of the workforce since Jan because of greed during the financial crisis and now they are paying for it.

title: "Technology Dept"
pros: Good Comp during good market conditions. Technologies being used these days in the firm is getting better
cons: Not a great copmany for beginners. Technology is not considered as an important department. Dont join unless u have no other options

title: "Ops Associate"
pros: surrounded by talent, prestigious brand
cons: lack of transparency from senior management feedback wise.

title: "Risk"
pros: Challenging work place and always changing
cons: Work life could be better

title: "Business Asssociate"
pros: Great culture! Amazing people and good pay! Smart people here. Location for office is good too with food and everything.
cons: Hours are bad! Expensive location in the surrounding area.

title: "GS: Is the squid in failing health?"
pros: GS still looks good on your resume.
cons: A shadow of its former self in terms of the quality of its people & culture.

title: "Prestige..."
pros: you know, prestige. the biggest factor that attract people
cons: too large which means lots of glass celling

title: "Good First Job - Great people to work with"
pros: Decent pay and a great first job.
cons: Long hours, no time for a lunch break, daily deliverables can get old.

title: "Review"
pros: Compensation, people, learning, exposure, coverage, reputation
cons: No work life balance if you want to be successful

title: "Vice President"
pros: Great team environment. People genuinely care about each other. Excellent benefits, training opportunities, interesting work, and beautiful office amenities provide a highly engaging place to work.
cons: Long hours. Global jobs require extraordinary effort across multiple times zones for success and make work life flexibility challenging.

title: "Good experience"
pros: Good salary, competitive and smart coworkers
cons: Long hours, mundane tasks, hierarchical structure

title: "Technology Analyst"
pros: Been working here over a year now. * Work with great, smart people who are dedicated to their jobs. * Hours not as bad as one would imagine. You will have the occasional late night dealing with problems in production, or ensuring a deadline for development is met. * Benefits are absolutely phenomenal (firm pays life insurance, short term disability, has good/great 401k options, provides health, vision, and dental and customizations to plans to fit your specific situation / budgeting, and much much more). * Compensation is great but not the top -- this probably has to do with a trade off for getting those magical words "Goldman Sachs" on your resume -- there is a large supply for relatively few positions, so they can afford to pay less than some competitors at the lower levels. * As it turns out the vaunted meritocracy of GS does indeed exist, and the top performers are regularly singled out and given plaudits and earmarked for promotion and better bonuses. * There's always something interesting going on, whether it's training sessions by industry leaders (like an engineer lead from Google talking about Angular 2), networking events, or talks@GS from famous people (Shaq, Laura Bush, Game of Thrones show runners, etc)
cons: * In the tech division, at least, there is an ongoing problem where the firm's standards for software keep on changing, resulting in a "hitting a moving target" problem -- by the time you finish upgrading to 2016's software specs, 2017 is here and you have a whole new spec to meet. * Some of the software specs are great and absolutely worth onboarding to, but some others are head scratchers that provide zero utility and only impede the regular course of software development (looking at you, forms engine). * While GS is definitely pivoting more and more into technology, resources (and by that I mean people) are still tight. Either the scale of changes should be reined in or more resources should be hired.

title: "Great Place to work"
pros: Awesome place to work! Great culture
cons: -Long Hours and stress, Politics

title: "It was a good run."
pros: A good learning environment with the opportunity to move up.
cons: The location makes it less desirable. Long commute no matter where you live.

title: "Internal Audit department; one of the best on the Street"
pros: - Limitless exposure and ability to experience multiple groups within the department - working with smartest people you can find in an audit shop - great benefits; medical, vacation
cons: - Long hours, not laidback like other audit shops - Demanding - inability to climb up the ladder before set timelines

title: "Business Analyst/Project Manager"
pros: Work-Life Balance, top technologies used
cons: Less compensation and unfair bonus structures

title: "Technology Ananlyst"
pros: -Good exposure to business -Capable colleagues
cons: -Does not pay as well as other tech companies -It is a bank, technology is not the number 1 priority

title: "Need to focus on lateral hire experience more"
pros: - Good perks like networking events, on-site health center, gym etc. - new hire acclimation for those coming in as campus hires is pretty good
cons: - need greater focus on implementing steps to improve lateral hire experience. There is definitely room for improvement with that group

title: "Treats employees like trash"
pros: Great benefits and name recognition
cons: Treat you like a number and not a person. Treat people unfairly and unequal. Don't practice what they preach.

title: "Operation"
pros: Work life balance. Good culture. You can grow in the company,
cons: Long hours. Training takes a long time.

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Fast Paced Smart Coworkers Great benefits including health, matching program, on-site gym facility Competitive compensation
cons: Long hours and difficult to manage work life flexibility Toxic and very competitive environment Structured career paths and scheduled promotions which decreases meritocracy and incentives to give the extra effort

title: "Work horse"
pros: Recognize tip performs, performance direct relation to pay, quick paced, provided with many opportunities
cons: Company runs "lean" meaning you will do 3 peoples average job and always be understaffed. No focus on retention of employees.

title: "VP"
pros: travel, people, career progression,competition, smart people,
cons: Long hours, politics, management bias, no work life balance, brown nosing, pay

title: "VP and assistant general counsel"
pros: Reputation, quality of work and co-workers; the organization takes its business principles seriously; and, despite what you read in the press, the client's interest are of paramount importance.
cons: Work life balance; more concern for the ROI of GS stock than employees; opportunities for career advancement are fairly limited.

title: "Good place to work"
pros: The people are great to work with.
cons: The culture can be overwhelming.

title: "Expect big politics with big company"
pros: Pay, benefits, team members, technology
cons: Politics, expected work hours,

title: "analyst"
pros: strong team to work with good compensation
cons: long working hours and high pressure frequent travel

title: "Associate"
pros: Great people, good pay, and the best culture on the street.
cons: Work life balance does not exist. Culture not very friendly for lateral hires.

title: "Tech Infra"
pros: Best of breed financial services firm, good benefits , medical, and 401K plan. Nice facilities, very professional atmosphere. Very diverse and inclusive.
cons: not like it used to be . deep cost cutting has reduced comp and staffing resources

title: "Managers get most"
pros: a lot of smart people there
cons: not a friendly environment to work with

title: "Investment Banking Summer Analyst"
