pros: Name brand is unmatched in finance and will take you far in any industry. Instantly impressed FT interviewers at many top boutiques. Great culture - everyone is open to doing catch ups. Awesome building with great perks.
cons: Very anti-recruiting. Absolutely won't let you recruit until after your first year. HCM tries very hard to keep you where you are - internal mobility to a different group or division is pretty much non-existent. Some groups are too big. Underpays the street at the analyst level.

title: "Best Experience for entry level employees"
pros: diversity and inclusion, internal tools and vendor training, networking opportunities, access to senior management sessions and town halls, affinity networks, community service
cons: better assessment of individuals for faster growth based on merit rather than number of years of experience and education levels, better pay

title: "Good Compensation, Poor Culture"
pros: The money compensation can't be beat. Salary continues to go up for good performers, even in bad years.
cons: The technology culture isn't for everyone. There's a lot of talk and hype about how great it is, but in the end, it's glorified contractors. Once you make too much money, you'll be out just like anyone else, regardless of your performance. Poor work life balance. Everyone I interact with are workaholics.

title: "High friction, bureaucratic company"
pros: The bottom line is that Goldman Sachs is not for someone who is passionate about software development. There are a few departments (enterprise platform for example) that are more focused on advancing the technologies in the firm, but most software engineer positions are tightly coupled with business teams and they dictate what you do and what you work on. The pros are: - Goldman is definitely one of the better financial firms in terms of experimenting with a wide-variety of technology stacks. In my short year there, I was able to experiment with HBase, Mongo, Vert.x, Angular JS - Many opportunities to learn. A lot of talks with many interesting people (one of the talks was with David Benioff from Game of Thrones). Classes for different technologies offered year round - Great people, friendly
cons: - bureaucracy, had to constantly fight with business to do things that would benefit them in the long run - extremely out-dated code base, so you would be spending most of your time fixing other people's code instead of working on cool new projects - Slang (enough said) - Bad management - most senior level managers are too complacent or have given up

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Training, leadership, opportunity set with hard work (across business lines and geographies)
cons: Large company requires drive and heavy networking to get to the next level.

title: "Great experience!"
pros: Network; opportunities; skills attained; Paid internship.
cons: Long hours but worth it!

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Amazing learning experience for freshers with outstanding processes and policies laid down.
cons: Work life balance is not that great!

title: "Tech Analyst"
pros: Good place to begin your career with. A lot of it depends on the team you're working with
cons: 401k not matched until 1 year of employment. 9 days sick leave

title: "Vice President - Operations"
pros: Committed to change/striving for improvement Work with very smart people Solutions oriented approach to solving problems
cons: Limited growth opportunities in Operations in hub locations Costs driving every decision in current environment

title: "Gs analyst"
pros: Great place to work and launch career
cons: Too many meetings each week

title: "Great place to have worked"
pros: Smart people - focused, interesting, Always changing - good opportunities, will find out some way to come out on top Very well run - Makes smart choices on strategy and excellence in execution
cons: Demanding work environment Can be overly competitive internally Needs to perform better on diversity

title: "Great experience, but know what you're signing up for"
pros: They will push you to be your best. You will be surrounded by Type A personalities that will become your best friends. Opportunities abound. Awesome professional development. Overall company culture is among the best I've worked with.
cons: Long hours, can be a "boys club" in certain groups

title: "Good, but getting worse."
pros: Quick advancement for career. Meritocracy.
cons: Worries too much about regulation now. Not as focused on core businesses. Pay isn't what it used to be. Terrible work/life balance.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Great working culture, awesome people, employee friendly, allows flexibility, very professional and overall great place to start and grow once career
cons: Cant think of a lot but, its a good place to work. At times does feel like filled with typical alpha personalities but again, typically filled with achievers and hence this is expected

title: "The Original Fintech Startup Powerhouse still delivers"
pros: - Best interview process of my life in a context where experience trumped nonsense tech screens. Sessions involved strategic and domain specific discussions with VP and MD technology leaders and one or two on-the-fly high level technical questions. Mostly, it felt like a flattering sales pitch. One of the only times in all my years working that I've left an interview actually feeling good about myself. - Premium offer over my then base salary, including discussion of expected year end cash awards. All arrived exactly as conveyed resulting in highest comp received in my 10 professional career - Moving towards a "startup-lite" culture with business casual attire, working remotely, flexible work hours, social/networking events - My resume was already decent but adding GS to it brought a torrent of invitations to interview, networking requests and other professional and personal benefits that come with being associated with the top global investment bank. - Management structure is flat, with no single person making decisions in solitude, including your direct manager. A strong network greatly affects project outcomes - Policy allowing mobility at any time is a big benefit for productive and effective employees as it shifts bargaining power in their favor by forcing managers to keep the situation equitable or find someone else. - Lots of very brilliant people have worked and/or still remain there from a fairly diverse set of backgrounds. Literal rocket scientists and multi-PhD superstars all over the place - even as consultants.
cons: - Strange culture where people often act like doing their job is a favor. Tricky communicating effectively with intelligent but often thin skinned and/or insecure personality types holding long term senior positions - Work often comes informally as high level projects along the lines of "rethink and simplify the current expensive but proven solution with delivery of an entirely novel, unproven, theoretically more efficient paradigm" - and then judged somewhat qualitatively on minor points and preferences, shaped by popular opinion. Politics here are as weird as they are dicey as they are crucial to getting ahead or staying afloat. - Compensation per employee is nothing like the press/media math of "X profit / Y employees". It's higher than average in general but there's many who are paid less than their value along with many medium term consultants with no skin in the game. On the positive side, there's almost no one who adds little to no value and sticks around for more than 3-6 months like all other banks - Management structure may be flat but largely because of its opaque, convoluted and constantly shifting nature. This can make it feel like a full political campaign cycle just to screw in a light bulb. - As crazy as it sounds, if you reach a senior level, it becomes difficult to pursue opportunities outside GS as the universe of companies that can and will provide both a better career trajectory and higher compensation shrinks dramatically. Those that can can usually have outlandish expectations with only incremental compensation improvement offered - like describing how to build a profitable algorithmic trading system in explicit, low level technical detail over the phone in 10 minutes.

title: "NA"
pros: Good working environment. Good visibility to upper management
cons: Varying market, too many restrictions

title: "Be ruthless"
pros: Eye catcher on a resume Helps your advancement in this industry by the connections you make
cons: Heavy work load stress competition Your life outside work will deteriorate.

title: "Was not the same place"
pros: The benefits are good. The best people at Goldman Sachs stack up well with any other finance company. Good focus on technology and challenging problem a plenty.
cons: the money is gone in finance. Regulation and low margins have squeezed all the money out. My compensation was down a third from the peak. they are trying to bring in a new set of people with reset expectations but there are few good people left to bring them up to speed. Soon Goldman will be like Chase or Bank of America, just another big bank

title: "Vice President"
pros: High Pay and dynamic environment
cons: Software you learn there is not usable on the street since it is all bespoke/homegrown

title: "Review"
pros: Challenging, engaging, educational, culture, innovation
cons: Hours, workload, stress, time, budget

title: "Intern"
pros: Great learning experience and exposure to others at the company. Everyone seemed to care about what we learned and how we were treated.
cons: Hours are unbearable and the competitiveness is really toxic. No relationship with coworkers due to that competition against each other.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Strong culture, emphasis on retaining talented people at the firm and willing to provide internal mobility options to do so. Brand name still carries a lot of weight and opens doors.
cons: The GS brand equity is not lost on managers and can hinder the ability to increase compensation as a result. Decision making very top heavy much like other wall st banks

title: "Tech Infrastructure Department"
pros: Great compensation, lots of smart people in business side of the company. Great location to work downtown NYC and you get to meet lots of vip.
cons: The worst tech infrastructure (TI) department in fortune 500 company, is all about who you know not what you know. Managers in TI department has no tech experiences whatsoever, only thing they know is trimming the fat that they want for themselves.

title: "slow growth"
pros: Challenging work and good people
cons: Too much competition due to management chaos Growth only in Low cost location. Show and Tell is more important that actual work

title: "Veteran Integration Program"
pros: Good experience, great exposure to finance and helpful for transitioning veterans
cons: Different culture takes some work/patience to get used to

title: "Overall great place to work"
pros: Ideal place for a person who likes fast pace. Great leadership and they help you groom yourself as a leader You get to learn a lot about financial markets. They do a great job of inviting the leaders from many streams to learn from their perspectives.
cons: Difficult to work flexible hours / WFH at a firm like GS. In person and on time matters a lot. As the firm got significantly larger you feel a bit lost in the org structure which is not very transparent. Compensation varies significantly with market swings - so not ideal for a person seeking stability.

title: "Operations associate"
pros: Great place for people that like to work in teams. The culture of the firm rewards people that are team oriented.
cons: Depending on the team you are in work hours may be very long. Also, it is a very political place and advertising on your work and accomplishments is necessary for career growth.

title: "Definitely a good place to start"
pros: This was my first job out of college so it was great meeting so many new people and making friends. Goldman definitely invests in its people and gives its new employees time to get up to speed on things. Expect a ton of training and networking events.
cons: At the end of the day, Goldman's an investment bank, and although its starting to change, technology still feels like a second tier (under the traders, banking, and finance divisions). It's not the place where you're going to come in and change the world, or help everyday people solve problems. But you'll definitely learn a lot along the way. Also, it's very team dependent. Different teams treat their employees differently.

title: "Great people"
pros: Working at Goldman Sachs in New York gave me an incredible opportunity to meet and work with people from all over the world.
cons: It was all terrific until many layers of bureaucracy became the norm. Also higher management does tend to play favorites. No regard for or consideration of loyalty.

title: "No title"
pros: Networking, diversity, chance of mobility, good benefit plan, review system is improving; people are open for conversation and most of them are willing to help
cons: Lack of communication between senior management and junior employee (decisions are not transparent); long work hours so work life balance is not real

title: "great company"
pros: dynamic, intensive and also very teamwork oriented
cons: hours could be long and the review process can be stressful.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Name, reputation, some smart people
cons: political, toxic, hyper competitive, not positive "work and challenge" stress but a lot of negative stress from people and politics. Environment is not a place that allows open discussion and people can positively challenge view points. Many people are not open minded.

title: "Media Services MOCC team"
pros: The salary and benefits are good.
cons: Unskilled Managers with no people management skills.

title: "bad culture"
pros: The pay is really good. You get stipends for dinner and cab rides. A good bonus if you work hard and make money. Some good exit opps
cons: Long hours. Bad culture. Oppressive management. A lot of micro managing on the lower level. Pay is the same as other companies.

title: "Great job, long hours"
pros: Great job, amazing and talented coworkers. I am pushed to my fullest potential every day. I spend a lot of time with my managing director, which helps to give direction to my career.
cons: Long hours; I work 60+ hours. If you are someone who does not like intense jobs, then this is not for you. There really are not many negatives.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Interesting projects, new technologies and drive for achieving and completion
cons: Long working hours difficult to maintain work life balance

title: "Back-office Technology"
pros: - Technical training when joining directly after college - Lifetime networking connections - Very strong infrastructure allowing you to focus on your actual job duties
cons: - At least as many managers as "doers" - High pressure that doesn't leave you when you go home

title: "Overall a good company"
pros: Great people, great internal mobility options, good benefits
cons: Very long hours, sometimes very high pressure

title: "Support Engineer"
pros: Good to start of your career. Benefits are ok. Bonuses can good.
cons: Work life balance. Layoffs. No job security.

title: "Analyst"
pros: big name, good culture, great place to start career
cons: long hours, stressful work environment

title: "Great company, but in banking industry"
pros: great people, can-do approach, constant search for new ideas and new ways of doing things, constant pressure to improve, develop, move forward.
cons: Industry that is on the downward slope: politically, reputationally, technically, legally, etc...Regulation will strangle it overtime, money and opportunities to make it will dry up and so will the talent pool working there. Perhaps not for 10 or so years, but Goldman is changing and not for the better overall. Unfortunately.

title: "Goldaman Sachs Strats review"
pros: Smart and hard-working people. Noticed that the lower level employees are often smarter than their bosses and more friendly.
cons: Old-timers clinging on to their jobs, don't allow new recruits to experiment or try out new ways of doing things.

title: "Great Company!"
pros: Great benefits, Great people to work with, Great brand name
cons: Salary is on the lower end

title: "Vice President"
pros: Lots of smart people and lots of opportunity to have a varied career in a location that is not New York. Lots of mobility opportunities
cons: 1) Low revenue and cost cutting has given rise to horrible office politics, lack of transparency into strategy and a lot of finger pointing when things go bad. 2) For junior level VP's there is little or no coaching opportunity. You are practically left to you own devices and blamed squarely for any mistakes. 3) Brutal hours and little or no work life flexibility. A lot of senior managers set a bad example by sending e-mails over the weekend and you are viewed unfavorably if you don't respond.

title: "Assiciate"
pros: Very smart and hardworking prople
cons: Compensation Work life balance Career development

title: "There's a reason attrition is so high"
pros: - Good name on your resume - Solid experience - Challenging environment - Great coworkers
cons: - Disconnected management - Lack of perks (despite how big the name is, and how perks used to be. You get nothing now but free coffee and decent 401k matching) - Cutthroat environment - it's really not like any other job you've worked and you'll drive yourself nuts if you take it too seriously - Management isn't honest about opportunities that really exist at the firm.

title: "Smart people, crazy hours"
pros: Great brand--perfect place to start out your career as it's a great platform for recruitment Smart people--they do a good job hiring Nice gym--one in a blue moon when you have time to work out, 200 West has a fantastic gym
cons: Crazy hours--too many allnights and canceled vacations Inefficiencies given many layers--comments from Associate, then VP, then senior VP, then MD, then Partner etc.

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Really work to help your career development and focused on training and development. Great people to work with and managers.
cons: Very little work life flexibility and entry level career path is pretty standardized making it difficult to differentiate yourself.

title: "Financial Analyst"
pros: Great place to work, long hours, smart and commercial people. Cachet of working for premier firm on Wall Street
cons: Long hours, sink or swim culture, no work life/balance. Definitely hierarchical.

title: "Sr. Commodity research analyst"
pros: Lots of networking opportunities inside of the firm
cons: Hierarchical Less career opportunities

title: "Work Hard -- and glean tons of great experience!"
pros: Talented, committed colleagues. Internal infrastructure is truly magnificent in comparison to so many other large companies.
cons: Mobility throughout global GS is not as easy as one would think. Don't even understand how it is legal, to be honest.

title: "Overall"
pros: Excellent company, work, benefits, people, teams
cons: Aggressive, hectic, very agile, unstructured, matrix/flat organization

title: "Taking the job was the best decision I have ever made and leaving was the second best..."
pros: Great opportunity to learn and build your resume. They hire from a lot of different backgrounds so it can be a great step into the industry.
cons: Lots of hours, high stress, incompetent management, a lot of talk and very little action. The company is not all that it is cracked up to be. Expect to feel like a cog in the wheel and expendable at any moment.

title: "Good but not the best"
pros: Network you build and people you meet.
cons: Hard to rise through the ranks.

title: "GS"
pros: Strong diversity and corporate culture.
cons: Reality doesn't always match culture desired

title: "Operations is not that exciting"
pros: Work with some bright people, decent benefits, get to take a trip to NY if you are an incoming campus grad.
cons: Long hours, boring and monotonous work, competitive culture. They will not hesitate to lay off staff.

title: "General Review"
pros: Flexible work arrangements and good people
cons: Tough for promotion and new opportunities

title: "Prime Brokerage Associate"
pros: The people you work with are often great, the culture is very strong and it's a great company
cons: It's a large organisation so you have to actively monitor your growth & connections

title: "Exactly what you'd expect it to be"
pros: Compensation - Generous. It is the primary motivational tool at their disposal, and they wield it aggressively. Some people might complain they don't get enough given how miserable they are, but the important part of their complaint is that they are miserable - no amount of money is going to fix that. Proficiency - There are some truly brilliant people working there. If you have a chance to work with them and pick their brain on a daily basis, you will learn more about the industry in a few years than many people do in their entire career. However, this is not the vast majority of the population at Goldman - my coworkers tend to agree with the following demographic breakdown: 10% brilliant, 60% slightly above average (but think being at GS makes them brilliant), 30% trying to escape and don't care.
cons: Leadership - It doesn't exist here. People are promoted to management positions based on their ability to make money, absent any consideration of their leadership potential. As a result, very few teams have anything but a toxic work environment with ineffective leaders.

title: "Amazing experience"
pros: Amazing networking opportunities, lots of networking events where you can meet people across the firm and learn about what they do.
cons: There were really few negative aspects of the experience.

title: "Pros/Cons"
pros: intelligent people, excellent healthcare/benefits package, great in office gym/healthcare facilities
cons: optics more important than real work, no work life balance- though it is promoted by management it is completely unrealistic given how lean the firm runs, when the firm does not perform well comp is increased for the selct few that are absolutely necessary, and is non existent for everyone else, posting updates more important than actually doing real work

title: "Technology at Goldman"
pros: GS is a great place to work with first-rate salary and benefits. The health care is excellent, with on-site health facilities. Lots of great co-workers. A really diverse group with people from all over the world.
cons: Technology at Goldman focuses on short-term wins which leads to a lot of thrash and misses potential opportunities that could result from longer term investments in applied research. Middle management layers (MDs) are driven too much by the need to avoid missteps rather than providing dynamic technical leadership. This is causing young people to leave the firm.

title: "PSLP"
pros: Very competitive with intelligent Co workers. Great place to work with a very good management team. Very high paced with many opportunities if you perform. Surprisingly not a lot of politics. Performance based. Good money and benefits.
cons: Long hours so balance can be difficult.

title: "operations"
pros: great benefits, teamwork culture, learning environment
cons: work life balance is none existent

title: "Gain good experience"
pros: Smart, passionate work force, fast paced environment. Forward thinking technologists, looking to build applications ground up. Good growth opportunities. Excellent review process.
cons: Long hours, pressure to deliver. Base increments and bonuses (Tech division) are a hit or a miss, closely tied with firm performance more than yours.

title: "High turnover"
pros: -good compensation and benefits -friendly people -working with smart people
cons: -management is unsupportive and isn't willing to listen at times -high turnover

title: "Equity Research Analyst"
pros: -Small teams -Ownership over research you put out -Apparent path for advancement within the firm -Serious culture of excellence
cons: -Lots of corporate politics to contend with -Brutal hours, but you should already know that going in

title: "Contract Worker"
pros: The people at GS were great to work with and the location was awesome. The hours were not terrible on my team and the work was fairly straightforward.
cons: Doing temp/contract work was fine but sometimes felt like you were less valued than other employees at GS. Another minor con was the work flow was a bit inconsistent at times.

title: "Best bank in the world"
pros: Great culture Great benefits Senior Mgmt cares about employee's growth
cons: Work-life balance is awful Compensation is not great

title: "Vice President"
pros: Company & people are very good.
cons: The workplace is very intense atmosphere

title: "GS Tech Salary"
pros: interesting, smart people interesting and challenging projects cutting edge technology beautiful building, brand value stability
cons: hours work life balance one person does the work of 2 and gets paid for 1 1/3 sometimes it seems like you're not moving up or moving laterally for a while before making a jump

title: "analyst review"
pros: Great teams and talents; Investment bank culture, and looks good on resume; Comprehensive training opportunities. Nice office in one of the best areas in Manhattan.
cons: Very long work hours and high pressure; Office politics could positively or negatively impact your career; Not easy to switch team, and limited promotion opportunities; Need to know the right people to be noticed.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Great team work envt, excellent benefits, great co workers
cons: review process can be too lengthy

title: "Associate - Analyst Operations"
pros: Diverse organization, strong financial backing, team driven culture.
cons: Low Pay, very long hours, political promotion culture.

title: "Great Firm to work for"
pros: Great work experience, very supporting peers
cons: managing work and life balance

title: "Vice President"
pros: Goldman is very competitive and challenging place to work. During the employment a lot of things can be learned. Easy internal mobility
cons: Long working hours. A lot of pressure to be in top ranking to be able to get bonus. Review process is very harsh.

title: "Great Place"
pros: Smart people work at the bank
cons: Hours are long and work can be repetitive

title: "Great place"
pros: Great place to work. Strong culture
cons: Long hours. Not a lot of hand holding

title: "Great place to start your Career"
pros: Working at Goldman Sachs will give you great Investment banking experience and you will work with many of the most qualified Investment Bankers in the world. The management is interested in your personal learning. Work life balance throughout the company is really improving.
cons: It can be hard to move up within the company. The company gives many options for Internal mobility, but it is not as easy as they make it seem.

title: "Associate"
pros: You get to work with great, sharp, execution-oriented people. In front-office technology roles, you learn the business and people skills, not just technical skills. I'm paid well and I appreciate the prestige and respect comes with working at Goldman. The people I work with are a joy to work with. They are humble, fun, very sociable, and very professional. Everyone is very well put together and affable. Honestly, I absolutely love working at Goldman, so don't let my below nitpicks make you think I don't. The only way for us to improve is for us to be transparent about—and focus on–our issues. So I'm going to focus on the nitpicks. If you can live with them, then JOIN! Because I'm pretty much covering every nit-picky grievance I have. (Really.) I think things are largely moving in the right direction, and that's what matters most, as it tells me that we are aware of our deficiencies, and we're actively working to improve them. No place is perfect, but Goldman is certainly among the very best places to work. I feel very happy, privileged, honored, and humbled to be a member of Goldman's "family."
cons: There are lots of meetings and distractions to juggle as a technologist. There's always more to get done then there is time for. Sometimes projects aren't properly designed in order to meet the pressure of deadlines, and you end up building a Leaning Tower of Pisa. You usually have to perform support tasks (on that leaning tower) while simultaneously developing new features. After you've helped resolve issues, the same people come back and ask what the status is on the project delivery timeline… in a meeting you're spending time with them in, of course. Some in the business will ask why a bug existed and how we can stop them going forward, as though we knew about them to begin with and left them in. (Have they ever read the notes on any phone app update? Find one that didn't include bug fixes! Unfortunately, bugs happen. Please be understanding.) There's also a lot of proprietary in-house tech. Goldman often chooses to re-invent the wheel, instead of using an open source library, or contributing to them, for that matter. In the end, it's a losing play that doesn't scale; better solutions are inevitably created when you collaborate with the world, and you gain knowledge-sharing gravity when you do so. Documentation is often lacking as well.

title: "Technology"
pros: Decent work / life balance.
cons: The culture has become watered down and it is not the place is used to be. There is a lack of career path and growth in Technology. Compensation is becoming non-competitive.

title: "Not easy to succeed"
pros: interesting and diverse people, world class facilities, many opportunities to learn, ability to build an extensive network, good but pricy benefits
cons: legacy infrastructure, can be stuck with poor management in many divisions, a bit bloated, can be too bureaucratic and frustrating, enormous pay disparity between front office and back

title: "Best place to start a career"
pros: Goldman was a wonderful place to start my career. They had a ton of support and mentorship. Most of all they had incredibly bring individuals as peers as well as managers.
cons: It's a sugar coating culture. You will never get feedback straight. You must go out of your way to make sure your interests are protected.

title: "Best place to start your career"
pros: Surrounded by bright, driven people in a professional work environment. Unlimited resources to develop professionally and personally. I'm constantly learning. NYC gym is a very nice perk.
cons: As said by many others before me, face time can extend a slow day from 6pm to closer to 8pm depending on the group / division.

title: "Operations - Great Place To Start A Career"
pros: Very very smart people and you get thrown into the fire right away where you can sink or swim. Anything you want to learn here you can and the name carries a lot of weight.
cons: Work/Life balance is a challenge. You have to be extremely focused and calculated to move up but i'm not sure that doesn't happen everywhere.

title: "great pay = no life"
pros: great pay, smart people, excellent brand
cons: they run their employees into the ground

title: "intern"
pros: you will have the opportunity to have your resume good for the future. it is a famous and big ompany that everyone tries to get in.
cons: long working hours, very stressful. but you will learn a lot and if you make it, things gonna be different.

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Great benefits, Career builder, Mobility
cons: Long working hours, Stressful enironment

title: "Better off at a tech company than doing IT here"
pros: -Depending on your group, you can easily have a great work/life balance. -Pretty strong job security, the good developers generally do not stay very long so if you're skilled then you won't really have to worry much about it. -People are generally very nice. -Advancement is pretty much standard until you hit middle management so there's a lot of transparency in career progression.
cons: -Pay is low for a software engineer job but above market for an IT support job, so it's not too bad if you have just a general engineering degree and not know a lot about programming. Don't be fooled into thinking that back office tech pay is going to be much better than other back office positions though. -Culture isn't that great to be honest. Since there isn't any profits/loss to show for performance, you'll encounter poor performing workers who just talks the talk. When things go wrong, it becomes a battle of egos and office politics instead of real honestly and working together. Level of trust is low between different teams because of it. It's very shocking how low the bar can go when simple programming issues gets turned into a magnitude of solving world peace.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Best in class, best in the industry
cons: no cons. Best place to work for.

title: "Associate"
pros: Competitive, great people, high impact job, brand value
cons: Not very transparent, screwed work life balance

title: "Senior Analyst"
pros: Great people to work with Salary is decent
cons: Lack of communication Direction may sometimes be misleading

title: "Not a place for a long term career"
pros: Opportunity to work with very talented people. Great place to start your career and get it on your resume. Unless you are on track to make partner, GS is not the best place for a long term career. If you are on track to make partner, be willing to sell your soul for the title and $
cons: The Goldman brand premium is quickly dissipating. Compensation is not what it used to be, the industry is going through difficult times and high pressure and expectations remain the same.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Firm with integrity who always tries to do what is best for its clients. Strong collaboration amongst teams and departments. Employees are smart and motivating.
cons: Long hours led to poor work/life balance, although this very much varies by team and department. Due to the size of the firm, some teams were highly specialized.

title: "Great small business with big business goals!"
pros: Flexible with hours.. Great pay..
cons: For 3 or 4 months very very heavy work load.

title: "Operations"
pros: Fast paced, great opportunity, a lot of responsibility, great compensation. Excellent place to start a career
cons: Challenging, competitive, fast paced, multiple projects

title: "Analyst"
pros: Great Compensation and Benefits in many categories, like the salary, insurances, opportunity for scholarships, etc. Benefits like the blackberry for work use pertaining to the role.
cons: Bad Manager in relationship to health management and work/life balance. Unwilling to cooperate with rules pertaining to benefits and employee activities

title: "Not what it used to be"
pros: - Resume builder, great for next jobs
cons: - Long hours, pay is not what it used to be

title: "HCM Anaylst"
pros: - Great place to learn foundations - Good to have on resume - Benefits are good ( 4mo paid maternity leave/1 mo for men)
cons: - TERRIBLE work/life balance - Extremely political and toxic environment - Very stressful place - Poor culture within the firm ( a lot of backstabbing, gossip ect) - Diversity is limited - VERY BAD MANAGERS - Mobility is discouraged

title: "No life"
pros: Great people, mobility options, very professional environment, challenging work.
cons: No personal time or life. The pay/compensation is not what you think it is. BIG difference between NY salaries and UT salaries. Excessive work, long hours.

title: "Associate"
pros: Strong culture, diversity, people are generally nice to each other.
cons: Working in tech side is sidekick, the pay is not good, especially for non-managers.

title: "Associate"
pros: GOOD LEARNING, great brand .. good money ...you feel like you are in the thick of wall street for good or bad ...If tahts what you wnat to do this is the place to be
cons: Crazy work Schedule... forget family life ... work balance ... they are ruthless when it comes to expectations for work from employees ... run very lean .....

title: "VP"
pros: Work environment is very agile. People are skilled and very savvy. Speed is important in day to day activities.
cons: People are more interested in internal politics. People are more interested in managing upwards.

title: "Great Platform"
pros: Great Platform to launch your career, you are surrounded by the best in the industry and that will teach you to be like them.
cons: The corporate ladder is steep, if you are good but not a superstar, you can linger around as a VP forever.

title: "money is good"
pros: money was really great people are very smart
cons: work life balance is not great

title: "Analyst"
pros: Money, experience, exposure to senior talent
cons: Poor work-life balance and hours

title: "Analyst"
pros: Good people, good environment, good manager
cons: bad time, bad politics and

title: "Hard work, well compensated"
pros: High Pay, Lots of Learning
cons: No life outside of work

title: "Analyst"
pros: quantitative analysis, quantitative development, quantitative research
cons: work there is very stressful

title: "XXX"
pros: lots of Career Opportunities, compensation good,culture is good
cons: no work / life balance

title: "Competitive salary/benefits, strong work ethic, management "by committee""
pros: - Best-and-brightest colleagues, hard-working teams, mentor program - Excellent benefits program, onsite childcare, continuing education/training - Flexible work arrangements - Strong focus on diversity, accountability, integrity, team-building - High level of trust from management, overall - Great onsite cafeteria (though pricey)
cons: - Management tends to have strong focus on managing up, not enough on team - Hard work isn't always rewarded, you have to be comfortable flagging your accomplishments to the right people - Intense pressure for perfection, high level of scrutiny at all levels - Challenging culture to fit into as a "lateral hire" (i.e., if you started your career elsewhere); often feels like you're the new kid in school and you have to prove yourself worthy before the team will accept you - Must be able/willing to set your own boundaries (i.e., work-life balance) - if you won't, no one else will - IT lacking; steps being taken to improve and update, but process is slow and new systems are often rolled out before sufficiently user-tested - Intense interview process; you'll likely interview with at least a dozen people before getting an offer

title: "vice president"
pros: Great salary good customer service.I recommend seeking employment hear because of the great office space.Best of all they give you a great pension when you retire.
cons: They encourage you to retire early and don't give great retirement benefits although overall it is a good idea to apply for employment at goldman sachs.

title: "Operations analyst"
pros: Good culture of the firm
cons: If you have the wrong manager your career will be a mess!!!!!

title: "Analyst"
pros: Great place to launch a career. Learn how to be a professional and strong work ethics. Also worked with great people.
cons: High stress, and low appreciation. At Goldman you are treated as a number and they make it clear anyone is disposable. I would recommend Goldman as a stepping stone. Get in and get out

title: "Wonderful culture, great benefits, and dependable co-workers"
pros: It was my first real job out of college and I really enjoyed my time there. Great people treated you with respect.
cons: hours can be long

title: "Vice President"
pros: Great place to work. Amazing technologists. One gets a chance to work in start to end of a development lifecycle - Starting from requirements gathering all the way to delivering the final product. Good compensation.
cons: Work life balance not great. Few in house products to work on. Might not have value out in the market.

title: "What you expect"
pros: Compensation is competitive. They try to di things the right way. Benefits are excellent. You're working with some of the smartest people in the business. Opportunities for advancement are excellent if you know what you're doing.
cons: Extremely cutthroat. If you're not type a, not easy to get ahead. The review process is way too involved and not actually that helpful.

title: "Nice place to learn"
pros: Great training and exposure to unique investment opportunities. Very nice pay as well, all-in-all a good place to start a career.
cons: Very difficult to move up. Office politics are absurd. People are too territorial to help truly develop younger talent.

title: "Associate"
pros: Great Firm, well known in the industry Ability to own and learn if self driven
cons: Lack of work live balance Peer group and culture very intense Politics play a major role at gs

title: "Vice President"
pros: Smart people Strong Culture Good Benefits Pro Active Culture
cons: Not too much focus on team work and collaboration vs. Individual progress

title: "Assistant"
pros: Great place to learn many new things. Very fast pace environment and majority of people are very nice in trying to help you. As long as you are nice and can show that you get work done then you will get respected.
cons: No room for growth, no feedback, a lot of hours.

title: "Excellent place to start your career"
pros: Goldman Sachs is a great place to start your career. Their rigorous training program and analyst program for investment banking provide tangible skills that can be applied to almost any other job.
cons: You have to work hard. If you don't want to put in the long hours, this is probably not the right fit for you.

title: "Good place to work"
pros: A lot of advancement opportunities, and salaries are good.
cons: A lot of red tape getting anything done can take forever Not really a technology company so if you like more of the technical side of software rather than business then it may not be for you

title: "Vice President - Technology"
pros: The single best part of working at Goldman Sachs are the people. I have never worked for a better, more professional, intelligent, and committed group of people in my career. The opportunity to work with the people Goldman Sachs is the best part of working for the firm.
cons: Development is viewed as a "cost" center and you are treated accordingly. If there is a down year or any issues, your raises and/or bonuses are the first to go. Not upper management who actually makes the decisions or are to blame for the bad years...yours. Be prepared to work on dual 19" monitors from the 90's in a tiny and noisy environment. If you ask to upgrade your monitors you will be told "We can spend thousands of dollars on upgrading everyone's monitors, but that's somebody's bonus!". They refuse to spend any more money on a department that is already viewed as an expense. There isn't an employer/employee relationship. They will try to get the absolute most out of you that they can and that you'll let them. Always with the promise of an "amazing raise" or "amazing bonus" that never materializes.

title: "Great Experience"
pros: Motivated, hard-working people that want to do a good job and produce quality work
cons: Lots of hours, intense work pace,

title: "Great Company/Poor Work-life Balance"
pros: Great career opportunities and compensation when due.
cons: Poor work life balance, and have to navigate around mediocre management at times.

title: "Sr Software Engineer Java"
pros: When you say the name "Goldman Sachs", people say Wow you work for The Goldman Sachs.Lots of market value. They work on some of the latest technologies. Relaxed dress code on Fridays and in Jersey office - great move by a company like GS. Free admission to museums.
cons: Dress code is very strict, developers need to maintain dress code even if they do not interact with business for years. WFH is a taboo. you sitting in your desk at 7 am means a lot. Does not matter how hard you work. Open layout is good but no phone rooms, or sofas or other areas when you want to concentrate on something. Some people think the stuff they are doing is more important and do not hesitate to scream on phone. Food is bad and expensive.

title: "Analyst Developer"
pros: Great Place to work lots to learn people are really helpful if you want to learn
cons: no cons from my time there

title: "Stay away at all cost"
pros: Good name to put on resume, you got to learn some financial knowledge. Lots of training available if you like to learn education/personal investing/some celebrity talk.
cons: I'll put this way, recruiting is like sales pitches, and I did not find the number anywhere close to what they advertised. Internal technology is terrible(almost nothing works reliably) and GS is not fixing them! architecture is also based on these so you will see some really really strange architecture. code base is absolutely the worse I've seen. You will find you have no transferable knowledge when you apply for new jobs. (Maybe you learned a few finance words and tons of politics tricks?) Office politics is nightmare. As a hardcore software engineer, I did not enjoy any minutes here, that's why I left.

title: "Technology Analyst Experience"
pros: Many opportunities to learn about finance and a broad spectrum of tech used throughout the firm.
cons: Management has started referring to GS as a "tech company" but the culture and pay is still far behind that of a tech company. It feels like working in an IT department sometimes.

title: "review"
pros: it was very very good
cons: i though it could be better

title: "Associate"
pros: They invest in their people and provide excellent feedback through their 360 degree review process each year.
cons: Overtime is mandatory and every year the company fires the bottom tier.

title: "People, growth, & job satisfaction"
pros: - nice to work with a bunch of smart people - learn and do a lot daily, hence accumulating knowledge and experience rapidly - get new challenges every year and high job satisfaction when spent time and efforts to achieve goals
cons: - long working hours and lack of work/life balance - stressful and intense - there are places offering more $ for the value (given the long hours)

title: "Product Control"
pros: cant thing of any pros
cons: very long hours / no pay

title: "Better than typical service firms"
pros: Ownership of work You can firsthand experience the impact of your work on your business clientele develop rigorous project management and leadership skills surrounded by smart people competitive salaries
cons: office politics around promotion people management may shadow technical prowess difficult to grab good opportunities for personal skill development. very focused on getting work done

title: "World-Class Firm But Can be a Rat race"
pros: - You work with some of the best and brightest in the world - Established and embodied culture of excellence - Meritocratic and performance based
cons: - Long working hours - Competitive environment, sometimes like a rat race

title: "Former VP"
pros: Very high quality people compared to most of the business world Strong compensation package
cons: Senior bankers very eager for junior bankers to specialize / expertise in niche areas to assist them which diminishes junior bankers' careers Fewer bankers being promoted to senior levels (many reasons for this including senior bankers simply staying in their roles longer) which leaves many bankers at middle levels looking for alternative employment at an awkward "almost senior" point in their career

title: "Great Company"
pros: Pay is good, benefits meet my expectations, and the working environment is competitive. All my colleagues are motivated and willing to work hard.
cons: The hours are very long and there is minimal work-life balance. The stakes are high and there is no room for error.

title: "Programmer Analyst"
pros: Smart ppl to work with, extensive review system with good follow ups by manager, ready to invest in new technology projects
cons: Recent years they don't pay that much, bad work life balance - lot of colleagues used to stay late just to impress and surprisingly it worked. In last few years there has been lott of attrition due to same reason.

title: "Great Company"
pros: Everything is very fast pace. It is an old cliche, but if you like to wake up and not know what your work day is going to be like, then you'll love GS. Everyone is really intelligent.
cons: Company may let go of people abruptly

title: "Tech vp"
pros: Still is a great place to work
cons: Unknown future of the industry

title: "Cut-throat culture, but high rewards"
pros: Great compensation at all levels on the salary and the bonus, great reputation among clients and corporates alike. Offices are very nice and people are very bright as well.
cons: Culture is very cut-throat, lots of people with big egos who generally make the working environment pretty toxic. Expected to work very hard so don't expect to have too much of a life outside of work. Also revenue growth will likely be tough if the current environment persists.

title: "Not great any more"
pros: Smart people around. Good for people at a higher level.
cons: Absolutely no work life balance. Not so good for junior level employees.

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Great place to work and wonderful culture
cons: Can be tough to navigate if you don't have great manager

title: "Managing director"
pros: Being a boss in the finance world
cons: No cons exist when your a boss

title: "Compliance"
pros: Great company to work for
cons: None that I can think of.

title: "Technology associate"
pros: Interesting projects. If you are ambitious, there are a lot of opportunities. Compensation is based on how well you perform.
cons: If you just do your work and don't produce above and beyond the bonus will be almost nonexistent

title: "elite investment bank"
pros: great team work in the operations division. latest technology (cloud containers), opportunities to work on multiple databases, programming languages like java, c# etc
cons: cut throat competition overall compensation not so great anymore the old culture no more existent.

title: "best bank"
pros: The work culture is amazing
cons: The hours can be long but rewarding

title: "Great place to learn"
pros: Very smart people Meritocracy Mobility within groups Mentorship Culture
cons: Incredibly long hours Cut throat competition

title: "No Surprises"
pros: Smart people. Large pool of resources to help you. Robust training program. Opportunity to rise the ranks. Exposure to interesting deals, smart clients, etc.
cons: People are not really folks you'd want to grab a beer with. Definitely lots of internal politics involved (not the pure meritocracy they might sell you on...just be sure you know how to forge the right alliances).

title: "Securities Division"
pros: Incredible exposure, talented peers fantastic experience
cons: Typically great people, but can vary

title: "Technology Division is Struggling"
pros: There is a plethora of different technologies abound at Goldman Sachs. If you want to learn new things, Goldman does provide for plenty of training and learning opportunities.
cons: Technology at Goldman Sachs is completely out of touch with reality. They have started imposing rigid mandates that have limited ROI for some teams, while failing to provide investments in tooling necessary for certain platform teams to succeed. They are significantly shedding jobs especially due to the market turbulence and the lack of significant change in direction to show appreciation and value for Technologists.

title: "Analyst"
pros: - Some of the smartest people you will ever work with - Flat hierarchy - Challenging
cons: - Lack of a work life balance because everyone around is a go-getter (yourself included)

title: "smart peer"
pros: you will have the chance to work with people who are very smart in general
cons: could be quite stressfull. long working hour.

title: "Great Place to work!"
pros: Strong salary. Strong Benefits. Challenging work. Beautiful offices. Intelligent, highly competent, and relatable people. State of the art technology. Flexible working arrangements. Diversity encouraged and is part of the culture. Obverall great place to work.
cons: Mobility is difficult. Mobility opportunities are encouraged but not practiced. At times, very political. Good talent is lost because of this. At times, very top heavy. Teams are packed with middle to senior management, and there is a heavy reliance on junior members. Progression hits a ceiling because of this, and when junior members who want to stay at the firm look for internal opportunities for growth in a different role, mobility is nearly impossible because a team relies so heavily on that junior person. Top performers have been lost because of this. Although it is preached, work/life balance is difficult.

title: "Risk Management"
pros: Culture, pride in company, smart people, internal mobility
cons: many years your salary is flat or slightly up year over year.

title: "Sachs treat their Contracted People Poorly"
pros: Great to see people work hungrily, eagerly and the bankers are ferocious at what they do. Those that are hungry play no games and it's inspirational to watch the fire as an Assistant or any capacity of lower tier positions. It's a brand so it will look good on paper.
cons: It's an overrated customer service job more than anything, tedious and poor treatment of people who are temps or contracted. They constantly remind you how you are "Not one of them" yet you are. Temps: No perks to the gym, discounts, small thank you bonuses for the harder work provided by temporary Assistants who are now coverage for the unreliable seniority.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Fast paced environment with lots of opportunities to learn. Depending on the division/team, it can be a pretty good work/life balance. Great benefits.
cons: Tendency to specialize people. Politics can be quite overwhelming. There doesn't really seem to be a way to progress within the firm for very technical profiles.

title: "I should have stayed!"
pros: AWESOME people, exceptionally talented, team oriented and supportive, generally good to work with. Great opportunities to move within the firm. GS really does that the best big corporate culture around. Amazing benefits and access to resources. Overall a wonderful experience and I regret leaving.
cons: Ancient technology, overbearing compliance, slow to change. There are a lot of cultural characteristics that exist just because they always have. For instance, the expectation of being chained to your desk whether or not you actually have work to do, or the idea of taking only the minimally required amount of vacation. This is the OLD way of doing business. In spite of its reputation for minting millionaires, lower and mid-level employees aren't making much more than industry peers. For junior and mid-level employees, comp does not keep up with Valley start-ups. Tech recruiters prey on analysts, associates, and VPs.

title: "Technical Architect - Risk and Control Systems"
pros: Quality of co-workers Interesting projects Position of company in industry
cons: Global teams instead of co-locating members in one office Disappointing pay in recent years Too much custom in-house platforms which lead to Goldman specific skill sets Emphasis on hiring in "low cost centers" - Do YOU want to relocate to Warsaw, Poland? Over emphasis on diversity when firm is already one of the most diverse employers (at least in the technology division)

title: "Analyst"
pros: Very good firm. Everyone there is smart and hardworking. All about adding as much value as you can before being cut.
cons: The paranoia of the place is palpable. Everyone is running for their lives it seems. Though it's rather obvious when one isn't

title: "Smart people, but trying too hard"
pros: 1. Very motivated and smart people surrounding you 2. Most people are fairly collaborative and happy to help / answer questions 3. Get rewarded for performance, very meritocratic place
cons: Culture centers around hard work and 'doing one's time.' There is an obsession with showing how hard one is working, as opposed to being efficient with time and leaving office at a reasonable hour. I worked with an MD (fairly up the ranks) whose wife had a baby & 2 wks later he was back at work, pulling 3am nights every day of the week. Go home to your wife, man.

title: "Operations Summer Analyst"
pros: Friendly and cohesive work environment
cons: Feel like a gear in the machine. Hours of mindless work

title: "Associate"
pros: Good work environment , great benefits. Excellent opportunities. Firm has done it best to help balance work -life. Great place to work.
cons: Hierarchy oriented culture, the 360degree evaluation is a eyewash , the ratings have nothing to do with quartilng and the quartilng decides your career path and salaries.

title: "VP"
pros: Great Place Great Culture No better place to start as a professional.
cons: No real cons other than Comp is opaque

title: "Great company"
pros: talented people and support for diversity
cons: long hours for analyst and assoiate

title: "Desktop Support Specialist"
pros: everything is great for working there.
cons: nothing to be honest. great company to work for.

title: "GSAM Analyst"
pros: Many opportunities to learn Company culture very focused on collaboration Benefits aside from pay are very competitive
cons: compensation skews on the low side Can be political depending on the team you are on

title: "VP- Tech"
pros: Employee benefits , good peer group and talented employees .
cons: Striving to improve work life balance

title: "Awesome place"
pros: Amazing place to work and learn
cons: Nothing negative to really say

title: "Watch out for vultures!"
pros: Good pay, good advancement, IF you're one of those people who intern your way in and deal with bringing in money. If you're anyone else, forget it. And in the office I was in, free coffee.
cons: High turnover, unfriendly work environment; demanding, unfriendly management. The classic stereotype of the "slave-driving boss" breathing down your neck. Very bad internal processes. Sick people go to work and make others sick, but it's all part of working for the biggest investment banking company in the world.

title: "Goldman Sachs - An Experience for the Better"
pros: The culture and the people. The place gets a bad rep, but it's undeserved. You'll work hard and around a lot of talented people. Having a healthy amount of Goldman time on your resume will help open doors if you do decide on other places to work.
cons: The hours, but you know what you're signing up for when you're coming in. It's not a 9-5, but it's not a 24/7 job either.

title: "PWM Ops"
pros: Great experience and great people
cons: Hours can be stressful and long

title: "Good but keep worling at it"
pros: Open to new ideas and hard working individuals
cons: Politics start showing up as you move up.

title: "IBD Analyst"
pros: - Smart, intelligent and driven colleagues and supportive senior people - Mentorship - Great company structure and clean management - Enough services and support available to do your job well - Great exposure to companies and senior management
cons: - Long and unpredictable work hours

title: "Great company and great opportunities"
pros: Work with talented people and learn a lot of things
cons: It is very competitive and you need to be proactive and motivated

title: "Good place to start a career"
pros: Great people, very open workplace
cons: Work can be repetitive and not intellectually stimulating

title: "Associate"
pros: Goldman Sachs has very intelligent people and you learn a lot from each other. Everybody has a drive to be the best and this makes it a great environment to work in.
cons: Hours are very long, work-life balance is very hard to manage if you want to move up the corporate ladder. You do not always get rewarded for your hard work.

title: "Market Risk Management"
pros: high quality Employee and firm culture
cons: work life balance and long working hours

title: "Solid Job"
pros: My team consists of intelligent individuals who enjoy their jobs and management that effectively foster a team environment.
cons: In such a large organization it can be difficult to find the right job when searching for a balance of interest in the business logic and technology behind your work.

title: "Good resume builder if you can handle mundane work...yawn"
pros: Driven and motivated atmosphere/culture. Pretty good benefits. Downtown office is nice with great views. Good resume builder. Diversity.
cons: Most of the positions in SLC are back office type positions where you won't get much, if any, face-time interaction with clients. There is a lot of mundane tasks that can be really mind numbing. You are just one of many "robots" and have your set of functions to complete the way they tell you (no deviating) on a daily basis. Most people can feel like they hit a wall in terms of learning as your day-to-day job responsibilities are quite repetitive with little room for creativity. You don't need to have a business degree to get hired at GS. Most jobs can be completed by anyone, really. Pay is on the lower end for the hours.

title: "They are okay to work for"
pros: High professional business envirenment, good benfit
cons: Office politics is really a serious problem over there

title: "Sr. Tax Asst"
pros: Great benefits, great bonus great pay
cons: There weren't any cons that I could think of

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Amazing people great place to work and to learn
cons: Can be competitive but that's not all bad

title: "A good place, for the most part"
pros: The high caliber of colleagues is a big plus; this gives a lot of opportunities to observe and learn from one's team mates, irrespective of whether they are more or less experienced than you.
cons: Very highly competitive environment; while this is a plus for some people, not everyone thrives in such a setting. With the right manager and team, this isn't a big problem though.

title: "smart people"
pros: smart people, culturally top notch
cons: little work life balance, middle management can be annoying

title: "Vice President"
pros: internal mobility opportunity for junior bankers good benefits industry leader in striking a better work/life balance for junior bankers
cons: some groups may have more office politics than others internal review system may not reflect everything an individual has accomplished but would affect compensation limited career support for mid-level staff

title: "GS Experience"
pros: Excellent place to share ideas and your always working with the brightest and best people.
cons: only top 10% make the big money

title: "Associate team lead"
pros: I work with some of the best people who strive to do the best in their job. Goldman has a really good structure to identify and land some of the best talent. Interesting work and you are always busy.
cons: They tend to burn you out- give you extremely tight deadlines with limited resources. For projects, you are given more work and expected to maintain all of your previous workload.

title: "Overall good firm to work for"
pros: Smart people are all around
cons: you have to work really Long hours

title: "Long hours"
pros: Good for Fresh college graduates. Very smart colleagues from whom you get to learn a lot. One of the best brands to work for in financial services
cons: Long working hours. Work life balance could be better. Benefits could be better. Performance management process could be better and can be more transparent

title: "Great"
pros: Management consulting in nature, work amongst best and brightest. Great foundational training as well, with opportunities to change roles within the division.
cons: Takes a while to move up in rank and pay. The only way is to put in years, slow and steady

title: "GS"
pros: The opportunity to work with experts in the field Great exposure to senior management for all employees The culture at GS is truly a team-oriented environment and the people is what has kept me at GS for so long.
cons: While I love the people I work with, the amount of hours contributed during the week do not lend itself to an appropriate work life balance and the compensation does not reflect that either.

title: "Solid place to start a career"
pros: Great leadership and training. Impactful work from the get go. People have high expectations for quality or work. Supporting teams are for the most part helpful
cons: Hours, pay is most definitely below market. However, they do reward their top performers well. Difficult to maintain top performer status.

title: "Human resources"
pros: The people are great to work with
cons: Long hours and the projects change.

title: "It's Investment Banking not DisneyWorld!"
pros: Benefits, locations, types of businesses, networking opportunities if you are aggressive. If you land with the right group/manager, you can go far. Ability to get assignments in other states or countries if you desire.
cons: Review system is constantly getting revamped and i don't feel they ever get it right. The need for consensus often makes getting approval or the green light extremely time consuming. Middle management is in need of training. You can easily be pigeonholed before you even know it. It is not as easy to move around within the company.

title: "Great company to work for"
pros: Employees are well-compensated and have many benefits including healthcare, vacations, etc.
cons: Long work hours. Time management is critical.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Team-work, strength of brand name, opportunity for internal mobility, junior banker initiative which includes no working from 9pm on Friday to 9am on Sunday, diversity of employees
cons: Demanding hours which can be counterproductive, highly pressurized environment, high expectations. Pros far exceed the cons. Great place to work.

title: "Summer Intern"
pros: good salary, in NYC, young co-workers
cons: serious environment, long work hours, intense

title: "Good - if you're in the right clique"
pros: Goldman invests a lot into people, great effort and expense put into training. Higher than average compensation.
cons: Intense work environment, disconnected unengaged local management, a culture of blame aversion and finger pointing even with teams.

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Intelligent co-workers, well-compensated, global, place to make a career
cons: Regulatory environment, main street backlash

title: "Equities Analyst"
pros: Exciting environment, great pay, good connections.
cons: Very political, long hours, high oversight.

title: "Great for new software engineers"
pros: Amazing training for hires right out of school. Great mentorship programs, interesting projects, tons of community service opportunities. Amazing benefits (on site gym and doctors, 16 weeks maternity leave, 18+ days vacation). You work with some of the smartest people in the industry.
cons: Depending on the team, your hours can be long. Business is demanding. There is in increasing amount of less interesting reg reporting projects. Bonuses are not what they used to be.

title: "Loved it !!!"
pros: great people all around, love the work culture and the opportunities presented.
cons: A lot of it depends on your manager, and the opportunities which arise in your specific location.

title: "VP"
pros: There is a unique Goldman culture that people are smart, demanding and ambitious. There are always challenges and opportunities to grow.
cons: Long working hours, stressful environment since the tops always want to be the best.

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Lots of smart and motivated co workers
cons: It is a very political firm. It all about who you know and if they are pulling for you to succeed.

title: "Summer Associate"
pros: Great company, lots of hours
cons: Long hours and face time is a must.

title: "Finance"
pros: Talented, driven people focusing on enhancements and always doing the right thing.
cons: Work-life balance - if you try for that, your career will suffer.

title: "Goldman Sachs India"
pros: It is a process oriented organisation. It pays well and you find smart co-workers to work with. It makes you a more savvy person and well versed in corporate culture.
cons: It promotes excessive red tape in its technology division. New ideas and thoughts take forever to be implemented. it generates frustration in people with a startup mindset.

title: "Nice"
pros: Working here is nice. The atmosphere was great. There was a major sense of teamwork.
cons: Lots of hours. Very stressful. Fast paced, that can be good or bad depending how you look at it.

title: "N/a"
pros: Mobility opportunities, learning and development opportunities and open door policy. The collaborative culture produces high performing teams. Good benefits and perks.
cons: The usual office hours are long if you need to coordinate work across multiple global offices. Get consensus on everything you do and want to deliver sometimes can get frustrating

title: "Associate"
pros: well-organized corporation with good benefits
cons: profit is driving the bottom line

title: "Trader"
pros: Base pay is great Lots of sharp people Brand recognition afterwards
cons: People are not creative Experience varies largely group to group Management and people development I found to be lacking

title: "Great company to work for"
pros: Great benefits, learning environment, encourage internal mobility, strong teams
cons: Promotions and raises take longer than they should. They seem to occur when the employee is on the verge of leaving.

title: "IT Specialist"
pros: Diversity of staff. Availability of transferring to other fields
cons: IT Upper Management is not local to Dallas area.

title: "Too restricted promotion structure"
pros: Surrounded by smart people, the brand and pretige
cons: You have to spend 3 years to get promoted, poor life balance

title: "No work life balance"
pros: Good package, take leaves any time, no fixed timing to come and go from office.
cons: No work life balance, No job security

title: "Equity Research Analyst"
pros: --Smart, driven people who are dedicated to their work. --Academically outstanding --People are down-to-earth, and willing to teach you things that you would find difficult to learn elsewhere --High degree of respect for peers
cons: --Long hours --Little time for developing other areas of your life

title: "GSAM AIMS group"
pros: Nice building, ease of access to senior staff. A lot of responsibility very early in career. Good progression if you prove yourself.
cons: Pay is below street. Most of the bonus pool goes to senior employees. Junior employees neglected when it comes to compensation.

title: "Good"
pros: very challenging but exciting work. The people were collaborative and supportive. This is for the PWM -tech group so might be different from the typical IB person
cons: company bureaucracy - doing good work is not enough to get up the ladder. You have to engage in office politics and be skilled at it

title: "Associate"
pros: Lots to learn good benefits
cons: Stress no life no balance strict deadlines new

title: "Associate"
pros: pay is slightly higher in SLC, than the SLC average, but significantly lower than their NY/NJ offices
cons: I would avoid the SLC office if at all possible. Lots of incompetent people. no one seems to know what is going on. Management are horrible at managing people, time, talent, etc

title: "Technology Analyst"
pros: Opportunity to work with smart and intelligent people in a fast growing and enterprising company. There is always something for everyone to do...and an opportunity for everyone to contribute, from small to great
cons: Not as many black people in the company, meaning it is not as diverse as it could be. Also, the compensation is significantly lower than in contemporary firms

title: "Most incredible culture"
pros: I have never worked for an organization where everyone from the mail room and copy room attendant to the executive office are so maniacally focussed on serving the best interests of the client.
cons: Goldman Sachs requires a complete commitment to excellent, which requires hard word and stiff competition to bring the best ideas to the client while at the same time creating a work culture where teamwork, honesty and efficiency are all valued. Its an environment that constantly is pushing you to improve.

title: "Well-Oiled Machine"
pros: Brilliant people - great culture - learn a lot - great structure and support system
cons: Long hours - unpredictable schedule

title: "Good and Bad"
pros: Training, smart people, great resume builder
cons: Suffocating compliance, dog eat dog co-workers, some terrible managers

title: "Associate"
pros: Having Goldman Sachs on your resume is a great asset. Most people think highly about this company because it has been apart of many high profile m&a and ipo deals and is known for its extensive recruiting practices and hardworking culture. So having this brand on your resume will convey many positive qualities to recruiters. If you get an offer here, definitely take it. Once hire, if you do not enjoy working here, stick it out for a few years and then start your search again.
cons: Goldman Sachs experiences very high turnover and many people, on average, stay with the company for 2-4 years. For example, in my department, in one year, about 5 employees left for other companies. Our department only had 30 people so it was a huge brain drain for us. When I asked my former colleagues on why they left, many of them cited the long hours. Some would work over 80 hours a week and other for over 11 hour days. They said they were unable to see their kids grow up or had healthy issues related to the long work weeks. So know that these long hours aren't for every lifestyle. I believe their workweek is best suited for recent college grads and other individuals who have not yet started a family.

title: "Great name to have on resume"
pros: I worked as an equity research analyst at GS. The firm is a highly recognizable name even when compared together with other wall street investment banks. Even if you work there for a couple of years, it opens the door for many more opportunities. Great training. Great platform. Great benefits (incl. healthcare, gym, meal allowances etc).
cons: Career path is not as straight forward for equity analysts as compared to investment banking analysts. One is pretty much dependent on his lead analyst to leave to be promoted to the senior role.

title: "Summer Technology Analyst"
pros: Great environment. Everyone motivates you to work harder. Interns get projects that will be in production. Co-workers are really helpful.
cons: I wish there were more product management roles in the technology division.

title: "Look Elsewhere"
pros: - Work with smart, educated people - Benefits
cons: - No work/life balance - Pay - No work from home opportunities - Senior management talks about flexibility, but this is never offered to employees

title: "Some very smart people, good learning opportunities"
pros: You would meet some very smart people, from whom you could learn a lot. The environment is nice, with senior management generally accessible and most of the time reasonable.
cons: The "consensus building culture" means a lot of meetings. Hard to do your job since sometimes not much time is left after all the meetings and conference calls.

title: "Still tops but losing it's edge"
pros: Salary and benefits are great if you work in the right cities and departments. Name recognition is tops (for now).
cons: - Technology is subpar. Poor integration of internal applications due to lack of communication between groups. Best developers don't work at banks. - Long hours - Mobility from Ops/Tech difficult with few exit ops. - Bigger banks gaining fast as GS cannot compete on many fronts, especially the consumer side.

title: "Great place to start a career in finance."
pros: Surrounded by extremely high-quality talent, which is a great environment for personal development. Talent development processes are robust and rigorously tracked. Career progress is well understood. Internal mobility program affords great exposure across products and geographies.
cons: Long hours and difficult work/life balance are definite features of a career in GS's "front office."

title: "Operations summer analyst"
pros: Prestigious name, lots of activities and opportunities to learn as intern and interact with upper level management. Great speaker series. Location was amazing.
cons: Found myself quite bored most of the time. Work seems mundane as an analyst at least. Overtime pay made no sense, as it was half time versus the standard time and a half you'd find anywhere else. Ops pay well below other divisions.

title: "Vice President"
pros: It has a great brand value
cons: Base compensation does not change much. You would get lost if you dont know to play the politics in the right way.

title: "Great place"
pros: Good pay. Competent colleagues. Opportunities for promotions if you work hard.
cons: Competition can be tough. Everybody is extremely talented.

title: "If your life is work, this is the place for you."
pros: Great experiences and opportunities. Okay pay. Good benefits. Work with very bright and dedicated people.
cons: LONG hours. Challenging personalities. Very homogenized culture that's conservative and hierarchical.

title: "Nothing exciting"
pros: Probably more efficient and commercial than other banks
cons: At least within the strats function, it is more and more just like IT. Strats team are either ppl entered before 2008 who are basically trapped here, or fresh grads desperate for a job. Anyone with a talent or choice don't want to stay here

title: "Good place"
pros: It's good place to start
cons: Not bad place to start

title: "Its transforming, but a long way to go"
pros: Transforming to a tech shop, but a long way to go.
cons: No more money in fin tech.

title: "Program Analyst"
pros: For NAPA NY trip is the best, challenging environment
cons: Bad management, partial treatment by managers Compensation after first year becomes incompetent Work life balance almost non-existent No On-site opportunities Considers Tech as cost center, so no much focus use of obscelete and propreitory technologies

title: "Hard Truths"
pros: Goldman pays you well, wants you to succeed, surrounds you with talented people, and evaluates performance on merit.
cons: Lots of very smart people that play things close to the chest so you'll feel the need to be on your game constantly. This can be very hard at times since you tend to work long hours.

title: "A great place to work"
pros: Incredible mentorship and opportunity set. I work with smart, motivated and creative people.
cons: Work life balance is a challenge

title: "really great"
pros: great environment really enjoy a ton
cons: not many downsides, all great

title: "Pays less every year"
pros: Good insurance, decent vacation time. I guess having Goldman on a resume looks good.
cons: Early starts, long hours, NO breaks. I've had lunch away from my desk once in the last 4 months.

title: "Great company but long hours"
pros: Great company to work for with great benefits and opportunities. Work with talented people and get paid well.
cons: Long hours and lack of management support it is a draw back. Technology is also falling behind the curve and the company is losing precious capacity.

title: "Doesn't remain challenging for long"
