pros: There are talented people around and the pay is good too. The work environment feels good for the first few years.
cons: The work gets repitive. The management does not handle projects very well. Directions or themes are not very well defined for a team. Meetings are not very fruitful as no conclusion is ever reached.

title: "Analyst Review"
pros: Great opportunities; international offices all around the world
cons: Incredibly poor work life balance is common

title: "Great people, commitment to excellence and client service."
pros: Great people, commitment to excellence and client service.
cons: Must be comfortable working at a large company.

title: "As financial analyst posion at"
pros: High pay compare to the industry
cons: Long hours and many projects

title: "Vice President"
pros: Competent co-workers, smart people, intellectually stimulating
cons: shark tank, aggressive culture, unpredictable stability

title: "Good Workplace"
pros: you will work with some of the greatest minds in the industry, also very good career opportunities
cons: haven't come across any so far

title: "The Production Center"
pros: Good hours and benefits
cons: awkward working conditions, near then garbage room.

title: "Smart folks, great start to career"
pros: - Great brand name, good place to start your career - Very smart co-workers - Highly professional culture - Talented senior management
cons: - Pay may not be as good as on the buy side

title: "vice president compliance"
pros: prestige and immediate recognition by others
cons: long hours and hard work

title: "Ok"
pros: Nicest peopLe to work with
cons: I don't think that the company has been the same as pre crisis

title: "Great firm, brilliant people focused on client delivery - ex operations."
pros: Strong firm strategy, strong senior leadership People centric, Client Focused, smart hard working employees Pay and benefits are great Constructive feedback for personal growth Flat management structure
cons: Operations is the only place to avoid. If you can get a role in any other division you should do it. Work life balance is difficult but that is an industry issue not GS specific. If you want a greater life balance don't work for Wall Street.

title: "Technology Analyst"
pros: Great collaborative environment. Beautiful office space. Global team. Mostly young (people are more or less 30). Salary is good for starting job.
cons: Not best technological practices. More about firm reputation than good code. After Vice President, must become a manager and stop coding.

title: "Goldman Sachs Workplace"
pros: great company to work at,meritocracy based
cons: Not much of cons here.

title: "GS Review"
pros: Excellent people to work with and learn from
cons: Work life balance is difficult to achieve.

title: "Analyst"
pros: good reputation and only just that
cons: time too long to work and the salary is not satisfied

title: "Meritocracy"
pros: Rewarding and demanding environment. Surrounded by the smartest financial minds on a daily basis
cons: Work / life balance takes a back seat at times.

title: "Great place to work if you enjoy finance"
pros: - Competitive culture - GS really extracts the most out of its employees. - They set you up for success very well. Give you all tools you need to succeed. - Competitive compensation. - Generous travel budgets - Amazing networking opportunities.
cons: - People: I don't know anyone that works at GS in a Sales or Trading position that actually likes their job. - Compensation: Although you get compensated well, money is all people talk about. Many colleagues will complain about their six figure+ bonuses. - I left GS and took a pay cut, but actually worried LESS about money because people at my new company don't talk about it all the time. GS culture places a great importance on money to the point of obsession.

title: "Investment Banker"
pros: Makes a lot of money
cons: There is a lot of headache

title: "Driven"
pros: Intellectual environment Reminds me of Harvard, everyone's smart etc.
cons: There can be group think

title: "Vice President"
pros: Good environment nice people good pay
cons: A lot of pressure

title: "Good Luck"
pros: Great company if you start as an analyst
cons: Harsh culture, no coworker friends, work, work work

title: "Long Days"
pros: Great place to get work experience and brand exposure.
cons: Work Life balance can be hard to figure out

title: "Vice President"
pros: Very efficient and competitive; strong risk management culture; excellent economic and trading research.
cons: Late work hours are anticipated (the company actually built a special limo entry for transporting late-night workers home). Too much focus on proprietary technologies that's discouraging capable IT candidates from applying for a job at Goldman.

title: "Good experience"
pros: Top-notch training, co-workers are brilliant.
cons: Less hands-on mentorship and witnessed some ugly competition b/w colleagues.

title: "Good experience overall"
pros: I worked in a great team led by a great MD. Smart people and very supportive.
cons: Long hours and mediocre middle office for my group

title: "GS REVIEW"
pros: This a very very very nice company. Everybody work as a team and yeah, they achieve things together. There is a good level of diversity.
cons: Nothing negative to say about this company

title: "GS Technology is on downward spiral - stay away."
pros: - Great training program for new grads. - they hire smart people (mostly) - Lots of different problems to solve - Internal platforms and other standardizations make development easier. - its still good to have on your resume. - they are hiring like crazy. (because so many technologists are leaving)
cons: - with smarts come arrogance. not unique to GS, but wow is it a lot. - poor equipment - No large screen monitors -we have 10 year old small 1280x1024 monitors!! Its difficult to work on those things. - many managers are not technical. Its gotten worse over time, and its at its worst now. - Forced ranking system. 1-5. Only 1 and 2 gets bonuses. The policy is to screw everyone else so they leave on their own volition. - they Cannot keep New hires from college. 90% of the "NAPAs" from 2 years ago have already left. - smart people are leaving in droves. Most good managers have left in the past 2 years, and 100s of great technologists have fled. This is not an exaggeration. - So many people have left, many teams are down to bare bones and that is a dangerous situation.

title: "Nothing is perfect"
pros: Flexible hours, opportunities to grow and learn, internal mobility, on campus facilitues such as gym, medical center, daycare;
cons: The environment can be stressful, and pretty competitive. There is often pressure to complete the tasks in very tight deadlines. Toxic multitasking is comon. This environment is best suited for highly ambitious.

title: "Tech Analyst"
pros: You work with some really great people at GS. I met some of my best friends at this place, and even after we moved on to other jobs we have remained close friends. The building is also incredibly cool and you feel proud to come to work every day.
cons: Work life balance in some positions can be pretty rough, but you should know this already if you're looking to get into any Finance based role.

title: "Culture of Risk Management"
pros: Worked in risk management, saw that company leadership did respect risk. In a pricing dispute between trader and controller, tie went to the controller. Company was able to produce a daily estimated balance sheet. I don't believe this is the case at other Wall Street banks. This culture of risk is what saved the firm during the 2008 Financial Crisis.
cons: Really intense and demanding culture, people get burned out, I was surprised at how little infrastructure/processes were built out in my group, i.e. no regular meeting rhythm between analysts/associates and VPs, scheduled ad hoc. There is summer training but you mostly learn everything on the job. Most people are very smart but not necessarily good teachers.

title: "Okay"
pros: Hard working and smart people
cons: Work-life balance is difficult to achieve

title: "Senior analyst"
pros: Good working environment with onsite health center and day care
cons: Staring increase health insurance from 2016

title: "Amazing Company"
pros: Great People, Great Company, Amazing City.
cons: Starting Salaries a little lower than one would expect, but you quick catch up in salary amount after 2-3 years

title: "Technology Analyst"
pros: Love the culture, the people and the opportunities available.
cons: Haven't experienced any thing bad so far.

title: "Large company - large network"
pros: The firm prides itself on networking and learning series where you are able to learn about different areas at the firm and meet people from all areas - back office to front office
cons: Must quickly adjust to the culture else you may find yourself out of the loop

title: "Analyst"
pros: Great culture, smart colleagues, great brand name
cons: long hours, hard to get promoted

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Decent work/life balance, inclusive environment.
cons: Horrible pay for federation divisions.

title: "VP at Goldman"
pros: - Dynamic and challenging work - Work with smart and motivated people - Compensation
cons: - Stressful - Talent development is not great - Long hours

title: "Lots of energy, not much direction"
pros: Lots of very smart people. It's rare to meet someone there who is just average. The brand has a lot of cachet, and I'm proud to say that I work there. The work in my area is interesting (though, I think that may be more of the exception, from what I've seen in other teams.)
cons: I feel like the vision is clear at the top, but by the time it filters down to the people actually doing the work, every type-A personality has begun their own little side project to show their support, and no one has the gumption to prioritize and cull the inferior projects. They are proud about taking care of their investors before their employees, which translates into less-than-one-might-think pay.

title: "Infrastructure Architect"
pros: overall good place to work
cons: depending on group, it could become stressful, long hours.

title: "Great company"
pros: Smart people, interesting work, culture of success
cons: Can be somewhat political, focus on commercial success at expense of team

title: "Good Environment"
pros: I have enjoyed working here.
cons: I have nothing bad to say.

title: "Global Investment Research (GIR) SLC ART Program"
pros: Working remotely gives you a buffer from the miserable and insecure senior analysts that you have to work with.
cons: They will call you "front office", but most of the street will not believe it or give you any credit since you are in a "back office" location. They will never tell you this when you interview, but your 2 years of experience in SLC will only amount to 1 year of experience in New York IF you get an opportunity to go there after the program (and that's a big IF since most New York senior analyst would prefer not to hire SLC analysts anyways). You will be treated like a second class citizen (which you are) by essentially everyone you work with who is in New York since you were not "good enough" to be hired there. They will pay you a ridiculously low salary that is inline with how they value you as an employee. The vast majority of analyst get to the end of the program just to realize that they are not going to New York since the firm doesn't value or want those from non-target schools, and unlike those that were hired in New York, they have essentially 0 exit opportunities (people may think they are golden with GS on their resume, but will quickly realize that they were just cheap labor that the firm paid very little for).

title: "Not the tech house if you are true engineer type"
pros: Got business exposure. Good for ppl who know how to self brand.
cons: Still just a white boy frat house. For the geek engineer type, or non-white ppl, space up is pretty limited.

title: "Culture of fear and ego"
pros: The name is respected regardless of what you do next.
cons: The culture is absolutely toxic.

title: "Investment Banking Analyst"
pros: One of the top banks on the league table. Very selective and intellectual based employee group. A great place to grow.
cons: Very competitive, people are absolute the social elites and may disregard you because you are not from a target school

title: "Investment banking - good starting point"
pros: Opportunities for advancement, smart group of analysts & MDs though some less than stellar middle management, opportunities for mobility & advancement to other roles
cons: Poor work life balance - junior employees end up working a lot of hours, very consistently. I think this is improving since I left

title: "Good place to start"
pros: smart people to work with
cons: people are perfectionists, terrible work life balance

title: "Good place to work"
pros: Good Career growth, Good place to work with lots of oppurtunities
cons: No work life balance Very high work pressure High expectations

title: "Great"
pros: Great learning environment, friendly employees, top notch place to start your career.
cons: Nothing sticks out to me at this time.

title: "Investment Banking Analyst"
pros: Great reputation, great 401k management. They really know what they're doing. Environment is fantastic to. I would highly recommend working here.
cons: It kind of tough to take days off, because you have to catch up on everything you missed that day. Decisions Decisions.

title: "senior analyst developer"
pros: Ahead of the all the big banks in terms of tech (e.g. which big bank is a member of the Java Executive Committee)
cons: Bureaucracy is a black hole It's an email culture Devs need more acknowledgement and upward mobility

title: "It's average"
pros: The pay is very good
cons: There is no work/life balance

title: "Good for Salt Lake, But Little Growth"
pros: Young office, plenty of opportunities to take charge and stand out. High expectations will train you to do well in any other job you can get in the valley.
cons: Extremely limited access to senior management. Long-term growth opportunities limited. The satellite office dynamic is toxic.

title: "System analyst"
pros: Innovations, good for out of college developers. A lot to learn from them.
cons: A lot of org changes, lay offs and lack of individual progress.

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: You work with dedicated and really smart people. Motivation for co-workers is not a problem!
cons: Country club atmosphere and very long hours.

title: "Vice President"
pros: awesome company and very smart people
cons: GS has no cons it is a great place

title: "VP"
pros: Smart, ambitious people. Flexible hours
cons: Competitive. No upward mobility. Hours can be long.

title: "Top Company"
pros: Excellent Domain experience while working with worlds top institute
cons: Hire and fire at time if economy goes for a toss

title: "Good Internship"
pros: This was a very good internship and I learned a lot along the process. Very challenging and competitive and you are always pushed to do the best you possibly can. Great compensation
cons: Double rotation program made it hard to get comfortable with the work on a desk. Just as I became familiar with one team's roles, I had to switch to another.

title: "Great experience if you can handle the workload"
pros: Goldman is known for getting the most out of its very talented employees. More often than not this means long hours and a grueling schedule of meetings, calls, and emails. As has often been said, the client is the most important thing about working at GS. This leads to a fairly rewarding atmosphere where everyone is working for the same goal. The name Goldman Sachs is as good as gold on a resume when you decide to look elsewhere.
cons: There are seemingly two tracks for employees: the 'fast' track and no track. Either you are identified early on as a start and moved up the ladder accordingly, or you more or less stay at the same level. Performance review is supposed to be objective and 360-degree but mostly results in back-scratching and rampant grade inflation.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Fun, smart people, collaborative environment, Jim Nondorf, John Davey, Lloyd blank, chairman of the investment banking division of the united staes of america part 2 and part three of dour
cons: long hours tough environment partners get a lot more money than u do because u r poor and what r u going to do about it

title: "GS working environment"
pros: The people are very helpful and also very fun and sociable people
cons: The hours can be a little long but that was expected.

title: "Not a place to stay"
pros: Plenty of networking and mentoring opportunities.
cons: Salary is not competitive, and promotion in middle office takes too long.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Very smart people, great tech stack and good learning opportunities
cons: Unnecessary pressure, nose brownie culture, non inclusive environment

title: "Services Division"
pros: Great friendly people, awesome collaborative environment, and relaxed culture. Had a very good experience during the summer as an intern. Every employee really wants to help you get the returning offer.
cons: There are few full time analysts compared to the amount of VP's. I think they should really do a better job attracting analysts to the division.

title: "Direct Support Professional"
pros: Provide assistance for people with disabilities, Help them interact socially in the community, Responsible for physical and emotional needs of the client
cons: unorganized schedules, time management, and data goals

title: "Trying to be a tech company"
pros: Goldman is trying their best to compete with other top tech companies, thus treating its employees really well. I love the culture and would have to say that what people say about their finance division is not necessarily true about tech division.
cons: Not a tech company, lacking is newest technology, not a Google or FB, but it has its own perks.

title: "VP"
pros: Great people who are really smart. Access to company management teams is very good, which helps in research effort. Good benefits and working conditions.
cons: Lots of hours and expectations are high. Research is not always viewed on par with other areas of the firm (I-banking and sales/trading, for example). Sometimes it's unclear what you need to do to move up.

title: "Gopher"
pros: It was pretty pretty great
cons: Actually no it was not pretty great

title: "Good Environment"
pros: They following the standard process of software development. A big team with latest technology you can use.
cons: Unfortunately, they have 18 months contract limit now. And people shifting quickly, different people have different coding style make the code hard to understand.

title: "G.S. isn't for everyone"
pros: The people you work with are incredible
cons: Long hours. Around 55-65 hours a week

title: "Good company, not for everyone"
pros: Very professional and a great name on a resume. You are working with some of the most intelligent people all in the same room. Very busy and will learn quickly.
cons: This company feeds off the young employees. They have shortened their hours but completely understand that they still put in over 50 hrs a week. Also, they are a little cocky. They believe that they are the big fish and you are lucky to be with them. Like I said, not for everyone. They only hire those that are humble, smart, and don't like to spend time outside of work.

title: "Great way to start your career"
pros: Great culture based on teamwork. You really get to work with people all around the world.
cons: Sometimes the work you might do becomes repetitive and hours could be long.

title: "Bad"
pros: I received great money and compensation
cons: There was a bad work environment

title: "Finance analyst"
pros: friendly environment, excellent knowledge development
cons: there are no cons working with goldman

title: "Great Company....but"
pros: Awesome people! EXTREMELY intelligent and pedigreed. Very open and collaborative environment. Easy to ask questions as a newbie. Good benefits and 401k plan (match 1:1 after first year). Salary is decent but not what you'd think from the premier investment banking firm. Facilities and equipment are top notch! Top level leadership is GREAT (Lloyd and Gary).
cons: Open concept desks (single long tables with 3-4 people sitting side by side (no barrier). Don't get an office until you are a Managing Director (VPs in the finance industry are dime a dozen and sit out in the open with everyone else...nothing special about being a VP at a bank. It's just another 'rank'.) Compensation for the non-revenue generating divisions isn't as competitive as it should be with other banks...especially at the analyst level (much less than $100k...which is a challenge in the NYC area). Work/life balance...they talk about it but that's about it. It's really up to you to carve out time for yourself and family (expect a MINIMUM of 10 hour days for all divisions...much more for revenue divisions, especially IBD (investment banking)). Collaborative environment can tend to stifle innovation as they like to take their time making decisions to ensure maximum buy-in.

title: "Vice President"
pros: 1. Smart People 2. Team oriented culture 3. Lot of investment in women in technology
cons: 1. Long Hours 2. Less salary to juniors then Technology companies

title: "Great Company"
pros: Great culture. Great people. Great company. Great location.
cons: Nothing that I can think of

title: "Analyst (Finance)"
pros: Great pay/salary, management is very supportive of your growth, ability to work from home on occasion (depending on your manager), prestigious name on resume, very nice building/facilities (NYC), no micromanagement, you're treated like a professional
cons: Work/life balance, extremely cutthroat environment, too focused on appearances at times, always need to be accessible via email, outdated technology, projects sometimes lack a clear direction

title: "Analysts"
pros: Very bright ppl Very smart ppl Good workers Enthusiasm Movers and shakers
cons: Very bright ppl Very bright ppl Very smart ppl Good workers Enthusiasm Movers and shakers

title: "Trading"
pros: Best culture on the street, very hardworking, no one looking over their shoulder
cons: Work life balance suffers, management can be overbearing

title: "Frustration and disappointment"
pros: good non-salary-related perks: gym, nurse, others
cons: Unhealthy work environment, disloyal and unfriendly professional competition

title: "Wall Street's best"
pros: The people are just great. There is a lot of attention to detail and company culture is superbly cooperative.
cons: Due to the hardworking nature of the job, expect long hours.

title: "Excellent place to work if you're willing to invest yourself"
pros: * Excellent compensation package & benefits * First-rate professional development opportunities * High-quality talent pool means your colleagues will be as amazing as you are * The culture is very productive and supportive, provided you find the right team
cons: * Working in-depth on proprietary systems can lead to a lack of transferrable skills when you leave * Compensation is great...but you'll work for every last penny * Leaving at 5PM is a half day

title: "Great talent, learning resource and team work culture"
pros: Very good for people who is willing to learn, work with others and desire to make impacts to the clients
cons: Fewer opportunity as you grow senior and in small offices

title: "It's ok"
pros: Great building, prestigious name, great training
cons: People stayed late for no reason, very much a face time culture

title: "Vice President"
pros: Great learning experience. At the center of the most important transactions.
cons: Grind... at all levels.

title: "Associate"
pros: Excellent culture. Very smart colleagues.
cons: Very intense environment. Tough to have a balance life if you have kids.

title: "Private Wealth Management Intern"
pros: Great experience, learn a lot, great name to have on the resume, got to do real work, good pay.
cons: long hours and have to do some secretary work.

title: "Long hours, challenging and rewarding work"
pros: Great professional development opportunities and programs. The company asks a lot of its employees, but if you put in the time and effort, you will be recognized and rewarded. The pay is generous.
cons: Long hours and a high-stress environment. While I appreciate that there is little tolerance for mistakes, the pace at which one is expected to produce perfect work can give you whiplash.

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Work with smart and motivated people. Great culture. Decent benefits. Steep learning curve (but only at first). Great name to put on your resume and a good place to start a career.
cons: Working in Operations means repetitive work and you are under-appreciated. Low salary/bonus for long hours and the cost of living in NYC metro area. Purposely limited mobility to other divisions. Comp and promotions do not seem merit based and take longer than other divisions.

title: "GS Analyst"
pros: Able to speak with employees on all different levels. Strong sense of firm values and support to help advance your career.
cons: Very big firm and access to front office and businesses are limited. Will have to sometimes throw yourself (and social life) into the job.

title: "Messed up Work-Life balance"
pros: Surrounded by great people Great benefits to emp Nice Gym location is awesome
cons: Work-life balance is terrible No great bonus People are rude, arrogant bad treatment to consultants

title: "OKAY"
pros: Good pay. A lot of good benefits and bonuses
cons: Work a lot of hours. No free time ever. Job is life

title: "Rat race. Fundamentally dysfunctional organization. (Tech Division)"
pros: Good company reputation and recognition, although continually waning. Competitive base salary. Nice gym.
cons: Close to impossible internal mobility. Long working hours is a given here as mentioned by others. Work life balance is a joke. On boarding of new employees is chaotic and unstructured. In Technology Division, there is no defined professional development in place. Skills learned are mostly proprietary since the tools used are home-grown and are not transferable elsewhere in the industry. A common internal mantra -- 'your network is your net worth' promotes a culture of exclusivity. The annual team review is unfair and frequently 'gamed' by those who are in the know. If you get an offer to work in Technology, be sure to be ask for the coveted title of 'senior engineer'. It takes years to earn this title even if one has proven prior experience.

title: "Associate"
pros: top notch people good culture team work good benefits it's tough place to work, but one of the best places to work in banking
cons: it's extremely challenging to keep work-life balance. you'll have to sacrifice a lot of your personal time..

title: "great"
pros: GS has great culture. It values diversity. There are great mobility options. They are involved in the communities and have many give back to the community options. Salaries are higher than just about anywhere.
cons: the common things that are nature of the beast, working with diverse groups from around the world sometimes causes language barriers. Frantic pace during long hours to keep up takes a hit on life/work balance

title: "Private Wealth Management Intern"
pros: Great place to learn and grow, was exposed to a lot in the financial field. Had the opportunity to network and talk to different people in the firm.
cons: Low work life balance. Intense environment, had to ask for some training and clarification. The private wealth advisors can be egotistical at times.

title: "Associate"
pros: Smart people, can have a great deal of impact, access to interesting opportunities, strong breadth of capabilities, decent compensation, challenging work.
cons: Can be bureaucratic, potential to be process-driven, depending on your group it may be more or less political, situations where there is a lack of focus and a drive to be bigger rather than best.

title: "Excellent front office leadership"
pros: Teamwork, dynamic environment, upward mobility
cons: Long hours are the standard

title: "Stressful"
pros: People, pay, benefits, customers, quality of work
cons: Sometimes they make you really feel that your lucky to be there, rather than wanted to be there.

title: "operation intern"
pros: hands on experience, good on your VC
cons: 50 hour a week, low salary

title: "Goldman Analyst"
pros: Probably stating the obvious, but the pay is great. I also really like the people I work with, which makes the hours easier. Supervisors take an interest in you, and the other analysts have become some of my best friends.
cons: Hours are long. Especially coming in at the intro level, you have to be prepared to give them everything you have. Competitive atmosphere might be a con for some. I really like the people I work with, but it's not exactly a diverse group—I can imagine that someone that doesn't "fit the mold" wouldn't feel the same way.

title: "Associate"
pros: Nice people to work with, team work is the most important always
cons: Big firm, sometimes too much paperwork

title: "Great Opportunity"
pros: The people are brilliant. The environment is surreal; precision and accuracy dominate every facet of life. As a result, you will grow and improve in all areas. Also, the perks were pretty sweet...
cons: 17 hour days. The work I did was mostly inputting and felt like the right computer program could easily take over my job.

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Culture and people, training in New York City is a great experience, lots of opportunities to meet people in different divisions
cons: Operations is tedious, boring, and for most a dead-end career. The organization is not actually flat and it is not a meritocracy when you work in the federation.

title: "GS is a competitive, rewarding firm"
pros: Working with some of the most intelligent people in business, handsome compensation, strong research division, opportunities for professional development
cons: There is a competitive environment, tough work/life balance, many late nights in the office and unanticipated projects from associates

title: "Operations Analyst - SLC Review"
pros: Smart intelligent people, Awesome firm perks, Name recognition, Organized training, Amazing culture
cons: Analysts have to go through 3-4 years before promotion, regardless of their responsibilities. Some managers are not great with people. 50 hours/wk minimum. Low pay. Salt Lake City location isn't ideal for young, non-LDS professionals

title: "Strong employees, disorganized management in Federation"
pros: Smart employees, occasional engaging work that affects strategy. Heavy emphasis on teamwork that is usually helpful to quality of work and experience of employees.
cons: Management is generally poor at allocating work equitably (too much for some, too little for most). Politicking is common especially among junior middle management. Has become a culture of checkers checking checkers.

title: "Associate"
pros: Great environment for highly motivated people looking to work in a high energy fast paced environment.
cons: You have to put in lots of hours and deliver to stay in the game.

title: "Good learning opportunity"
pros: Smart people, team work, opportunities to learn, dynamic
cons: Structured, regulation, some bureaucracy and politics

title: "Investment Banking Associate"
pros: Some of the best and brightest people that you will ever have an opportunity to work with. Very challenging and thought provoking work as well.
cons: There is no work-life balance. Large amounts of sacrifice for the professional gains that you will realize for your career.

title: "Good Place to Work"
pros: Access to some of the most exciting cmoopanies
cons: long hours. Little consideration for work life balance

title: "Operations"
pros: They are very control focused and take great measures to ensure nothing falls through the cracks.
cons: Overwork and underpay the operations team - especially at the associate level.

title: "Incredible"
pros: Career development, networking opportunities, fast paced culture! Very bright and talented people. Market and client demands keep you on your toes.
cons: No cons that I've experienced so far. Only thing maybe is that it is slow to adapt new technology

title: "Risk Associate"
pros: Very challenging learning new things everyday Coworkers are all very smart and hard working
cons: Long hours and there is very little work life balance Less focus on one area and attention is too diversified

title: "Inspiring work"
pros: Inspiring work Great coworkers Company / program recognition
cons: Harsh deadlines Work on and off the clock

title: "Internal Audit Associate"
pros: More flexibility then most other financial service careers. Not extremely mentally taxing. Ability to learn about many areas within the company.
cons: Pretty much back of the back of the back of the back office. The function to assess risk is important, but most other areas of the company could care less. The work is not stimulating or interesting.

title: "Great company to work for"
pros: Excellent company culture that engenders hard work, a competitive environment and superior performance. Great benefits including performance-based bonuses and great retirement matching.
cons: While GS makes a point to try to keep a good work/life balance, the environment is still very demanding, with plenty of last-minute demands. Because of the competitive culture you always have a sense of being disposable.

title: "associate"
pros: good place to work and grow
cons: work life balance is not great

title: "Technology VP"
pros: Nice location in Jersey city and Downtown NYC. Pay is decent, though a bit low these days compared to other financial firms. Still, compared to other industries, it is good.
cons: A lot of ego and politics. Most of the truly talented technology people have left to join other banks.

title: "Vice President"
pros: smart people, team oriented culture,competitive environment
cons: Since 2008, there has been too much focus on cost cutting. Divisions such as Technology and Operations are considered as cost center and a lot of jobs are relocated to low cost areas such as Bangalore and Salt Lake City.

title: "Good Company and lots to learn!"
pros: - Lots of technology to play around with - Very smart people all around you -Company culture is good, with many one on one meetings to discuss career options -Interesting work, you get to see the users of your product using it happily!
cons: -Big organisation, it can get difficult to climb up the corporate ladder -Technology is not the business of this company

title: "Goldman Sachs"
pros: Intelligent people, driven, hard work, access to senior management, in building gym and health center, live deals often (good deal flow)
cons: Long hours, poor work life balance, unexpected calls from client or managers to do something last minute, not efficient

title: "Large bank"
pros: Good career development in the long run. Company encourages internal mobility. Senior employees are respected by the company. Has a very strong technical team
cons: Has a complicated hierarchical system. The company titles are lower compared to other banks. People have to work hard for years for promotion.

title: "Goldman Sachs Security Operations"
pros: Get a chance to deal with high value, interesting transactions
cons: Long hours, little appreciation, high turnover,

title: "IBD analyst"
pros: Great place to start your career Better mentorship and culture than other banks Opens up a ton of opportunities.
cons: Lots of hours - same as all firms

title: "Sales & Trading Analyst"
pros: The people. Everyone brings their "A" game to work everyday and it certainly makes it an interesting place to work.
cons: It can be exhausting as an analyst. I think many people get burnt out.

title: "Quantitative analyst"
pros: Great place. Definitely pays well based on the talent. Highly competitive work place and very diverse in nature
cons: as i mentioned it is highly competitive and banking business is not appealing any more with the regulators

title: "Intense"
pros: Good and smart people with excellent sales skills
cons: Intense internship experience and expected to always be networking

title: "Friendly environment and great people to learn from!"
pros: everyone was very eager to help the intern class do a great job
cons: hours can be unpredictable sometimes

title: "Analyst"
pros: I love how great management is
cons: Sometimes things are very manual and operational

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Great people, great hours, great opportunities
cons: average pay, firm is very careful about employees using social media

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: The gym is beautiful, they have work out clothes for you to use there. Very good benefits. Lots of locations to choose from.
cons: Very competitive environment, long hours, repetitive work. Need to put in a lot of years to think about moving to a different department.

title: "Can be a great place to work, but is hit or miss depending on the team"
pros: Flexible work arrangements, gym in building, flat organization, mobility
cons: Long hours, low pay, lacking diversity and not inclusive

title: "Great Experience"
pros: Given a lot of opportunity to contribute to group work, and really dive into the materials, people are very intelligent, competitive and usually good all-around people
cons: work life balance is rough and you have to be available at any point, not always time for help, review and learning because people are always busy

title: "Good experience, lots of hours though"
pros: Met a trader willing to teach me the ins and outs making the experience worthwhile
cons: high stress, hours. Not too bad at first but it wears on you.

title: "Excellent Employer!"
pros: Great pay, supportive culture, nice people.
cons: Long hours, FaceTime valued, some terrible senior managers

title: "Work life"
pros: Good place to work for with intense hour
cons: Work life balance can be challenging

title: "Mediocre"
pros: I guess one pro would be that the facilities at the HQ office in nyc are nice. Mainly b/c the building is new.
cons: Lots of turnover especially in the departments that matter. Most people think they're the smartest person on the floor which doesn't make for a collaborative environment.

title: "Team Lead"
pros: Goldman has a lot of smart, hard-working individuals. It cares A LOT about diversity, enough to detriment it's businesses.
cons: Work/life balance is not a thing there. They work you and work you. Loosen the purse strings and provide a few more employees to ease the balance.

title: "Great entry level job!"
pros: The work environment is professional, yet laid back given the location. The firm hires extremely bright individuals from diverse backgrounds. The office is growing fast, which means that there will be many opportunities for upward mobility in the years to come.
cons: Unfortunately, the stereotype of long hours is true, but the office has been working to improve flexibility. The analyst program is very structured, and does not allow for promotions in the first 3 years.

title: "Great Culture"
pros: Very hard working coworkers. Always learning and being pushed to succeed.
cons: Long hours. Sometimes doing mindless work.

title: "Great internship"
pros: Great culture, smart people, fun community
cons: Long hours, not a lot of work from home flexibility

title: "Work/Life balance"
pros: Excellent Benefits, good training, talented employees.
cons: Cutthroat competitive culture is not for everyone.

title: "Thrilling ambition, culture of visibility"
pros: You're working with the best. It's a rare occasion to find someone here who is only average.
cons: Being a busybody and an attention hog is actively encouraged...the company term is "posting"

title: "Pros and Cons"
pros: "Nicest sharks you'll ever meet" - if you're great, you can move up quick, and get recognized
cons: Technology team can be difficult to work with, and Federation not terribly bright

title: "Great Place"
pros: Some of the brightest people work alongside you. the management is very democratic. Lot of paid time off. Some of the brightest people work alongside you. the management is very democratic. Lot of paid time off.
cons: Work hours can be very very long, especially the unpredictability of work hours. Work hours can be very very long, especially the unpredictability of work hours.

title: "Great people"
pros: Everyone is smart and passionate.
cons: Internship didn't account for support duties that came with the full time position.

title: "Fun and challenging"
pros: great exposure to front office trading desks
cons: Tech team is thin, lots of middle management

title: "Summer Analyst"
pros: Emphasis on people, quality real world experience and training
cons: There are no cons to share

title: "Culture"
pros: The culture creates success for the people at Goldman. The culture is due in largely to the senior level management at the firm and also the size of the firm.
cons: There are no downsides to Goldman.

title: "Great team with smartest people"
pros: Full responsibility of project, teammates are smart and nice, working on very interesting projects, great learning opportunity and career development
cons: hours is a bit long, but most are from peer pressure

title: "Technology Summer Analyst"
pros: Fast-paced, great structure intern projects, lots of mentorship
cons: Not enough tech intern events, some business units are more technical than others

title: "Analyst"
pros: Great name, big firm and great company culture
cons: long working hours; developer is not revenue maker, feel like secondary

title: "Sales and Trading"
pros: Great atmosphere with top colleagues.
cons: Work-life balance isn't the best; it has to be a big part of your life.

title: "Managing Director"
pros: Fast pace, high intensity, extremely talented employees at all levels
cons: Work life balance. Performance expectations stretching the limits by a day

title: "Equity Research Analyst"
pros: Good place to start career, lots of talented people, very interesting job with opportunity to grow if you do well.
cons: Firm culture is very rigid, either you fit in or you don't. Also lack of interest by senior people in becoming mentors for junior analysts.

title: "Superstars"
pros: Folks there work extremely hard, and are dedicated. During a particularly tough deal, we'd start a conference call at 6 pm, break for dinner, and pick back up at home at 10 pm until 2 am. But it was fun. Everyone is ambitious, and it was a great environment to be in.
cons: It's only a con if you don't want to work hard and dedicate yourself to your career. If not, it's a hard place to work.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Very collaborative environment, good leadership, people are very focused on delivering high quality results
cons: Suffers from problems of a large organization which is difficulties to make decisions and lots of communication overhead

title: "Ok place"
pros: Good pay, good benefits, fun work.
cons: long hours and siloed management

title: "More than just a job, it becomes your life."
pros: As everyone here as already stated, you are working with the most talented and brilliant people. Almost everyone is smart and driven, and work very hard. You will get to learn a lot, it is a great learning opportunity and this will advance your career in the industry faster than other firms. The firm is great at developing a career track for you and really is good at career and people development. Lot's of training opportunities and GS Talk.
cons: Be prepared to sacrifice your personal life and health. Again, it's true, very long hours. The lack of work/life balance is not something senior management is addressing. For the low pay, it is really not worth it and causing a very high turnover at the firm. Management has been aware but are not doing enough if anything at all to address this. If you want to kiss your relationships goodbye, lose sleep and peace of mind, sacrifice your health all to work here for little pay, work here. There are trade-offs, you will learn a lot and be at the top of your game. On the other hand, is it worth the burnout? I am still not sure.

title: "Great company"
pros: Talented employees who care about professional development. Ambitious and driven.
cons: Hours can be tough and can take getting used to.

title: "Wonderful employer"
pros: Excellent perks for employees in all aspects
cons: Hectic Job hours exceeding regular work hours

title: "Tough to maintain work-life balance"
pros: Ample opportunities to learn new things. Work with a lot of hard-working, bright people. If you're hardworking individual with plenty of personal time to spare on work, you can do really well here.
cons: From my personal experience, relative to the work you do the comp isn't high despite common sentiment about this company. Depending on the group you're in things get political, hard to advance your carer if you don't know the right people. If you want to move up in the ladder, you have to forget about your personal life and ensure that you work nights and weekends. Plus you need to ensure that the upper management is aware your personal sacrifices.

title: "Big learning curve, but excellent work environment"
pros: I enjoy learning from everyone around me. Each employee brings a large amount of knowledge and experience.
cons: Longer working hours than competitors

title: "culture"
pros: great culture. teamwork. highly professional.
cons: big institution. turnover rate high.

title: "Trader"
pros: People are very smart and competitive, learning quite a lot
cons: Sometimes the environment is too stressful.

title: "Prestigious, lower than expected pay, boring job"
pros: - In Operations at least, work-life balance is reasonable - Benefits are great, including in-office perks - Great to have the brand on resume
cons: - A high school student could do the job; no skills are required and no skills are learned - Career path and salary increases are very rigid, not a meritocratic culture - Very limited mobility opportunities, except within same subdivision (which means doing relatively the same job) - Bonuses are almost non-existent outside of the front-office, and salary is low - Hierarchical culture; your opinion is valued depending on your level

title: "Great"
pros: Great intern pay about 15K for 10 weeks
cons: Lots of hours a week

title: "Summer Intern"
pros: The training program is very rigorous and the feedback system really helps you grow in 10 weeks.
cons: Long hours - if you are really interested in Finance, and would want to spend at least 2-3 years in the industry, the it might be a good choice.

title: "Internship Experience"
pros: Provided the good training. Had many chances to network with many senior leaders
cons: Not sure whether its intern/Analyst's compensation is competitive enough

title: "Great place to work"
pros: helpful and friendly people, great pay
cons: nothing major, no free food

title: "Intern"
pros: Your managers and team are truly focused on your professional development You receive actionable feedback throughout the summer The internship program is well-organized
cons: There is a huge, and at times inhibiting, priority on presentation and attention to detail for internal material. The hours are usually worse than comparable jobs at other banks. There is a culture that encourages meeting proliferation which takes up significant time without providing much value add.

title: "great job with an unbeatable brand reputation"
pros: Smart people Great comp Bragging rights for life
cons: Say good bye to your family

title: "Pretty much what you'd expect"
pros: They let even the interns get working immediately so you gets lots of hangs on experience, even if it is with Slang. They have a large and well practiced internship program so there's no difficulty in dealing with HR and there's lot of events and stuff.
cons: The job can be a bit tedious and the experience seems to very greatly depending on your team. The workforce seems to skew a bit older but everyone is incredibly friendly so its still a pleasant work environment. Also, Slang is proprietary and there's a good chance you'll use it so that knowledge isn't very useful elsewhere.

title: "Good starting point"
pros: Great benefits including medical dental vision etc, smart people, professional environment, decent pay. Management is generally well informed, involved in day to day operations.
cons: You will work a lot of hours. 50 hours is the expected minimum, with some people working 70 plus. Upper management and mid level often have different ideas of changes that are needed.

title: "Summer Analyst"
pros: Great people, great culture and work environment.
cons: Definitely have to work long hours

title: "Good People"
pros: Very smart people. Working on top projects with the ability to see some of the most relevant work happening at the moment.
cons: Long hours. Grind can be very tough. There can be some internal politicking and everyone gets highly cut throat at times.

title: "Administrative assistant"
pros: Gym, medical office, building estheticaly pleasing. One can break the ceiling and move up from an admin position if they desire to do so
cons: Each department has its own way of managing its infrastructure and its employees. Some other better than other. Information is release on need to know basis which is frustrating if you want succeed. Research the group where you are applying before you accept your offer

title: "Good place to work"
pros: Smart people; Strong technology organization; Plenty of learning opportunities; Great place to start your career out of school due to strong intern and new analyst programs; looks great on your resume
cons: very political; not enough to just be good at your job - you need someone senior to push your career forward; technology organization is undergoing a radical change - not necessarily for the better; compensation model deteriorated

title: "Great Company"
pros: room for growth, opportunities and benefits
cons: Work hard and long hours but worth it!

title: "Analyst Developer I"
pros: Good exposure given to freshers. The hierarchy structure is good. Mentors are available to help.
cons: Long working hours and busy schedule.

title: "Great company but needs change"
pros: Good teamwork and overall smart people
cons: Not adapting to changes in market. People leaving for competition

title: "Private Wealth Management Summer Analyst"
pros: The company culture is outstanding, everyone you work with is friendly and extremely helpful
cons: I did not experience any cons during my employment

title: "Technical analyst"
pros: Good environment. Good people, good work. Everyone works hard. Work from home.
cons: Some teams with ridiculous hours. They want everyone to focus on growth development. Not enough pay.

title: "A cult, but a very well-paying cult."
pros: Very, very smart and ambitious co-workers. You'll be amazed at how hard you can work.
cons: A very passive-aggressive culture that strongly enforces conformity to the corporate culture.

title: "The times they are a changin'"
pros: Cache of company name. Smart people. Dynamic businesses. Opportunity for variety of roles over the course of years. Nice buildings in all major financial centers
cons: Excessive focus on cost cutting. Offshoring is too powerful an aphrodisiac for managers who are not able to drive value through innovation.

title: "Finance Division"
pros: Smart, diverse people. Great environment to learn. High performers get more interesting and challenging work
cons: Regional office will never garner the same respect as New York. More interesting and challenging work doesn't mean better pay at lower levels.

title: "Contingent Worker"
pros: The people are fantastic; motivated, outgoing, and intelligent.
cons: They treat contingent workers badly. Terrible hourly wage, 60 hours a week routinely, dull backoffice work, with little respect or mobility given to people in contingent positions. To give perspective, I left the FX ICON team to become VP of machine learning at a competitive firm, so experience or competency was not an issue.They are genuinely treated poorly.

title: "Executive Assistant"
pros: excellent place to work, dynamic and intelligent people all around you.
cons: I worked very long hours for the gentleman I worked for.

title: "analyst"
pros: good company, nice food service, nice building
cons: Aggressive, fast pace, not nice, sometimes too strict

title: "Worked for over a decade. Never looked to work elsewhere"
pros: I have been working here at GS for over a decade and really enjoy my work as a technologist. I get to work on a lot of interesting platforms and have not even written a resume. The pay is excellent. The firm is in the direction of creating a work environment similar to tech companies. I do telecommute mostly a day per week, and it helps immensely with managing my other-than-work-life. Overall, I do recommend GS to technologists, depending on your interests.
cons: Given its a bank with stringent regulations, the work does come with a lot of scrutiny unlike tech companies where developers are quite relaxed and probably that leads to less stress. The working hours depends on the kind of work, and dedication. I would definitely say its not for those looking for 9-5 or staring at their watch to go home. I don't recall anyone asking me to stay back against my wish, but I do work long hours, as it helps me the work and of course my career.

title: "Great place for money but not keeping your skills"
pros: pays more than most and there are plenty of classes to take to teach you new skills. The insurance is also pretty great.
cons: not an environment to practice your skill-set. Although you are encouraged to learn as much as possible, there is no environment to practice anything that you learn. everything is calculated for cost so there is no budget for real computer equipment or virtual machines to practice anything.

title: "Operations"
pros: Professional development, challenging, strong culture, industry leader
cons: work life balance, limited career potential in Utah

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Super smart people, very well managed company, a leader in its industry where you will never be bored and always be challenged.
cons: Very competitive as you would expect from a place like this. Very difficult to relax and think about problem domain without worrying about internal competition. Don't expect to feel like you are changing the world unless you are in love with finance.

title: "Analyst"
pros: The firm culture is very supportative and the collegues are very smart. Good for starting a career.
cons: The workload is heavy and need to spend a lot of time doing support. The work pressure is a little high.

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Incredibly smart people. Internal mobility.
cons: Work is never good enough

title: "Admin"
pros: Goldman allows you every tool you need to achieve your career goals
cons: Goldman is not diverse and really needs to start making that more of a priority. They are missing untapped potential for the company to grow

title: "Summer Analyst"
pros: Nice people, Good Work Experience
cons: Very Long Hours - Therefore the Salary on an hourly basis is pretty weak. Not a formal training program by any means. 14 hour days.

title: "Vice President"
pros: Great colleagues work together well in a friendly atmosphere. I really enjoyed my time at Goldman and learned a ton. I would highly recommend it.
cons: The work is difficult and time consuming. You have to work late at night and on the weekends. The job can interfere with your personal life.

title: "Analyst"
pros: There is a lot of brilliant people working for Goldman Sachs. You will learn more in a very short period of time than you likely would at other companies. There is also opportunity for advancement in a relatively short period of time if you perform.
cons: Because the company is so large, you get placed in a very specific area of work. You become a subject matter expert, but can be stuck doing the same type of work frequently. It is also a demanding work environment. It is definitely not a 40 hour a week job if that is what you are looking for.

title: "great firm, good benefits"
pros: prestigious, good pay, was a great firm to work with to start career off but definitely has its drawbacks as seen below.
cons: There was a lot of red tape and bureaucracy that got in the way of getting things done and culture can be described as up or out, you perform you get out. that's how contracts were designed as well.

title: "Very warm, tech doesn't have the same hours that you hear about in the paper. 8-530 is average."
pros: Great people, very smart co-workers. Working on projects that will be used by people in real time. Great mobility opportunities.
cons: Doesn't have the same perks as other tech companies, ie free food, game rooms, etc.

title: "Tech - Study up and go to a tech company or even startup"
pros: Best of the big investment banks - IT peers at other investment banks may be envious. Great if you need a visa. Work from home is handy. Unlimited sick days are nice. Hours are getting better. Offices in both New Jersey and New York City (and globally) depending on your situation. Internal mobility and location switching not difficult. Health insurance and 401k packages are top-notch.
cons: Not a tech culture. Very corporate. Work really hard (working smart is discouraged for job security reasons) for minimal reward. Make sure you really believe in the mission of what you are doing. Massive turnover in tech - the perks and compensation that are still left are being scaled back to improve the stock price. May be uncompetitive with other industries. Tech practices and code are obsolete (but slowly getting better). You may be thrown into the fire to maintain legacy systems with almost no documentation. Ensure you are keeping your skill set up to date. In many tech teams, morale is really low. Management may be only concerned about their career progress and you may not receive credit for work you have done. You are compensated mainly on how much money your project, business unit, and the overall company brings in - make sure to choose the right projects and business unit. Beware that compensation may not be based on merit.

title: "Excellent company to work"
pros: Professional people Highly motivational Good Pay
cons: Demanding job. Long work hrs

title: "Great company"
pros: Competitive pay/benefits, very intelligent personnel and great culture! Outstanding reputation. Consistently solid financial performance. Global company so global opportunities and very diverse workforce.
cons: Work / life balance can be better.

title: "Intern"
pros: Great learning opportunities. Employees invest in your personal development and allow for a great deal of responsibility of work.
cons: Hours are as advertised (quite long)

title: "Overworked understaffed"
pros: Great company finically in the world banking market

title: "Vice President"

cons: Working hour is generally long and you are expected to work under pressure. It is not easy to achieve work life balance.

title: "If you're looking for a job in tech and iffy about working at a financial institution, try it out."

title: "Associate"

title: "Overall great people"

title: "If you are not a culture fit, it shows."

cons: My manager didn't care too much about my own growth. She was a terrible boss and was not a good advisor. You have to look out for yourself a lot. And people will smile in your face but give you crappy anonymous feedback.

title: "IMD Review"

cons: Was surprised at the total pay package, the focus definitely seemed to be more on the intangible aspects of working there rather than the cash.

title: "Goldman Sachs"

title: "Takes the right type of person...."

title: "Operation Analyst"
pros: GS culture is great. People are hard working and smart. Team work is important here. Overall, I love working at Goldman. It is rewarding.

title: "VP"

While management seemingly promote innovation, but they limit innovation at times by controlling what people should develop and sharing of ideas (especially related to enterprise platform) is sometimes tightly controlled.

title: "GS"
pros: Teamwork, learning opportunities, client service

title: "Great place to work for!!"

cons: 60-70 hours a week is normal and expected to be on-call when not in the office. Consensus driven environment. Rarely is anyone allowed to make decision without consulting the global team.

The diversity networks provides ample opportunities to build relations and to understand the culture.
cons: These cons are very team specific - there could be long working hours due to shortage of staff. Interest to work on different kind of projects may not be heard. Lots of proprietary technology which does not get valued a lot in the market. Compensation in the recent past has not been good.

title: "Legacy Code Base, Loaded with Technical Debt"
pros: Work and live in the city. Most of the IT Managers are nice and very professional. Great Benefits. You'll learn a professional work culture that will last throughout your career.
cons: The bonus comp structure, and uncertainty surrounding it, is used by management to underpay employees. I was paid 15% under-market during my time there, using this underhanded negotiating tool. The code base is OLD and as more people leave, it's deteriorating, most of the work is debugging rather than new dev work--this is true across the board, no position is immune. 'diversity' has created Cultural/Caste system issues, and language barriers throughout Tech. If you think IT people are poor explainers, wait until you have to understand the system via broken English.

title: "Smart people"

title: "Sweat Shop culture in technology"
pros: Good on resume Good Benefits and meeting some talented folks
cons: constant cost cutting initiatives. Goldman technology feels they are great in technology and different than other firms.Surprisingly these comments only come from people who have never worked outside the firm. Reality is that they are not really different and in fact their technology is very out dated resulting in hard work for people and difficult release cycle. Everyone I meet has a constant fear of layoffs. They are just hanging in there till the inevitable layoffs happens Not a good option for 10+ years experience laterals.Most would be used for layoffs bucket or lower ratings in appraisal cycle Benefits that used to great are declining every year.health benefits premiums and deductible has increased a lot No work from home even for genuine cases All in all not worth the hard work you put in. Better compensation/work life balance outside Technology is on constant cost cutting. Form outsourcing to below average compensation to extra works hours, they are master of squeezing employees for profits. There Idea is hire only college graduates and lay off people above 35. It has a 20-20 un official rule. Be prepared to work 20% more on 20% less salary than competitors. They will really keep an eye on you on every small things like when you come to office,how may breaks you take etc. Micro Management to the core Everyone I meet has a constant fear of layoffs. They are just hanging in there till the inevitable layoffs happens Not a good option for 10+ years experience laterals.Most would be used for layoffs bucket or lower ratings in appraisal cycle Benefits that used to great are declining every year.health benefits premiums and deductible has increased a lot No work from home even for genuine cases All in all not worth the hard work you put in. Better compensation/work life balance outside

title: "Goldman Sachs"

title: "Standard large company plus a little bit of rep"

My first group was with a group of very (not necessarily relaxed, but certainly not uptight) people. Great colleagues, smart, motivated. Interesting work, if you're into that sort of thing (I was in Technology).
cons: Worked at a second group -- more business facing but to be honest I enjoyed the work much less. A lot more focus on minor details that add little value but "look good". A lot more focused on getting things done, than getting things done right.

title: "Good Company"
pros: Good Salary, good environment, good location, good team, too many smart people.
cons: People are so busy, no too much time for your personal life.

title: "You can have a great career, if you like to work ALOT"
pros: Great benefits, great career path if you are motivated. Pay is okay depending on the year. Some management is very good and listens to their employees. If you want lots of new opportunity, it is yours, you just have to ask. If you want a career in the investment banking industry, this is the place. You just have to remember, just because the office is in SLC it doesn't mean less effort or time in the office. In fact, I would say it is more. Also, if you are having problems in your life, they will really help you out, but you have to ask them. If you are having personal issues, they will literally bend over backwards to help you. I knew a guy who got in a terrible accident while on vacation in Mexico and had to be life flighted to the US. Needless to say it was an expensive trip. GS took care of the whole thing. He didn't have to do anything. Also their maternity leave is KILLER. No one can touch it (4 months FULL Pay).
cons: Terrible work life balance. I literally worked minimum 50 hours a week for almost 8 years (on slow weeks). And I was not even vice president (didn't want it, could not devote any more time). Also, there are some really awful managers that they keep around even though they violate company policies (favoritism). They really will just work you to death or a heart attack (or divorce) if you let them. It is all about face time (at least in my division). They would say it wasn't, but if you left "early" (less than 50 hours) people (and managers) would make comments, even if you were AWESOME and super efficient at your job. They didn't care. It was like a contest who could stay the longest, and even then that wasn't good enough.

title: "Amazing Company"
pros: Pros for working for Goldman Sachs were the benefits. Including profit sharing, parental leave for both male and female employees. Vacation benefits as well were nice. Travel cost were fully compensated
cons: Cons to the job were long hours and lots of travel in my position. Along with stress of the job, fast paced atmosphere.

title: "Vice President, Foreign Exchange Sales"
pros: Smart people, great benefits, big bonuses for jobs well done. Great prestige. Easy to find any other job in the industry if you've worked for Goldman.
cons: Lots of politics. very competitive dog eat dog. Long hours.

title: "Associate"
pros: Benefits are superb. Firm provides great opportunity for retirement investment
cons: Work life balance needs to be enforced more

title: "Senior Analyst in Technology"
pros: prestige that comes with the name good on resume people 'think' you make tons of money you don't need to explain where you work once you just say the name
cons: The prestige is really just a facade- If you work on their proprietary programming language - secdb/slang, get the hell out as soon as you can. you will be behind in mainstream technology, and you won't be marketable outside the company very soon. Once recruiter said there are some companies out there who simply won't interview any ex-goldman employees as they are just behind in technological skills, and there is a 'bad' reputation for ex-gs people you do NOT make tons of money here unless you are the exceptional 1%. most people would LOVE to make the avg gs salary - 350K or 400K as advertised in wall st, but it's extremely top heavy. Go to other hedgefunds who could easily pay much more. GS is very savvy when it comes to saving/making money, and they won't spend more money to keep you happy- but just enough so you don't leave. The culture is all about facade--- it's very superficial and no one trusts anyone. because of this 360 degree 'review' system they have, everyone pretends to be nice to everyone but when it comes to review, they can always backstab you because only a few people can get the high marks. When I left, there was a backlog of exit interviews up to 3 months - and another colleague of mine who left 1 month after me said he had to wait 6 months for his exit interview. In other words, there is a mass exodus happening in technology. If you are in technology, you are considered a 'cost center' and will NOT be treated the same way biz side folks are treated (traders, sales, strats). What I see in GS is all these cost center people, Tech, Ops, Infra, end up trying to suck up to the business folks, empowering them to act rudely as they have the ultimate say in everything. Expect an extremely political environment. Either you get into the fraternity or you are out. Since 2008, there hasn't really been a 'golden year' where everyone was happy with their compensation. GS would use 3 factors to determine your comp - your performance, company performance, market benchmark ---- and they would also find that one factor to tell you why your comp is not gonna be stellar this year. If you are a technologist fresh out of college, I would totally recommend you to go into startup space and that way you would learn so much more. If you are a lateral hire from a tech industry, don't come to GS. If you are lateral hire from another finance industry, GS may be better than other big banks.. but if your objective is to maximize your salary, I would recommend a hedgefund space instead.

title: "Analyst"
pros: Competitive environment - stimulating, smart employees. Culture that is conducive to learning, and friendly co-workers.
cons: Horrible work life balance, but everyone knows that when they sign up. Don't take a job here unless you understand how long the hours are going to be.

title: "Great Company ... but not for everyone"
pros: I worked in the Technology division for 5 years. 1. I worked in the technology division of Goldman Sachs and i admire the smart people and technical courage of the company. The company truly believes in technology and is not afraid to build (and invest) in home grown products where all financial companies just live on the mercy of vendors and system integrator. You will be surprised at the scale and complexity of technical projects executed by Goldman on their own without the involvement of any vendor or service integrator. 2. They take great pride and ownership in their work. The company outsources very little and products receive great attention from everyone. Managers pay great attention to detail. Goldman definitely seeks perfection in what they do.
cons: 1. Get used to executive worship culture. Goldman have MDs and Partners and they are living Gods in the corridors. This create a culture of sycophancy and executive pleasing. I have seen people spend their days and nights not on working but pleasing. 2. Very New York Centered. New York is the absolute power center and the managers there will share nothing with anyone else (even with other US cities). In other cities you don't have an authority to do anything without triple New York approval. All important projects are completely controlled out of NY and if you are in other locations you will find that its hard to grow. (or even breathe). 3. Its a company which encourages a culture where people work 20 hours a day. It's common to see colleagues work nonstop from 6:30 AM to Midnight. 4. Organizational Arrogance: Management has very firm views on what needs to be done and you have little or no voice. It takes many years of service for anyone to have a voice in the company. Questioning or disagreement almost always is a career limiting (or ending) move. This arrogance leads to a culture where people spend their entire culture building mega personas, and hyper images of themselves. Its a culture where snobbery thrive. 5. Very rigid organizational rules: Goldman follows lots of processes and governance models around IT. These models are so rigid that even small tasks can take many months of back and forth wrangling between IT and governance teams. This is why executing even small projects takes 10 times the effort it would take in a easy going organization.

You'll find data replicated like crazy all over the place. 60% of the tech stack is internal. Impossible to google a solution to something you get stuck in.

Better compensation/work life balance outside The whole firm is pushing toward outsourcing to save money. It has a 20-20 rule. title: "A good starter job.   A technologists view of GS."
pros: Above average pay. Training that you won't get anywhere else on a variety of technical and nontechnical topics. Benefits are very good. People are smart.
cons: In the technology division of Goldman, they have racked up tremendous technical debt. That debt needs to be repayed and the current work reflects that. Plan on spending a lot of time doing technical support and learning a lot of code that is not well-documented. Plan on fixing bugs and doing a lot of "uplift" work. If you are lucky, you may get to do some new development - but probably not for a few years. Goldman technology has had a lot of attrition the past 2 or 3 years - people getting fed up with the status quo. Management doesn't appear to be doing much about it. Their new strategy seems to be to drive their senior engineers out of the organization and replace them with younger, low-cost engineers that they can work to death and hold a work visa over their heads. Goldman hasn't had a really good year income-wise, since 2009. When you are interviewing, they will sell the "bonus" as a significant part of your total compensation. But, the bonus is directly related to the firms earnings for the year and less related to the great work you did that year. You could be a super hero engineer one year, but if the firm did badly that year, plan on a small bonus. On the other hand, you could have a less than stellar year with the firm performing well, and get a good bonus. My experience was that I got a good bonus a couple of years and a less-than-inspiring bonus on the other years. They talk a good talk about work-life balance, making you believe that is part of the corporate culture. Don't believe it. Once you get to the VP level and above, you will need to sell your soul to GS to continue to move up the corporate ladder. If you don't care about having a life outside of work and your family is a low priority, you will do very well at GS. Also be sure that you have very good skills playing "corporate games" and politics as you move up the ladder. Those skills become very important. If you are a good smoozer, you will do well. If not, plan on being treated badly enough that you will choose to leave on your own. Goldman rarely fires people. Their strategy is to level off your salary and stop paying you bonuses, until you leave on your own. It's a lot cleaner that way. No lawsuits to worry about for wrongful firing. GS is always looking to "manage risk", even when it comes to their people. Finally, the most important thing. Make sure you have a great relationshsip with your direct manager. GS does a "360 degree review", but 350 of those degrees are the opinion of your direct manager. Even if 15 of your peers think you are a superstar, you will not got a good ranking, if your direct manager thinks you are lacking. By the way, a poor ranking against your peers translates into getting passed over for a bonus. Summary - Join GS right out of college, work 4 or 5 years, get trained, get some experience, get GS on your resume and get out. A smart strategy for the smart engineer.

cons: Like any large corporation, the political landscape dictates whether or not you're part of the inner circle. Play the game otherwise you won't last long.

title: "Operations Division"
pros: Goldman does a great job of finding smart, talented, driven people. The open culture makes it so that you can speak to people at all different levels--vice presidents, managing directors, etc--and your opinion is given considerable weight, no matter your title.
cons: Very long working hours and zero career development in the operations division. Great people leave the firm because they become frustrated by the lack of professional development.

title: "Goldman used to be a great place to work, but it's on the down turn"
pros: perks flexible working arrangement benefits brand name vacation policy paternity/maternity leave
cons: limited personal growth few promotion opportunities work-life balance

title: "Analyst"
pros: Smart people to work with
cons: Future set out in stone, no way around the corporate levels

title: "Excellent Place to Launch a Career"
pros: Flat organization with great great people, lots of access to senior management, fast-paced and challenging work environment ensures you'll never be bored, lots of opportunity to work on different things and transfer to different departments (if you're a high performer) & outstanding benefits. Goldman really puts a lot of emphasis on their people, in developing them and having an open environment that's conducive to learning & progress.
cons: SLC office is growing so rapidly there are some growing pains, it can feel like a very new/transitional type of company at times and there can be kinks in management and organizational structure (ie an ill-defined job role) that can add a lot of stress at times. Also, salary is ridiculously low. I don't care what they claim the SLC market is paying, it's way low. It seems like the other banks in town are raising salaries to compete with GS in the recruiting game though, and plenty of people quit to jump ship so perhaps with time the market will force salaries higher. That said, the benefits package is amazing!!!

title: "Great Place"
pros: Good culture. Great vision and management
cons: Too much institutional lethargy. Lots of resistance to change

title: "Vice President"

title: "Good place to work"
pros: This place pays well and is well managed

title: "Working at goldman sachs is great !"

title: "Great company"

title: "Neutral"

title: "Goldman Sachs is a great place to work right out of college in order to get a great financial skill set."

title: "Great experience"

cons: The culture might be a bit too strict depending on the group and division. You have to go through some (sometimes) annoying training

title: "Company provides a platform for an amazing career."
pros: Incredible collection of smart, driven hard working people. Company culture is a meritocracy, allowing anyone to succeed who has what it takes, plus a bit of luck helps too.
cons: Very intense culture which can take a toll on your personal life. Huge time commitment.

title: "Analyst - Investment Banking"

cons: -Preach as if they encourage and support a work life balance, but the culture goes against this.

title: "Operations Intern"
