title: "Smart people, long hours"
pros: Smart people, name recognition for resume and above average pay
cons: Long hours and bureaucracy can be tough to deal with

title: "Good Place to work!"
pros: Good money, really smart people.
cons: no work life balance. politics in the system.

title: "Good Company to work for"
pros: Awesome work culture and good benefits
cons: Work Life Balance can be improved

title: "Great Opportunity"
pros: Get to fast track your career in finance. Learn a lot in a short period. Very professional attitude towards work.
cons: Long hours, lack of a social life.

title: "Logistics coordinator"
pros: Great Learning opportunities! learned alot in the 12 years i was there
cons: they are all about the bottom dollar your just a dollar amount to them so when the numbers are not made they will chop you with no thought what so ever!!! they talk about one thing but at they do another!!

title: "Learned a lot about the industry, but didn't gain a lot of real world experience."
pros: Great pay and work life balance in Salt Lake City
cons: Too much fluctuation in management.

title: "Vice President, GSAM"
pros: Great culture, Smart people, Structured training program for Juniors. Internal Mobility
cons: Competitive, GSAM not as respected as the sell side.

title: "Nice company"
pros: Nice building. Competitive pay. Competent tech environment.
cons: Long hours. Café food variety very limited.

title: "Challenging but filled with opportunities"
pros: Good compensation, plenty of opportunity for strong performers
cons: Very poor work life balance

title: "Good company"
pros: great place to develop your skills and trace your career path great company values and high standards
cons: tough hours and most of the time you have to keep motivating yourself to keep going considering the hours and sacrifices you make. But that's what I wanted to sign up for so

title: "Great firm, very smart people"
pros: I have met very few people who are not smart in this firm. Everyone at senior levels i.e Partner are very very competent, highly commercial and quite practical. The commitment to diversity etc is real. It is mostly a meritocracy.
cons: The firm needs to keep an eye on how much further the compensation ratio vs ROE tradeoff should go. Right now, it is pretty close to the point where there will be wider discontent. But needless to say this is something thats constantly discussed and watched internally.

title: "Talented people but tough place to work"
pros: Everyone is generally highly competent. Although there is still a lot of politics, there potentially is less than most other banks.
cons: Mobility between divisions is basically impossible. Have a culture of long hours and generally sharp elbows. IBD is not particularly supportive of women

title: "Great company to work for"
pros: The company values their employees very highly. The pay is OK, not incredible. The opportunity for advancement, along with the prestige of the company, are two of the biggest draws for GS.
cons: The hours can get long. Sometimes it seems as if the firm favors hires that are from outside the company. It's very fast-paced, but that is also a good thing.

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Nice management, a lot of mobility
cons: Training- would be nice to have additional training

title: "Nice place to Work"
pros: Salt Lake though has great crowd, nice people
cons: Does not have that many cons

title: "Good for people to start"
pros: Meet interesting and talented people
cons: Stressful and lack of balance

title: "Survival of the fittest"
pros: Challenging and the best out there.
cons: No work life balance. Can get political

title: "Great company to work for."
pros: Smartest people I have ever met.
cons: Work can be stressful sometimes.

title: "Great experience at Goldman.  Top Notch Company"
pros: Teamwork, smart people, driven to succeed
cons: Working hard to making work/life balance better

title: "Goldman"
pros: Steep learning curve and challenging environment Structured analyst training, and career path unfortunately if you don't come in as an analyst it is much harder
cons: Insider/clique culture where "outsiders" people not born and bred in the Goldman culture will find it hard to succeed.

title: "This place is a demanding and rewarding place to work."
pros: Great benefits and potential for earnings
cons: Long hours and big expectations.

title: "Great company but highly political"
pros: Smart people, interesting work, challenging
cons: Very political from most junior to most senior level

title: "Summer Internship"
pros: Fit with my interests, nice culture
cons: High work load, high pressure

title: "It was generally okay"
pros: Great soft drinks and they had yummy snacks
cons: People were odd and you could not bring dog to work

title: "Best bank to work for but things can change"
pros: Good pay, intelligent people, high efficiency
cons: Long hours, lack of diversity, low internal mobility

title: "Climbing the ladder!"
pros: People and responsibility. Amazing work culture.
cons: Ladder is tough to climb, stay for a while, committed and you will do well.

title: "Overrated"
pros: They sorely need techs who are rational and pragmatic and can lead the inexperienced pool of convertd interns. I can easily outperform peers. Although the marginal benefits of outperformance is low. In fact, the outperforming person gets leeched on by users, peers and managers who relegate their responsibilities, you need to learn to stop working and go home. The only outcome is that the chance of being laid off is low.
cons: Vicious and political corporate culture, pursue culture of treating individual as commodity, while the "system" is first class citizen. Talk of impact oriented, meritocratic culture is just corporate, marketing speak, far from reality. Annual culling of "low performing" employees frequently causes people to be politically oriented Non trading, non operations functions are really detached from the real businesses, have limited financial markets knowledge. Not much to learn from.

title: "Best Job I ever had"
pros: The level of the people you work with is absolutely top-notch! Compensation is fantastic.
cons: They basically own your time. You are expected to be responsive to things like email and text 24 x 7.

title: "Great benefits but poor management"
pros: Premier financial services firm. Benefits package. Extremely talented individuals.
cons: Lack of diversity and emphasis on cultural awareness. Seniority based. Poor management from a career development perspective.

title: "Equity Research"
pros: good experience, good support, good exit opps. exposure to the street, smart people, great work is awesome.
cons: overworked becasuse there are not enough staff members. you may end up pigeon holing yourself if you stay within an industry too long

title: "Senior Developer"
pros: Great caliber of people. Fast moving environment.
cons: Be prepare to live work

title: "Strong, admirable company culture that isn't always reflected by all teams or individuals"
pros: The firm overall really does work hard to ensure employees have the resources they need to be successful. From personal wellness classes, multiple corporate perks, and affinity networks to the robust 360 degree reviews and comprehensive training materials and professional skills classes. For self-motivated individuals, you will learn a tremendous amount from working here.
cons: Despite structured frameworks to promote a positive, healthy culture, there are many managers who circumvent these parameters. For example, despite 360 degree feedback, upper management still dictates the year-end performance review. At the end of the day, there is still a very strong undercurrent of politics despite the claim to be a meritocracy. This distracts from people doing real work and rewards people who spend more time self-promoting.

title: "Technology Team at Goldman Sachs"
pros: - Very smart people all around - Extremely busy and result focused - Cutting edge technologies used
cons: - You may be stuck doing bad work - so pro-actively fight that - Divide between strategists (high profile technologists with high business knowledge) and technology can make you uncomfortable

title: "Not a good employer"
pros: good pay, bad management, no time for self
cons: slog yourself, not much benefits, office culture not interesting

title: "Diverse organization."
pros: Diverse organization. Challenging. Decent benefits.
cons: Extremely bureaucratic. Even a small change or enhancement requires multiple levels of approval and confirmation. Small mistakes are counted against you during appraisals which can be frustrating. Noisy environment - especially working near trading desk - No privacy. Most of them have lunch at their desks - difficult for a fresh graduate to move up the ladder. Maximum number of years that a fresh graduate can survive is not more than 3 years unless he/she has good connections. Continuous change in managers and team - every 6 months. Internal mobility is purely based on performance. Legacy technologies - feels like you are in the mainframe era.

title: "Great Place to Learn Financial Technology"
pros: Colleagues are brilliant yet very fun social people, makes for a great environment day-to-day. Pay is good, can't complain there. Interesting problems facing the industry and close client interaction make the job consistently challenging in a great way. Remote working is easy and encouraged.
cons: The hours....you end up spending a lot of time here if you're trying to advance yourself. A lot of advice I've been given to get ahead basically translates to "do this extra task in your nonexistent free time". Focus is becoming more on cost control rather than building products to advance the business, which makes me worried for the future.

title: "Fun"
pros: Gold everywhere.....lots of gold and gold and gold
cons: Hours computers and excel and mouses

title: "It is a very challenge company"
pros: good pay, good reputation, good location
cons: long hours, hard colleagues, hard requirement

title: "Operations Summer Analyst"
pros: Great development throughout the summer with a lot of hands on training from team.
cons: Work days are 10 hours minimum, sitting at a desk all day. Can be exhausting and hard to balance with normal life.

title: "Analyst Developer"
pros: Pride which comes along. Smart people around you. Fast paced environment, you feel you did a lot at the end of the day but there is always much more to do. Instantaneous feedbacks
cons: Can be very demanding. Sometime people get to a point of pointing fingers More emphasis is paid on how and what are you doing not just about work. Micro managed and boils down to how many hours you put in and how well you please your higher ups The strategy to over work employees is not so good. I have seen almost everyone complain of having social lives messed up due to work demand.

title: "High pressure environment"
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Too much politics as you get senior, it becomes all about whom you know

title: "Dog Eat Dog"
pros: prestigious and can be well compensated
cons: thrown under the bus, always need to cya

title: "Intense fast paced environment with long hours"
pros: Experience, exposure, responsibility, compensation and prestige
cons: long hours, intense and relentless environment with no room for mistakes

title: "Good place to work"
pros: Good compensation and good health benefits though it went down from previous years.
cons: Finance Department is top-heavy and title doesn't match responsibility.

title: "Operation Analyst"
pros: Internal resource are amazing - you can learn so much from GS; people are responsible and teamwork-oriented.
cons: Less diversity than big cities (e.g. New York, Chicago, and S.F.); Limited Career Development Path for operations.

title: "Smart people, tough to navigate the organization"
pros: - Surrounded by talented and smart people. - Very fair in managing work and home life - they help you in times of strife.
cons: - Organizationally nebulous waters- very hard to get things done - in a way its too consensus oriented. - Organizationally too top heavy - very difficult to move ahead in the organizaton - easy to plateau out career wise.

title: "GS Operations is a great place to start If you want to be in finance or you don't have a plan out of college"
pros: A little background about myself, I worked in the Salt Lake City Office which has grown to be the second biggest location in the United States and my entire career was in Operations Division. Please take that into account. I can't speak for Sales, Trading, or any other division outside of having to deal with them on a regular basis to get work done nor can I talk about the other office locations outside having visited a few and all are different. Ops is great in that you can learn a lot of transferable skill sets and abilities that you can take to almost any job. You are only niched into ops by your own lack of creativity if you think that ops is a dead end career choice post college. I hope this helps puts things in perspective for a lot of you. I still believe that overall this is a great place to start a career although I would doubt that its a place where people ultimately make their careers (at least in Ops). Some Pros about GS is that - Professional growth If you don't know what you want to do in life running through the gauntlet that is Goldman Sachs is a smart move to build up your professional profile and skill set. You will be forced into situations that take you out of your comfort zone and if you are lucky you will have some good people around you to help you prepare and learn from those experiences. Every situation is treated with highest professional manner and everything you do is expected to be of the highest quality of work. Every report should be accurate and concise, every email professional in tone and content, every analysis has every angle covered with good presentation and the appropriate content for the audience. Everything matters and you better be sure your work is up to grade. Don't be scared they will understand you are new to this the first few times you make a mistake. - Smart people all around you If you haven't realized it by now you will shortly that you are rarely the smartest person in the room (if you are currently that will change at GS). These people are smart. Very smart. You can pull the wool over their eyes once or twice or maybe get by for awhile with a manager that doesn't care but in the long run (year or longer) you will be exposed. Thats ok, you don't always have to be the smartest in the room you just can't take it personal every time someone calls you out in public or private and get better. Again, this is Ops not other divisions. Ops is not out to call you out every time you make a mistake or criticize you on every idea. They do it its because the firm benefits more when your mediocre idea is vetted with other smart people and becomes a great proposal. Don't take it personal. - High stress environment This is a pro and a con. If you can handle a high stress environment you will thrive. If you can't you will learn to or you will be looking for a new job shortly after joining. GS puts a lot of pressure on you really quick. Like I said before, what you do matters and sometimes you have to make really hard decisions in short periods of time because market is closing or client is threatening a walk or your manager doesn't want to lose his or her head and needs you to crunch some numbers yesterday. Just know that once you overcome these obstacles you will be better for it. - Responsibility is high for junior individuals Another pro and con. Almost the same speech from high stress environment. - Mentors Rest assured the really good managers at GS (and they exist) understand that good junior analysts need good mentors to show them the ropes and take them under their wing. GS will even match you up with one if you haven't found one on your own. Just know that its on you to follow up with them and if you are smart you will have more than one and they will be strategically placed in positions that you can leverage. Reach out to them, gain their insight and heed their advice because they have been there longer than you and guess what they are still there and successful so they must know what they are talking about. Just don't restrict yourself to one, get many and get them from backgrounds that you are not comfortable with. More perspectives will often change your own on a situation. Take this advice; man walks in a desert when he surrounds himself with people that think and act like him.
cons: - Work/Life balance Forget it, you won't have one. You work 10 hour days on a good day and 15+ on a bad day. Your dog will drown in anxiety or chew up your sneaker collection, your wife will hate your job, your kids will wonder if you love them and your friends will inevitably people that work with you or in the same industry. Assuming of course you are on the path to success at the firm. Otherwise you may be able to pull off weekend getaways, the occasional afterwork drink and hey maybe even the gym to burn off all those donuts you ate your desk. - High stress environment Read above but if you can't handle being in a stressful, high strung, alpha environment where everything you do matters than please save yourself the therapy sessions and medical costs and try something else. - The actual work can be boring Yeah it sucks, especially at the analyst level. Guess what? Processing transactions, data entry, project testing, trade settlement, account opening, etc all suck. They are not fun. Not even a little. But it gets better... you know when you are an Associate and you are leading a team of analysts doing something they hate for that almighty dollar. - Corporate politics This is not unique to GS. For those that are in college are have never worked at a large organization please mentally prepare yourself for the office politics. They are there and you are playing whether you like it or not. You can choose not to play and hope by the good graces of Allah and Blankfein that you are noticed for your good work but I have a higher chance of getting that 10 at the gym to ask me out on date. You are going to have to play. Marathon some Suits on USA and learn up on office politics and keep yourself out of the crosshairs as much as you can. Build friendships and network, don't through people under the bus, and don't take credit for someone else's work and you will be fine. This is where a mentor will do you well. - Compensation Analyst level it sucks and you will kick yourself for it. Stick it out and get lucky that the firm has a great year and you too can have a great year. Just remember its based on how well the firm did, how well your business unit did, and how well you did. Oh and you are also in ops which is at the end of the day a cost and not a revenue generating arm of the firm and so you will never get rich until you make MD. Well off at VP but not rich. - Senior Leadership How can I say this. Just because Michael Jordan was arguably the best player ever... doesn't mean he is a great coach. Phil Jackson was a mediocre player and well look what he accomplished. GS traditionally promotes Jordan's to management so prepare yourself. - Accountability You should definitely have this. Some people won't and some people will. Sadly you will find there are large groups in GS Ops that are not. You can't change them and unfortunately those that don't are what slows down good businesses. Be accountable and you will be surprised on how fortunate that will be for you. Heck, be accountable for other people, it shows leadership and managers will recognize that. - Can't trade (oddly a big downer) GS Ops cannot trade on personal accounts. Well you can but only if you first check with your manager, the compliance lists and your mom. Sadly almost every company is on some list that restricts you from trading. Get used to indexes and big funds. Its like working for Sam Adams and company policy says you cant drink... ever without asking them first. - Grindhouse mentality for some areas There are areas of GS Ops that are quite literally grindhouses. They take you in, chew you up, and then spit you out when you are done. Then they go out and get the next college kid and repeat. Sorry its just how it is. Learn what you can and transfer to another area if you want or leave but its their business model and it works for management.

title: "Stressfull"
pros: Brand name, good benefits, internal mobility
cons: Long working hours, Stressful,

title: "A fair and organized company."
pros: They treat everyone fairly. They have a yearly review that will bring out the strong and weak points of every individual who works for them.
cons: Depending on the division that one is working in, there can be politics and favoritism that takes place, however, this happens just about everywhere else.

title: "Demanding but rewarding experience with upward mobility for strong performers"
pros: *Significant responsibility given to junior employees, with opportunity for career advancement *Highly competent colleagues that are both intelligent and efficient *Offers much better than average pay relative to comparable positions at other firms
cons: *Work/life balance could still use improvement, though hours are largely manager dependent and similar to that of other firms *Bureaucracy and internal politics make the work environment fairly stressful at times

title: "Started off great but working here didn't live up to the reputation or the hype"
pros: Great opportunity to learn about the financial industry. Worked with incredibly smart people.
cons: Lip service was given to teamwork but senior management seems to give themselves all the credit for success. Sr management makes promises but keep their word to their employees. Mentors and advocates are needed for lateral hires but mentors are the only ones they help with

title: "Operations Analyst"
pros: Good Company name and culture
cons: boring job, little learning and development

title: "Associate"
pros: Smart people under one roof
cons: tough environment to work in

title: "Good experience but difficult long term"
pros: Good on resume. Smart people. Learned a lot
cons: Burn out. Long hours. Competitive

title: "Work life balance, non existent"
pros: - Best and the brightest to work with. - Great benefits (401K, vacation, unlimited sick, health insurance, life insurance, 4 months paid time off maternity)
cons: - work/life balance does not exist. In order to get promoted in the company your complete focus needs to be on your job. Regular outside activities are not encouraged. Very difficult to have a life outside of work. - Regular hours do not exist. Employees are expected to work until the job is done, even if that means 16 hours/day for weeks or sometimes months on end. - culture is very corporate. Difficult to make changes to processes or procedures. - no perks! Including no company parties, not even for Christmas. Only thing free in the office is coffee and water (if the water dispenser is working).

title: "Peerless"
pros: I worked with the very, very best. A once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. They take doing things the right way very seriously. Read their statement of values; they actually believe and aspire to them.
cons: The hours are long and the expectation for dedication to the company is high. It's a stressful work environment requiring full focus and desire to succeed.

title: "Great people and great culture"
pros: The best thing about the firm is outstandingly smart people at the firm. Working with the extremely smart individuals, you naturally push yourself to learn more and grow. People are very hard working and it is engrained in the culture. The importance of teamwork at GS is not overstated; people are all willing to help each other.
cons: At this time, there are too many regulatory requirements that GS needs to comply to, meaning a lot of resources are spent on reg related projects, and not so much on other innovative profitable projects.

title: "Smart People but long hours"
pros: Work with very smart people
cons: Long hours and low base salary (big bonus tho)

title: "Good company to work for"
pros: Good compensation, great technical oppertunities
cons: work life balance is a struggle

title: "It's not who you are it's who is waiting in the wings to replace you."
pros: Benefits are a positive but they are gradually cutting those as well.
cons: Long hours, low pay and poor morale

title: "Great Place smart people, political"
pros: Great learning experience, lots of reps
cons: Disconnect between senior leaders and jr members

title: "Entry level operations position."
pros: Lots of control over project work.
cons: Not as much of a meritocracy or as team-based as I had hoped.

title: "Investment Banking Analyst Program"
pros: Terrific 1st job out of undergrad. Exposure to high level corporate transactions. Financial Modeling training.
cons: Work life balance. Hierarchy. Plenty of work never makes it to client.

title: "Great experience at Goldman"
pros: Excellent firm culture. In my view, senior management did all that it could to connect with employees and make them feel valued. Even questions on reviews of managers were thoughtful and demonstrated that management cares about creating a culture of fairness and respect.
cons: It is a very structured organization -- this makes for a well-run operation, but at times certain processes (eg getting Compliance and management approvals) can take longer than at smaller organizations.

title: "Demanding and satisfying work"
pros: Highly intelligent, knowledgeable and supportive coworkers
cons: It tends to be at least a 60 hour work week

title: "Goldman Sachs Analyst"
pros: great clients, great pay, smart coworkers
cons: bad hours, a lot of work

title: "Product Controller"
pros: Very intelligent co-workers and sr. management
cons: Do not have any to list here

title: "Overall , GS is nice place to work"
pros: Good working environment and people is nice (based on which office you work at) Lot internal sources available for employee and great benefit.
cons: Comp could be better ( based on the hour we put in and market rate).

title: "Good"
pros: good job development oppurtunities, particularly at the start of your career
cons: large org with a lot of politics

title: "A great place to work for someone who is looking to utilize teamwork skills in a fast pace financial setting."
pros: The people and culture make this place thrive. If you are not a team player then this isn't the place for you. Great coworkers
cons: Work life balance is non existent if you want to proceed up the corporate ladder. Prepare to dedicate your life.

title: "Good Culture and Organization"
pros: I work in the SLC office. And, although there has been some historical discontent about the policies/attitudes of individual managers, I think the firm takes the time to reassert the message that gets communicated to employees. I can say that the company culture is very inclusive and open. The organization is as much of a meritocracy as you can get. Most people who produce good results are rewarded for it. You also feel very connected to the other offices around the world as global meetings are held via video conference to keep employees tuned in to what's going on.
cons: Not too many cons. Your bonus is unpredictable and is based on annual firm performance.

title: "Interesting"
pros: Good brand name on resume, learning opportunities, some great people. Despite the declining opportunities on the sell-side, GS is still a great place to start a career. On the whole, it seems to be more intelligently managed and aggressive in its capital allocation than other banks as well.
cons: Many people think they are smarter than they are (read - arrogant). Higher ups in the organization are only focused on the bottom line attributable to them/supporting their bonus, not necessarily moving people to the roles in which they will most benefit the company.

title: "Challenging 10 weeks, in a bad way"
pros: Some folks were great, a lot of folks were fine. The exposure to senior level meetings and decision making was truly valuable.
cons: Naturally, the hours were bad, but presumably you know what you are signing up for. I had worked long hours before but it is much harder without the sense of teamwork, camaraderie, and gratitude from senior folks. A few people were genuinely malicious and there was no way to protect yourself from them and no recourse when you were mistreated. Before I started people told me that a lot of backstabbing goes on at Goldman. I didn't really know what that meant until a few weeks into my summer. Most people were smart enough, but they didn't seem to be anything exceptional. If anything, the experience gives you the sense that smartest guys on Wall Street really aren't that clever. The simplistic level of the financial analyses and the lack of thought that goes into the inputs to analyses was eye-opening.

title: "Processing"
pros: - Great brand name to have on your resume - Occasional exposure to complex finance
cons: - Facetime/perceptions oriented culture - Work has been so streamlined it is mundane and requires little critical thinking - Management prioritizes immediate cost saving over spending the money required to improve processes resulting in little/no progress towards improving efficiency - Compensation has been consistently poor for several years - Extremely high attrition among A1-3s is very discouraging as many go on to better opportunities elsewhere - Poor work life balance - SLC provides significantly fewer outlets for good nightlife and culture than other cities

title: "Great place to work overall"
pros: Great people, lots of opportunities, great benefits
cons: Getting promoted can get political. People are very competitive and performance is subjective.

title: "Company itself is great, management is horrible."
pros: Smart people who know how to work hard. You can learn a lot by just listening to client calls and the advice of coworkers on investing and running a business.
cons: No work-life balance at all. Judged solely on work product and ability to be the first in the door and the last out. Management does not respect that employees are people with lives outside of the office, and lots of management is not 'trained' how to be a manager.

title: "Summer Intern"
pros: Great people and very organized company
cons: Long hours and work environment was not personally what I am looking for

title: "Excellent Company"
pros: Best company to work in. Gets lot of exposure and get to work with best in industry
cons: It is very difficult to maintain work life balance due to high expectations

title: "Great compensation, long hours"
pros: - Good money - Working with the best - Great bonuses
cons: - Long work days (but expected)

title: "Great place to work, if you can handle long hours"
pros: Team oriented work environment Guided career development Meritocracy Lots of locations for mobility across the global Diverse workforce Professional work environment
cons: Long work hours with little incentive to stay late Secrecy around compensation Unbalanced in the mid range ( i.e. your position really helps progression) Structured in early career is difficult to progress fast

title: "Positive culture, colorful people"
pros: GS has a culture of excellence. People strive to do the best at whatever it is their job requires. Employees understand that they are each a key piece of the puzzle, and that GS plays a very important role in the global markets. From back-office operations to client-facing sales folks, GS employees are smart, interesting, and collaborative. The company knows how important it is to retain talent, so they compensate well, and are starting to emphasize the importance of maintaining a healthy work-life balance.
cons: The days can be stressful and sometimes way too fast-paced. Some teams are stretched incredibly thinly, and mistakes are sometimes made because there is so much to keep track of.

title: "Best managed large company in the world, but not for everyone"
pros: Competent, friendly people. Lots of talent.
cons: Ambiguous structure and promotion tracks, can be political. Big company bureaucracy. Somewhat inbred.

title: "Great place to work hard, and get paid for it."
pros: Smart people, great analyst class, offers a good career path due to its reputation. Its reputation goes a long way in your search for the next job. Provides good training for junior people.
cons: Very long hours, pressure from senior people, high turnover of excellent people... seems like the company is losing very good talent quickly. It is a very hierarchical firm especially in investment banking (not so in securities).

title: "Satisfying experience but not without points of frustration"
pros: Team oriented culture, opportunities for training and development, working environment with talented and diverse individuals, favorable compensation relative to other investment banks, increasingly genuine focus on work life balance
cons: As you move up in seniority, advancement in the firm becomes increasingly based on politics as much as ability (or more so in many cases)

title: "Good."
pros: There are to many pros to mention.
cons: There are no cons at all.

title: "Overworked for decent, though inconsistant pay"
pros: money awesome maternity leave policy great benefits impressive company name to have on your resume
cons: crazy hours no work/life balance pay varies greatly from year to year, even if you are in a support function (like HR) ol boys network - impossible to penetrate very dependent on your manager - if no one likes him/her, you have no shot at getting anywhere, regardless of how hard you work access to senior management is limited interview process is ridiculous

title: "nice people"
pros: Best in the industry and so looks good on one's resume. Ideal for folks who want to be in the finance world
cons: it is hard to maintain work/life balance and so difficullt particularly for those with little kids

title: "Great place for a creer"
pros: Very good work ethics, smart and motivated people to work with, great mentorship programs
cons: Pay is average, not that competitive.

title: "The best of the best"
pros: Smart people, team culture, leader in most business segments
cons: Long hours, strained reputation at present

title: "Great place to learn"
pros: Work with the smartest people
cons: In my case, recognition achieved via politics and not production

title: "worst experience ever. I regret stepping into this so called best company to work for. It is an illusion on paper."
pros: Employees are spoiled with big salaries, big bonus, perks and rewards here and there.
cons: Major back stabbing, hierarchy issues still at play, assistants are miserable, old, have festered and cranky. No room for growth whatsoever for the assistants. Profanity usage runs galore. There is no confidentiality. You can hear everything about the client being discussed by employees even when they are bad mouthing the client.

title: "In the words of the man who threatened to fire me, "This place isn't for everyone"."
pros: Goldman offers fantastic training seminars that anyone is welcome to attend. Also, I really did feel like I was learning from the best in the banking industry. The wealth of knowledge that the business leaders have is unbelievable, and if you can manage to schedule some time with them, you'll probably learn more about the industry than you could anywhere else.
cons: Constant fear. Every person in the office I worked in in Salt Lake knew that only a few missteps could cost them their job. Once a year management picks a bunch of employees they want to replace and walks them out the door (keep in mind, these are all brilliant, hard-working people). Management will remind you of these routine expulsions as means of motivation. Working at Goldman is an intense scramble to be better than your co-workers, because you know that if they happen to be better than you, you will be treated as expendable. I was more anxious and stressed at Goldman than I've ever been in my career, and developed constant, throbbing headaches and had a very hard time sleeping. If management thinks they can replace you with someone better, they won't hesitate to do it. Firing dedicated employees is a very common and cavalier occurrence at Goldman. A culture of rudeness and extreme passive-aggressive behavior is pervasive throughout the company. If someone thinks you aren't important, they often won't respond to your e-mails or calls, regardless of how desperately you need their help. This kind of behavior is completely accepted. Also, expect business leaders to be extremely critical and demanding.

title: "Cool Experience, but not as Competitive as the Companies in the West."
pros: Goldman Sachs is kind enough to offer pretty competitive stipends and housing compensation (though not enough to fully cover housing). However, it was filled with ambitious people and was a challenging experience.
cons: Goldman Sachs is a great work experience, but the pay isn't as competitive as Google/Amazon/Facebook etc. Also, the housing stipend for summer interns is pretty low considering the insane prices of NYC.

title: "Fast paced and challenging work with a bunch of people with great work ethic"
pros: Fast faced; challenging; ability to make an impact; meritocracy; lack of politics at the rank and file level. The company gives a lot of opportunities for people who want to excel. But at the end of the day, you need to be a team player. If you are not, you are out.
cons: Bad work-life balance; reduced pay and bonuses due to new regulations. Bonuses are not awarded equally between business and federation functions (like operations, technology etc) due to which there's some resentment.

title: "Good company"
pros: * Very competitive * Work with a lot of talented people
cons: * Big company issues - sometimes things get lost in transition

title: "Politics"
pros: Best of Minds in the industry
cons: Long hours and office politics

title: "You Get to Work With the Best"
pros: The facilities and the people that you work with are top notch. You are given a lot of responsibility early on, and if you stick around long enough you'll get promoted at least to the Associate level (pretty much the equivalent of a VP at any other bank).
cons: No work life balance, the work can become really mundane and finding a reason to stick around becomes difficult. Pay can also be better, but because the Goldman name is worth so much on a CV they pay the younger employees less compared to the competitor

title: "Overall I have been satisfied with my managers, colleagues and work environment."
pros: Meritocracy, reputation, global footprint, quality of coworkers.
cons: Lack of transparency with pay, work life balance, turnover.

title: "Fantastic place to work, abysmal work/life balance."
pros: The best bulge Investment bank on the street, period. The opportunity to work with some very bright people in on some very interesting deals. Great benefits package. Great place to have a child (Although you will never see them again once your Paternity/Maternity leave is up) Motivation to grow and push yourself to be the best.
cons: If you are single when you start you can plan on staying single until you move on, or marring a co-worker. It does vary dramatically with what group you happen to be on however, many groups have virtually no life outside of work. I have talked with people on other teams who only work 60 hours per week. It has been my experience that the more interesting the work the greater the demand for people to work on the team and the more you can expect to work. You are really compensated a year in arrears. Base is base but GS Pays you for what you have done this year in next year’s bonus. It’s a clever way to increase employee retention. Although if you ever quit you will miss out on a lot of remuneration you have earned.

title: "lack of caring for loyal workers"
pros: good pay & bonus and opportunity to learn
cons: knowledge and loyalty are not always rewarded

title: "Less cool than in the movies, but still pretty cool."
pros: Pay is pretty good, and there's smooth jazz always playing in the men's room. If you're an assertive self-starter, you'll move up quick. High energy environment.
cons: If you aren't a member of the tribe you'll have restricted access to the cafeteria, but there was a good Afghan place around the corner.

title: "A good career start"
pros: Global team. Good internal mobility opportunities, even across regions. Challenging tasks.
cons: Very political. Work life balance...

title: "Focused!"
pros: Intelligent colleagues, streamlined internal systems and good benefits.
cons: There are a few great single contributors that should never have been placed in people management roles.

title: "Fulfilling experience but physically draining (high burnout factor)"
pros: Work with some of the brightest people on Wall Street
cons: Work with some of the biggest egos on Wall Street

title: "Fantastic place to work and advance your career."
pros: Great place to work. Good benefits. Great on resume--just in case. Prestigious.
cons: Lots of time spent working. I feel like I'm working all day and not doing enough.

title: "An exhilarating place to work"
pros: Passionate, driven, bright people, with an endless amount of responsibility and promise
cons: Doesn't pay well amidst the downturn and regulatory environment

title: "OK experience"
pros: Plenty of career opportunities at GS
cons: Company randomly moved employees to different divisions at height of crisis Not a great work-life balance Need to think about regulatory environment before taking a job here

title: "Rewarding Experience"
pros: -Learned a lot about the corporate culture -Feel confident about working for other companies because of the experience
cons: -Long hours and sometimes stressful

title: "Collaborative culture"
pros: Supportive team members Career progression Network opportunities
cons: Fluctuating business conditions Steep learning curve

title: "Good company, smart people, zero work-life balance."
pros: Great people. Terrific training and great place to start one's career.
cons: Zero work-life balance. Racked up a lot of vacation days, but was never able to use them.

title: "It has been an eye opening and mostly rewarding experience in the back office."
pros: Great employee benefits, including state of the art facilities and high compensation. Often perceived as among the best in the various fields it takes part in.
cons: Be prepared to work hard and sometimes long hours. There is a great debate ongoing as to whether the Goldman Sachs that made its reputation still exists or is being diluted over time.

title: "Poor work life balance."
pros: Working with the best of the industry
cons: Impossible deadlines. Extremely long hours and work around the clock.

title: "great company"
pros: The culture at GS is great, and you're surronded by smart people. The firm does a lot of great stuff for employees too - great speakers, philanthropy, etc.
cons: I found job mobility much easier said than done. it was really hard to move into new roles durnig the tough years and there was a lot of hesitation about switiching divisions

title: "A good place to learn and get experience"
pros: Great learning opportunities, if you are proactive and willing to put in the time and explore
cons: Limited growth, some areas are very political

title: "Great company, pay, and benfits. Experiences may vary..."
pros: Very good pay, benefits are nice.
cons: Slow growth opportunities (despite all they preach) Your experience is completely dependant on your manager. The person directly to my left loves his job, I hate mine. We do the same job, but my manager is awful (only looks out for themself), and his is great. Before accepting a job here, be sure to interview your soon to be manager as much as they are interviewing you.

title: "Good learning experience, but ultimately a cog in a wheel."
pros: Many experienced and senior people who are good at business are driving the business forward.
cons: Too much politics (as one would expect of any large company). Also, as a junior person, one feels like being a copy editor and completely at the whim of one's boss (typically middle management) - there is meritocracy - measured by hours and face time - it is not a healthy one.

title: "Ok for the first couple of years"
pros: Great people! Best people I've ever had the pleasure to work with. Coworkers are helpful and intelligent and you'll always feel part of the team. Work/Life balance is fine. Worse than other Fin Firms, but it's GS!
cons: Salary is terrible for Tech. Wouldn't recommend it for other Tech people. As in most places, work is interesting at first. Over time, it gets repetitive.

title: "Great company to work for."
pros: As long as you give your all, you will be recognized and rewarded.
cons: Can be somewhat "clickish" and political.

title: "OK to work for."
pros: Talented people. Pay not up to the mark as compared to market
cons: Technology People not paid up to the par.

title: "Was a good learning experience"
pros: Good Location and work culture. Smart people to work with. New hires are given four month analyst training which is pretty intense
cons: Not working in the main stream if coming from a technical background. Mainly applications development. Not a lot of innovation. No documented processes

title: "Good"
pros: great compensation for top quartile performers, plenty of opportunities to learn, great colleagues
cons: poor work life balance, really poor communication in certain departments, constant organizational changes leading to low morale

title: "Fun, great place to start a career."
pros: Great Place to work, smart people everywhere.
cons: Work life balance is tough (what's new).

title: "Great"
pros: Good learning opportunity, lots of exposure to different industries, and a great place to meet new friends
cons: Long hours, stress, lack of sleep, a lot of tedious work sometimes, pressure, constant demand to be a high performer

title: "Nurturing your career, constant pressure"
pros: Goldman Sachs is an excellent place to begin your career. The training programs are robust and holistic, and managers really care about developing each and every person.
cons: The pressure to 'do more' is pervasive and inescapable. While this mindset does help drive progress, it is often excessive, and getting ahead requires inordinate amounts of effort. Also, pay is very dependent on the market and is therefore unpredictable in the short term.

title: "Brilliant"
pros: It is the best investment bank in the world
cons: There is nothing cons with GS

title: "Technology Analyst"
pros: A lot of responsibilities and opportunities to grow Supportive managers Collaborative teamwork environment
cons: You will be stressed Reputation is a big thing Political

title: "Current Analyst Developer working for one of the Goldman flagship product in Equities."
pros: 1.Your peers, your manager and your manager's manager and beyond are incredibly smart too. You spend very little time explaining but more on iterating through different plans. 2. You define your responsibility by asking question/concerns. Most times if you can convince your higher-up that something needs to be done. You get the job to address it.(from re-writing a critical module design to creating a test-harness). 3. You get to put on different hats. I am a low-latency c++ developer and I have worked from researching and requirement gathering directly from external client to doing development , deploying and testing with the client for user-acceptance. I have also managed a project. 4. People are in general helpful even in scenarios where they dont get credit for what they are helping out on.
cons: 1. The company especially the equity side is moving from a fast paced development centric division to consolidation and development with caution model. This means a lot of boring administrative jobs get thrown at you.(fill mammoth release tickets etc) 2. As much as it can be pro , undefined roles can hurt you very much. 3. Its way too lean. My direct manager has a 18+yrs of experience and is a global manager for a entire business line.Its a challenge at crisis, pressure moments to communicate with my manager in a language he expects at this level. 4. Pay scale is at best mediocre now when compared to tech bigs.

title: "Challenging and competitive, but very rewarding"
pros: People are nice, intelligent, hard working
cons: long work hours. Everyone is an alpha type.

title: "Work hard, work hard."
pros: Goldman is willing to give you as much responsibility as you can handle. Some bright people, mostly at the very junior and very senior levels - less so in the middle. Very good exit opportunities.
cons: 100+ hour workweeks for the norm for investment banking analysts. Little concern for employees' long-term career trajectory, much more interested in maximizing their short-term productivity.

title: "I think it is a good place to intern but not a really good place to work for full-time position"
pros: They have a really good program for interns to connect to each other. U have opportunities to expand your network.
cons: You have to be active to ask what u need until you get it because all of them are very busy

title: "Awesome place to work at"
pros: Good work life balance, good growth opportunity.
cons: Long hours sometime required. More diversity needed.

title: "Amazing opportunity"
pros: The people that work there are incredibly talented, hard working, and intelligent. Just having Goldman on your resume pens up many opportunities in other sectors.
cons: Depending on what group you're in, you can spend long hours on the job. I was putting in roughly 80-100 hour weeks. You're compensated generously, but have to make the job your life. Everyone expects you to live to a certain ideal.

title: "Constant pressure to perform"
pros: collaborative, intelligent and ambitious coworkers, career opportunities
cons: work/life balance, stress, becoming political, much more focus on cost resulting in downsizing.

title: "work us like dogs"
pros: comp is decent relative to peers
cons: no life outside of work

title: "Very poorly managed."
pros: Name recognition of Goldman Sachs on resume.
cons: Micro-managed. Very poor morale amongst non-management.

title: "Solid Company, Low Pay"
pros: Very impressive benefits Great coworkers Potential for upward mobility but you have to be able to weather to storm financially
cons: Low Pay Expect long work days

title: "Not what it used to be"
pros: Opportunity to work with some of the hardest working and driven people in the industry, Compensation can be top-notch in "good years"
cons: Review process can be very political and lack ability to effect true results

title: "Publishing Assistant"
pros: The pay, benefits and fellow staff were amazing
cons: The hours were too much. Was very hard to have a work life balance

title: "Great place to work"
pros: smart people, a lot of growth
cons: intense, long hours, must perform

title: "Good prospect for out-of-college / grad school graduates to start a career"
pros: 1) Best Team to work with 2) Sharing knowledge 3) Employee values for good work
cons: 1) Have to work more than the regular working hours sometimes. 2) Lack of multicultural diversity in the Technology Division at Salt Lake City

title: "Highly focused firm that is good at what they do"
pros: Decent pay, good work environment, like-minded individuals
cons: Short on bonuses, long work hours

title: "analyst"
pros: Good brand name on your resume
cons: Salary not competitive comparing to peers

title: "Great place, smart people"
pros: The vast majority of people at GS are extremely smart, talented and hardworking. You can learn a great deal from the people around you. Atmosphere is very collegial and demanding.
cons: Job satisfaction and advancement is highly dependent on your manager. If your manager is not great, your opportunities at the Firm are significantly more challenged.

title: "Great firm / culture"
pros: Pay, culture, smart colleagues and opportunities to work in different geographies / business units
cons: Lack of work-life balance and work can be uninteresting at times

title: "Everyone in the SLC office is miserable"
pros: The people in the other offices are talented
cons: Low pay, long hours, expect you to bend over backwards for them to not reciprocate in any way
